###Chapter 1

"Evelyn, you've lived with the Lowells for fifteen years. I truly can't bear to see you go..."

Vincent Lowell stood in the center of the living room, his eyes reddened, voice choked with emotion—the very picture of a doting father reluctant to part with his child.

Evelyn Roland held her suitcase in one hand, a black backpack slung carelessly over her shoulder. She glanced at her adoptive father's theatrics, the corner of her lips curling into a cold smirk.

Had she not overheard his scheming in the study that night, she might have actually fallen for this hypocritical act.

At six years old, she'd been rescued from human traffickers by Charles Lowell. A head injury had stolen her memories, leaving her with only the face of her savior. The kind-hearted old man took her in as his own.

For the decade he lived, she'd known peace. But when his old illness flared up, even her skills could only extend his life by ten years.

Everything she'd done for the Lowells in secret, only Charles had known. On his deathbed, he willed her 10% of the family shares—ostensibly to protect her, but in truth, to ensure she'd continue safeguarding the Lowell empire.

She saw through it but didn't refuse.

The moment the funeral ended, Vincent's mask slipped. That night, she'd heard all three of them in the study, plotting how to drive her out.

"If we can't find her real parents, we'll frame her for scandal!" Margaret Hill's shrill voice still rang in her ears.

And Vincent? Not a single word of protest.

How laughable. All her sincerity, wasted on ungrateful snakes.

She didn’t care about the shares. Only Charles' kindness had tied her here. Now that he was gone, there was nothing left for her in this house.

"Goodbye, Mr. Lowell."

She turned, dragging her suitcase behind her, her voice icy and detached. The grief on Vincent's face froze instantly, twisting into something ugly.

"Ungrateful wretch!" Margaret sprang from the couch, her spite on full display. "Even a dog wags its tail before leaving. She can't even say a proper farewell!"

Beside her, Victoria Lowell—her mother’s spitting image with those sharp, upturned brows—sneered. "Mom, trash will always be trash. No amount of polishing in the Lowell mansion could turn her into a diamond. But it’s perfect—she’ll fit right back in that dumpster of a village."

To force her out, Vincent had paid handsomely to trace her roots—Jiangshui Village. The Rolands were the poorest family there, parents who scavenged for scraps, with four good-for-nothing sons.

She could imagine the life awaiting her.

A glint of malice flashed in Victoria’s eyes as she suddenly stood and shoved a wad of cash at Evelyn. "Here, little sister. Take this ten thousand. I wanted to write a check, but I doubt your village even has a bank..."

Lowering her voice, she added smugly, "Oh, and some good news—I’m pregnant with Nathan’s baby. He said a wild stray like you was never worthy of him. It’s always been me he loved—"

Evelyn’s crimson lips curved. "A toad with a slug—a perfect match. I’m just glad I didn’t get stained by such garbage. The stench is unbearable."

Victoria’s face turned livid. She yanked at Evelyn’s backpack—and with a clatter, a pure gold medal hit the floor.

"My piano competition medal!" Victoria shrieked dramatically. "You stole it!"

Margaret lunged forward. "I knew she was a thief! Search her bag!"

Vincent frowned. "Evelyn, is this—"

"Does it even need asking?" Margaret cut in shrilly. "She’s desperate! Butler, search her now!"

Amid the tension, Evelyn laughed.

From her bag, she pulled out a larger gold emblem studded with emeralds. "Recognize this?"

Victoria paled. "The Jury President’s Badge from the International Piano Masters?!"

"Compare the status, the weight, the value—which of hers even comes close?" Evelyn smirked, casually projecting surveillance footage onto the living room screen.

The video clearly showed Victoria slipping the medal into her bag.

Gasps filled the room.

Victoria scrambled to shut off the TV while Margaret spat, "You installed cameras in our home?!"

"How many times have you framed me? I only let it slide out of respect for Charles." Evelyn flicked the miniature camera on her backpack charm. "As for the badge... Did you really think the theft of a jury president’s emblem wouldn’t make headlines?"

The debt was repaid. These three clowns wouldn’t get another ounce of her courtesy.
###Chapter 2

Evelyn Roland's slender fingers traced the edge of her phone as her icy gaze swept over the three members of the Lowell family.

"Where Victoria's piano talent truly comes from—you know better than anyone." Her voice was frosty. "The compositions I wrote over the years more than repay the Lowells for raising me."

Vincent Lowell's expression darkened.

"After I turned twelve, I never spent a single cent of the Lowell family's money." The corner of her lips curled into a mocking smile. "And as for the Evans family engagement—shall I expose your schemes right here?"

Margaret Hill trembled with rage, but her husband gripped her arm to stop her.

A bead of sweat trickled down Vincent's temple. The crisis three years ago still haunted him. The old patriarch had claimed Evelyn was the one who secretly intervened. He’d refused to believe a teenage foster daughter could possess such influence.

"Evelyn, I’ve always treated you as my own—" he began, voice pleading.

"Enough." She cut him off. "From today onward, I have no ties to the Lowells. If you slander me again..." She paused, her eyes glinting dangerously. "I won’t hesitate to let the entire city know how the Lowells treat their foster daughter."

Just then, a flustered servant rushed in. "Sir! There’s a troublemaker at the gate claiming he’s here to pick someone up!"

Margaret shrieked, "Filthy trash! This family is cursed!"

Evelyn grabbed her suitcase and turned to leave. Behind her, Victoria’s triumphant laughter rang out. "A garbage collector dares compete with me?"

As she stepped through the gates, her phone buzzed.

"Withdraw all support from Lowell Enterprises," she said coolly.

A furious male voice erupted from the other end. "Those ungrateful snakes! If not for your behind-the-scenes maneuvering, they’d have gone bankrupt years ago! And that Victoria—stealing your compositions and flaunting them—"

"I’m going to find my birth parents," Evelyn interjected softly.

A brief silence followed. "What if—"

"I know what I’m doing."

The screech of tires cut her off. A black Maybach hurtled toward her.

With lightning reflexes, she braced against the hood, her scattered belongings strewn across the pavement.

"Watch where you’re going!" the driver barked.

Evelyn slammed her palm against the window. "No honking in residential zones. Get out and pick these up!"

A deep, magnetic voice spoke from the backseat. "Step out."

The driver immediately fell silent.

Evelyn’s gaze flicked to the rear seat. In the interplay of light and shadow, the man’s chiseled profile was sculpted perfection. But when she glimpsed the faint crimson flicker in his dark eyes, her pupils constricted.

That toxin... She’d only read about it in ancient texts.

"Sir," she suddenly smiled, radiant. "May I have your number?"
###Chapter 3

Sebastian Valdemar's thin lips curved into a dangerous yet captivating smirk. His frosty gaze swept past Evelyn Roland before settling on the trembling driver.

"Who gave you permission to pick things up?" His voice was low. "Get out and inspect the car. Record everything. Don't leave any room for fraud accusations."

The driver paled. "Yes! This young lady did bump into the front of the car. I'll check thoroughly."

He moved to open the door.

Evelyn let out a cold laugh and slammed it shut with one hand.

"Fraud?" She arched a brow. "You were the ones speeding through a residential area and blaring your horn. Does driving a luxury car make you above the law?"

The man's dark eyes locked onto her, gleaming like ink under the backlight. He scoffed. "So it's not fraud. Then stopping a car in the street to ask for contact details—that counts as harassment."

Evelyn nearly laughed out loud. She raked her eyes over him without restraint. "The poison in your body will cripple you within two years. You'll be bedridden, muscles atrophied, completely dependent. Harass you? For what? That pretty face?"

The driver gasped.

Was this woman insane? How dare she speak to Mr. Valdemar like that...

Sebastian's expression darkened instantly. How did she know about the poison?

"Who the hell are you?"

Evelyn leaned in slightly, her beautiful face alight with provocation. "Oh? Interested in me? Sorry, sir, we’re not acquainted. Keep this up, and I’ll sue you for harassment."

She threw his words right back at him.

With a bright, mocking smile, she released the car door and stepped back. "Weren’t you going to inspect the car? You take care of your vehicle, and you’ll compensate me for my things. Oh, and don’t forget to apologize properly."

The driver stood frozen, caught between a rock and a hard place.

Sebastian studied Evelyn for a long moment before growling, "Drive!"

The window rolled up, and the Maybach roared away in a cloud of dust.

Evelyn waved off the exhaust fumes, cursing the man’s insanity under her breath. As she bent to gather her scattered belongings, she noticed the Maybach was heading toward the Lowell estate.

A car with triple license plates meant extraordinary status. Since when had the Lowells befriended someone like that?

Inside the car, Sebastian’s relaxed posture was gone. He stared at his legs, his expression stormy.

Crippled? Dependent?

The woman’s words stabbed into him like knives. Coincidence, or could she really see through him at a glance? And those eyes—strangely familiar...

Evelyn dragged her suitcase to the gated community entrance, where an argument was still raging.

Three security guards stood ready with batons. Opposite them was a beat-up Santana, beside which a young man in a floral shirt was gesturing wildly. "Why can that car go in but not mine?"

Laughter rippled through the onlookers. Evelyn walked straight over. "I’m Evelyn Roland. Are you here to pick me up?"

The man stiffened, his slicked-back hair seeming to wilt in shock. He scrambled to adjust his appearance—this girl was nothing like he’d imagined.

With striking features, porcelain skin, and an innate regal air even in casual wear, she exuded icy allure. Yet her peach-blossom eyes held a mesmerizing blend of coolness and charm.

This was the delinquent girl from the files?

The private investigator must’ve been blind!

Dominic Laurent hastily straightened his collar, grinning ear to ear. "Hello! I’m your second brother’s best friend. Came specially to fetch you today."

Evelyn shoved her suitcase into his hands. "Thanks."

Dominic blinked, then eagerly yanked open the passenger door—only to pull it clean off its hinges.

The crowd erupted in laughter.

Without batting an eye, Evelyn got in, took the door, and slammed it back into place with sheer force.

Dominic’s jaw dropped.

Superhuman strength?!

He hurriedly stuffed the luggage into the trunk, climbing into the driver’s seat with an apologetic look. "Sorry, this car was fifth-hand when I got it..."

"It’s fine." Evelyn calmly buckled the patched-up seatbelt.

Dominic marveled inwardly. Gorgeous, easygoing, and not a gold-digger—he’d take a dozen sisters like this.

After five failed attempts to start the car, sweat beaded on his forehead. Those bastards—he’d asked for a junker, not scrap metal!

"Let me." Evelyn deftly pulled out a few wires and had the engine roaring in seconds.

"This car needs serious repairs. If you’re not selling it, I can fix it as payment for the ride." She dusted off her hands, buckled up, and closed her eyes to rest.

The effort of prolonging the old man’s life with acupuncture, followed by three days of vigil, had left her utterly drained.

Dominic excitedly whipped out his phone and typed furiously. Alex! Lend me your sister for a couple days! She’s amazing!

At Blenheim Palace in the capital...

Alexander Roland shot up from the sofa, his phone creaking in his grip. "Mom, Dad, I’m going to get my sister."

He bolted out the door. A silver Pagani screeched out of the driveway.

He never should’ve listened to Dominic’s stupid idea! If Evelyn thought the Rolands didn’t want her, his parents would skin him alive.
###Chapter 4

The rattling engine of the old Santana made Evelyn Roland's temples throb.

She massaged her aching forehead and turned to the window.

A road sign pointed unmistakably toward the capital.

"Dominic Laurent." Her voice was ice. "Jiangshui Village is south."

The man behind the wheel stiffened.

"Well..." He forced a laugh. "The Roland family moved to the capital years ago."

Evelyn's eyes narrowed, her knuckles cracking ominously.

"Over a decade ago," Dominic added hastily. "Better opportunities there..."

She scoffed and pulled out her phone to check the route.

The car lurched violently.

Evelyn's knees slammed into the dashboard.

"What was that?"

Dominic already had his seatbelt off, eyes gleaming. "A damsel in distress!"

An Audi sat half-ditched in a roadside gully.

A pale woman leaned against the trunk, sweat beading on her forehead.

Evelyn's pupils contracted.

"Get my bag!" she barked.

Before Dominic could react, she was at the woman's side, fingers on her wrist.

"Three months pregnant. Threatened miscarriage."

The woman's legs buckled. "Save my baby..."

"Lie down."

Evelyn unfurled her needle case. Silver flashed above the woman's abdomen.

Ten minutes later, the pallor faded.

"Call me next time." Evelyn scribbled a number. "I charge for this."

Sirens wailed in the distance.

Dominic sidled up. "I didn't know you could—"

A roar of engines cut him off.

A silver Pagani blocked their path.

The door swung open. A man's voice was dangerously calm. "Where are you taking my sister?"

When their eyes met, Evelyn's heart skipped.

"I'm your second brother," he said.

——

In a hospital room, Olivia Valdemar traced the edges of the note.

Her phone rang.

"Sis! Are you okay?"

"Thanks to a young miracle worker," she said softly. "You must meet her when you return."

###Chapter 5

Half an hour later, Evelyn stood before the grand gates of Blenheim Palace, taking in the imposing security and meticulously landscaped gardens. She silently thanked Dominic Laurent for crafting the perfect "impoverished" backstory for the Roland family.

If the Lowells discovered the truth, escaping their grasp wouldn't be so effortless.

Whether those fabricated documents were intentionally leaked by the Rolands as a diversion, she couldn't be bothered to investigate.

Fewer complications were always preferable.

Alexander studied her calm expression and finally exhaled in relief. He quickly grabbed her duffel bag. "Mom and Dad are waiting in the main hall. I—"

Before he could finish, two figures hurried toward them.

Edward Roland looked dignified in his tailored gray suit, exuding quiet authority. Beside him, Sophia Roland radiated timeless elegance, her well-maintained beauty accentuated by understated grace.

Their eyes locked onto Evelyn, instantly glistening with unshed tears.

Sophia pulled her daughter into a crushing embrace, dampening Evelyn's shoulder with her tears. "My Evelyn... I've finally found you..."

Evelyn stiffened.

No one had ever held her like this. Instinct screamed to push away, but the tremors wracking her mother's frame gave her pause.

Her raised hand hesitated before settling awkwardly on Sophia's back, patting once.

"I'm fine," she said flatly.

Sophia only wept harder. Edward steadied his wife, voice thick. "She just got home. Don't overwhelm her."

"Right, of course." Sophia hastily wiped her cheeks, then slid a luminous jade bracelet from her wrist onto Evelyn's. "This belongs to the lady of the house. It's yours now."

From the shadows, Isabella Langley dug her nails into her palms.

That bracelet—coveted for years—handed to this stray without a second thought!

Evelyn caught the venomous glare instantly, her eyes flashing icy for a heartbeat.

"This is Isabella, your sister," Sophia said, linking their hands. "You must look out for each other."

Isabella's eyes reddened on cue. "It's okay if Evelyn doesn't want to call me sister... I'm not really family anyway..."

Here we go.

Evelyn smirked inwardly.

"Don't flatter yourself," she said coolly.

The dining table groaned under lavish dishes. Sophia fluttered around, heaping Evelyn's plate.

Seizing the moment, Isabella piped up, "Evelyn, the university's adult education program is accepting applications if you want to continue your studies—" She gasped theatrically. "Not that your education is lacking!"

Silence fell.

Sophia frowned, but Evelyn set down her fork first.

"Pass."

"Sweetheart, I know you've suffered." Sophia squeezed her hand. "There's no rush. Let your father and brothers take care of you."

Edward opened his mouth, only to shut it under his wife's glare.

Under the table, he nudged his son.

Alexander discreetly shifted his foot—no way was he crossing Mom today.
###Chapter 6

All eyes were fixed on Evelyn Roland.

Isabella Langley clenched her silver chopsticks until her knuckles turned white. Blood ties meant nothing. They were just a genetic combination of Edward and Sophia Roland.

She was the jewel the Roland family had meticulously polished for twenty years.

Dinner had just ended when the butler rushed into the dining room, flustered.

"Young Master Alexander, there's someone outside claiming to be a business partner from your design company—"

Before he could finish, a whirlwind of a figure barged in.

The woman carried a stack of documents, her brow furrowed with urgency.

"My apologies for interrupting."

"I need to speak with Mr. Alexander immediately."

Evelyn glanced up, studying the tall middle-aged woman. Something about her seemed familiar.

Alexander's expression darkened. "Ms. Macmillan, what is the meaning of this?"

As CEO of KL Design Group, he'd been dealing with headaches from Penelope Macmillan of Vanity Jewelry. She'd developed a batch of premium sapphires but rejected every design KL presented.

"The summer sales season is approaching," Penelope said, her voice tense. "If we don't finalize these designs soon, it'll be too late."

"KL took this project. You need to see it through!"

Penelope?

Evelyn's lashes fluttered slightly.

So it was her.

Years ago, when Penelope's business failed and she contemplated ending her life, Evelyn had casually sent her a design sketch, suggesting she pivot to gemstone sourcing.

Now she helmed Vanity Jewelry.

The city truly was a small world.

"Business matters belong at the office," Alexander said coldly.

"I couldn't find you there!" Penelope stamped her foot in frustration. "When will the designs be finalized?"

She'd rejected every top designer at KL. No one could decipher what she wanted.

Alexander was ready to terminate the contract.

"Brother." Isabella's sweet, confident voice cut through the tension. "I studied jewelry design in London. Let me try."

She was a top graduate from London Design Institute, with dual degrees to boot.

After a hesitant pause, Penelope nodded.

"No need to wait. I can sketch it now."

Isabella motioned for the butler to bring paper and pen. Her hand flew across the page, completing the design swiftly.

Penelope examined the drawing. While not breathtaking, it had more life than the previous attempts.

"We'll go with this," she decided.

Edward beamed. "Isabella, you've saved the day."

"I should've had you design it from the start," Alexander said with a relieved laugh.

"We're family, after all." Isabella emphasized the word "family," her gaze flicking pointedly toward Evelyn.

"Would you like to try, Evelyn? Perhaps Ms. Macmillan will prefer your work."

The air turned glacial.

Evelyn lifted her eyes slowly, her gaze sharp as a blade.

Isabella's back prickled with cold sweat, but she held her ground.

Sophia frowned. "Isabella, don't be ridiculous."

Everyone knew Evelyn hadn't even finished college. Asking her to design jewelry was pure mockery.

"Mother, I heard Evelyn worked with jewelry at the Lowells..." Isabella's eyes glistened with unshed tears.

She'd done her research. Evelyn had been nothing more than a janitor at the Lowells.

A country bumpkin with a high school diploma, daring to compete with her?

"If Ms. Macmillan is satisfied, let's leave it at that," Edward said diplomatically.

But Evelyn rose and walked to the desk.

Trying to put her in her place on her first day home?

She rarely bothered with such games, but she wasn't a pushover either.

"Evelyn..." Alexander started, worried she'd humiliate herself.

Isabella smirked, anticipating the spectacle.

Evelyn picked up the pen, glanced at the sapphire photos, and let her wrist move effortlessly.

In under ten minutes, the design was complete.

Isabella scoffed. Anyone could doodle. Talent was what mattered.

Penelope approached, prepared to offer polite praise.

Then she saw the sketch.

Her entire body stiffened as if struck by lightning. Her hands trembled uncontrollably.
###Chapter 7

"This..."

Penelope Macmillan's hands trembled.

The design sketch slipped from her fingers, fluttering lightly to the floor.

The crowd quickly gathered around.

On the paper was a minimalist sapphire necklace design, its intricate hollowed-out craftsmanship perfectly accentuating the gemstone's natural brilliance.

Even Evelyn Roland, who knew nothing about jewelry, could see this design far surpassed Isabella Langley's work.

Isabella pushed to the front, her pupils contracting sharply.

How was this possible?

She stared at the sketch, her nails digging deep into her palms.

"My little sister draws so well," she forced a sweet, syrupy smile. "But... doesn't this look familiar?"

Her pointed gaze landed on Evelyn. "Plagiarism is an unforgivable sin in our industry."

The air turned icy.

"Impossible!"

Penelope suddenly shouted, her voice shaking with emotion.

She picked up the sketch with trembling hands, pointing at the small "C" mark in the bottom corner.

"This is..."

Her head snapped up, eyes red-rimmed.

With a thud, the formidable jewelry tycoon dropped to her knees before Evelyn.

"My savior! I've finally found you!"

Gasps filled the room.

Evelyn cursed inwardly.

Her habitual signature had given her away.

"Blossoming Prosperity..." Penelope choked out the cringe-worthy online alias.

Evelyn's eye twitched.

A username she'd casually chosen in middle school now sounded unbearably embarrassing.

"Get up," she muttered through gritted teeth.

But Penelope remained kneeling, tearfully recounting how a single design sketch had saved her career years ago.

"So..." Alexander Roland stared at his sister in shock. "You designed the Heart of Ruiya?"

Penelope nodded fervently.

Isabella stood in the corner, her nails nearly drawing blood.

Why?

After twenty years of meticulous effort, how could this bastard child outshine her?

"Did you study design?" Alexander asked.

Evelyn shook her head.

Study? Her five consecutive global design championship titles spoke for themselves.

Alexander's eyes lit up. "Join KL Design Group!"

Evelyn almost refused—until she imagined enduring Isabella's fake smiles every day.

"Fine."

Penelope looked ready to faint with joy, suddenly twenty years younger.

Sophia Roland warned her eldest son: "Take good care of your sister, or I'll dismantle your company!"

Alexander nodded rapidly.

Evelyn lowered her gaze.

This feeling of being protected... it was unfamiliar.

Sophia led her to a standalone two-story villa.

"Do you like it? We can redecorate tomorrow if not."

"It's perfect," Evelyn said softly.

That word—"Mom"—stuck in her throat, unspoken.

Isabella lurked in the shadows, venom swirling in her eyes.

This house she'd begged for had been waiting for its true owner all along.

"Come find me if you get scared, little sister," she cooed.

Sophia beamed, clasping their hands. "You two must get along."

"Goodnight." Evelyn shut the door directly in their faces.

Outside, Isabella sniffled. "Mother, does Evelyn hate me?"

"She just needs time to adjust," Sophia reassured.

Isabella clenched her fists.

Would Sebastian Valdemar's engagement be stolen from her too?

The shower stopped running.

Evelyn towel-dried her hair, noticing 200+ missed calls from Dylan Orlando on her private phone.

"What?" she answered.

"You actually went back to that backwater town?" Dylan screeched. "You make millions per commission! Why would—"

"My father is Edward Roland."

Dead silence.

"Ed... Edward Roland?!" Dylan's voice skyrocketed. "THE Edward Roland?!"
###Chapter 8

Evelyn Roland responded with a lazy "Mm-hmm," and Dylan Orlando on the other end of the line immediately exploded.

"Boss! You're actually the Roland family's heiress?!" Dylan's voice was so shrill it nearly pierced her eardrums. "This is like winning the genetic lottery!"

"Does this mean I get to be the rich sidekick now?" He chuckled shamelessly.

"Get to the point." Evelyn yawned, her tone icy.

To her, the Roland family's wealth meant nothing. She'd always been independent, never relying on anyone.

Besides, the thought of their tangled web of relatives was enough to give her a headache.

"Wait, don't hang up!" Dylan rushed to say. "CH Design Holdings' project in P Country is wrapping up. They're asking when to transfer operations back home."

Evelyn's gaze sharpened.

Over the years, she'd discreetly built numerous overseas ventures to avoid suspicion. Now, it was time to start reeling them in.

"CH isn't established enough domestically. We can't transfer directly." She paused briefly. "Stop taking new orders for now. We'll discuss details tomorrow."

"Got it!" Dylan agreed readily. "I'll pick you up at the Roland estate."

The next morning, Evelyn had barely stepped out of her room when Sophia Roland approached her.

"Did you sleep well, sweetheart?" she asked eagerly. "I made breakfast for you. Would you like something Western or—"

"No need." Evelyn declined flatly. "I have plans with a friend."

Sophia stood holding the homemade meal, watching her daughter walk away, her eyes dimming with disappointment.

From the second-floor landing, Isabella Langley observed the entire scene.

How long had it been since her mother cooked for her?

That ungrateful bitch. But fine—the sooner Sophia realized how unworthy Evelyn was, the better.

When she saw Evelyn get into an unfamiliar Maybach, Isabella's eyes flashed with malice.

Where would a girl from the Lowell family get such wealthy friends? Something was definitely fishy.

Dylan had chosen the newly opened Le Bar du Ritz for their meeting. Even in the morning, the bar was already bustling, the lights dim and hazy.

"Why here?" Evelyn frowned.

"Supporting a friend's new business," Dylan said with an appeasing smile. "Besides, places like this are ironically the safest."

Evelyn couldn't be bothered to argue and followed him to a booth.

Dressed simply in a white button-down and jeans, her bare face stood out starkly against the bar's neon glow.

Within ten minutes, multiple men had approached her, only to be met with glacial rejections.

"This is what you call 'quiet'?" She shot Dylan a sidelong glare.

Just as he opened his mouth to explain, another unwelcome guest appeared.

"Fancy seeing you here, beautiful." Dominic Laurent stubbed out his cigarette, eyes lighting up with delight.

After driving her back to the Roland estate, he hadn't been able to forget this intriguing girl.

Evelyn lifted her gaze, expression indifferent. "Do I know you?"

"Playing dumb?" Dominic grinned. "I'm the one who personally escorted you home."

"Oh." Her voice was frosty. "The guy with the fifth-hand Santana?"

Dominic's face flushed crimson. His friends behind him burst into laughter.

"Since when does Young Master Laurent drive such a wreck?"
"Fifth-hand? Hahaha, more like battle-scarred!"

Dylan was about to suggest moving to a private room when Dominic plopped down beside them.

"Little sister, places like this are full of creeps." He shot Dylan a meaningful look. "You should be careful."

Dylan's temper flared. "Who the hell do you think you are? Back off from Evelyn!"

"I'm a friend of her brother!" Dominic's face darkened. "You're the one bringing a girl here—what are your intentions?"

"My relationship with Evelyn is none of your—"

Dylan nearly blurted out "boss" before Evelyn yanked his arm.

The two men squared off, each grabbing one of Evelyn's arms in a tug-of-war.

"Come with me!" Dominic demanded.
"She came with me!" Dylan refused to back down.

Evelyn winced at the painful pulling. Just as she was about to snap, a mocking laugh cut through the noise.

She turned and locked eyes with a pair of amused ones.

The cripple from the Maybach?
###Chapter 9

Sebastian Valdemar leaned against the second-floor railing, gazing down at Evelyn Roland in the booth below.

His slender fingers idly swirled the glass in his hand, a flicker of mockery in his eyes.

Evelyn suddenly looked up, as if sensing his stare.

Their eyes locked across the space.

As he turned to leave, she distinctly heard a derisive scoff.

"Hmph."

Evelyn averted her gaze, focusing on the two persistent heirs vying for her attention.

"Beautiful, care for a drink?"

"Back off. I asked first."

The men bickered like rutting peacocks, faces flushed with competition.

A wave of boredom washed over her.

With a twist of her wrist, she effortlessly broke free from their grasp.

"Get lost."

Dylan Orlando immediately took three steps back.

He knew his boss's temper all too well.

Dominic Laurent, however, refused to give up. He reached for her shoulder.

Evelyn drove her elbow into his stomach with surgical precision.

"Gah—"

Dominic doubled over, sweat beading on his forehead.

The woman hit like a truck.

Irritated, Evelyn left the booth and headed for the secluded lounge area.

In the shadows, Isabella Langley clenched her phone.

"Slut. Can't resist flirting, can you?"

She dialed a number, her lips curling into a venomous smile.

Meanwhile, Sebastian was ushered into the VIP section by his friend Zachary Merouin.

"Rare to see you here. What brings you?"

Zachary slid a freshly mixed drink toward him.

Sebastian's eyes unconsciously scanned the room.

"Keep this place clean."

"Excuse me?" Zachary looked baffled.

"No illegal activities." Sebastian's voice was ice. "Especially trafficking."

Zachary nearly leapt from his seat. "Sebastian! Who do you take me for?"

"Then control your patrons."

The memory of those cool, composed eyes unsettled him.

He'd misjudged her.

That woman wasn't some doctor. She was just a...

"Something's off." Zachary narrowed his eyes. "Since when do you care about this?"

Sebastian ignored him, downing his drink in one go.

Soon, a group of women approached.

He rejected each with a frosty glare.

Not far away, Evelyn scoffed.

Playing the prude.

As she turned to leave, she caught the bartender slipping something into Sebastian's glass.

The lighting was dim, but she saw it clearly.

"Serves you right."

She headed for the restroom.

The moment she pushed the door open, a strange sweetness filled the air.

"Damn it!"

She held her breath, but not before inhaling traces of the drug.

Her limbs grew heavy. Heat pooled low in her abdomen.

Aphrodisiac.

Three hulking men blocked the exit.

"Hey pretty, don't rush off."

The leader licked his lips as he advanced.

Fighting the haze, Evelyn pulled a silver hairpin from her updo.

"Who hired you?"

Their hesitation gave her an opening.

She struck with lethal precision.

Silver flashed. One man collapsed, clutching his throat.

"Try me."

The remaining two faltered under her murderous aura.

Evelyn bolted past them into the hall.

The drug's effects intensified. She needed refuge fast.

The upstairs VIP area was her only option.

Stumbling, she shoved through a door and locked it behind her.

Footsteps pounded outside.

"Where'd she go?"

Back against the door, Evelyn slid to the floor.

Sweat dampened her forehead.

She bit her tongue hard, using the pain to stay conscious—

Only to freeze at the icy voice behind her.

"Who gave you permission to enter?"
###Chapter 10

The presidential suite was pitch black, with only slivers of moonlight slipping through the curtains.

The faint scent of sandalwood lingered in the air.

Evelyn Roland curled up beside the sofa, her cheeks burning, her breathing ragged. She fought desperately against the drug coursing through her veins, but it was a losing battle. If this continued, it might damage her meridians.

A sudden pounding erupted at the door, accompanied by crude shouts.

Soon, the security guards' angry voices cut through the noise.

"Get the hell out! You dare cause trouble on Mr. Merouin's turf?"

"My buddy's resting in there. You got a death wish?"

The booming voice belonged to Zachary Merouin, the bar owner.

Evelyn remembered Dylan Orlando mentioning him.

She fumbled for her phone to call for help, only to realize it was gone.

"Damn it."

The drug's effects intensified, scorching her rationality like wildfire.

Staggering, she headed for the bathroom, hoping cold water would ease the symptoms.

Outside the bar, three thugs were thrown out by security.

"Fuck! The prey got away," the leader spat.

In the shadows, Isabella Langley's face darkened with fury.

"Useless! You can't even handle a drugged woman?"

The thugs kept their heads down, not daring to speak.

Isabella suppressed her rage and pulled out a wad of cash.

"Take the money. But remember—"

Her eyes turned icy. "If a single word leaks out..."

"Don't worry!" The thugs hurriedly assured her. "We know how to keep our mouths shut!"

"Wait," one thug suddenly recalled. "There was a man in that room too. Probably..."

Isabella's eyes lit up. "Really?"

"Swear to God! Mr. Merouin said it himself."

A cold smirk curled her lips as she dialed a tabloid reporter's number.

Inside the suite.

Evelyn stumbled into the bathroom, her foot slipping.

Her hand instinctively grabbed something—

Warm, firm muscle met her touch.

"Who's there?"

A deep, restrained voice laced with anger.

That voice... the disabled man?

Evelyn realized he was drugged too.

Sebastian Valdemar shoved her away. "Get out!"

The drug's effects grew unbearable.

Evelyn bit her lip—she was doomed either way. Might as well...

She lunged at him.

Cold water cascaded over their feverish bodies.

From the bathroom to the bedroom, the moonlight bore witness to their madness.

At dawn, Evelyn woke first.

Her body ached as if run over by a truck.

Beside her, the man still slept, his striking profile softened by the morning light.

Footsteps and the sound of camera adjustments echoed outside the door.

"Heh..."

Evelyn smirked, dressing swiftly.

Before leaving, she left a note and a few coins on the bedside table.

"Worthless service. This is all you get."

She climbed out the window and shimmied down the drainpipe.

Three floors were nothing to her.

Let that bastard face the media alone!

The door burst open.

Camera flashes flooded the room.

In the café across the street, Isabella clenched her fists in excitement.

"They're coming out!"

But when the figure in the doorway became clear, the reporters froze—

It was a man!

Sebastian's icy gaze swept over them, his eyes glinting dangerously.

"Three seconds. Disappear."

The hallway fell deathly silent.
###Chapter 11

The gray-furred mouse darted onto Qian Xiaoyu's head in a flash, baring its sharp teeth with a shrill squeak. Its tail stood straight up, ready to attack.

"Get down!"

Every hair on Qian Xiaoyu's body stood on end. She had always been terrified of small, furry creatures—especially mice and snakes.

The little mouse flicked its tail dismissively and leaped back onto the well's edge. Drinking sweet well water was far more appealing than dealing with this coward.

Qian Xiaoyu froze.

Had she just understood the mouse's squeaks?

The high-pitched chittering had translated clearly in her mind: Stupid human! This great rat has no time for you!

This was more shocking than time travel or pocket dimensions.

She cautiously approached the well. The mouse was drinking, its round belly rising and falling with each breath.

"Hey, little one," she called softly.

The gray mouse pricked up its ears and glared at her. "What? Want a fight?"

Qian Xiaoyu burst out laughing. This wasn't a hallucination—she could truly understand animals!

Fear melted into fascination. She poked the mouse's plump belly, earning an indignant glare.

"Don't touch this great rat's stomach!"

After confirming her ability, she turned her attention to the pocket dimension. With a thought, well water surged into a perfect column, and wild vegetables arranged themselves neatly along the field's edge. Only the distant fog-covered areas remained inaccessible.

"This is enough," she murmured. The fertile land and magical spring would secure her survival in this ancient world.

The mouse sprawled on the well's edge, belly full, hiccuping contentedly. Qian Xiaoyu scooped a handful of water. It tasted crisp and sweet, but held no obvious special properties.

"Time to go back." She glanced at the sky. The kids would worry if she stayed out too long.

With a thought, she and the mouse reappeared in the forest. The vegetable basket and chipped kitchen knife lay untouched where she'd left them.

"Squeak! Take me back!" The mouse frantically hopped in place.

Qian Xiaoyu grinned and lifted it by the scruff. "Come home with me, Graybie."

"Let go! Wild cats will eat this great rat!"

"Relax, I'll protect you." She winked, then paused. A serious problem occurred to her—how could she eat meat now? If she heard animals begging for mercy, how could she stomach it?

Strangely, the village chickens and dogs still sounded like ordinary animals to her. Apparently, only certain creatures could communicate.

After gathering vegetables, she carefully uprooted a few plants for her experimental garden.

On the way down the mountain, the mouse stubbornly refused to leave the basket. Qian Xiaoyu sighed. "Fine, but behave."

Two small figures came into view at the mountain's base. Warmth bloomed in her chest. In this unfamiliar world, she was no longer alone.

"Sis!"
"Jiejie!"

The children sprinted toward her. Little Hua threw herself into Qian Xiaoyu's arms while Xiao Jiang dutifully took the basket.

"Let's go home."

The setting sun stretched their three shadows long across the ground. Outside their shabby cottage, the newly built fence gleamed golden in the fading light.

"Uncle Cao and the others helped fix the walls," Xiao Jiang reported solemnly. "You said we must remember kindness."

Qian Xiaoyu ruffled his hair, proud. But her stomach growled loudly, reminding her of their empty pantry. She hurried toward the kitchen.

The thin porridge only sharpened her hunger. Her stomach protested the lack of proper nourishment.

"We need to earn money," she muttered. Without farmland, how could they survive on wild greens alone?

A sudden shriek interrupted her thoughts.

"Mouse! There's a mouse in the basket!" Little Hua jumped up and down in panic.

Xiao Jiang grabbed a broom. "I'll get it!"

The gray rodent scampered up the wall, sticking out its tongue. "Catch me if you can, brat!"

Dust flew as boy and mouse chased each other around the yard. Qian Xiaoyu massaged her temples—peace and quiet seemed impossible now.

###Chapter 12 

The elevator doors slid open soundlessly. Benjamin stepped aside to make way.

"Miss Roland, after you."

Evelyn's gaze lingered on his face for half a second before she stepped in.

As the doors closed, Benjamin loosened his tie. The boss had said she was just a greenhorn, so why did she carry herself like seasoned royalty?

He rubbed his temples. Too much overtime lately—must be seeing things.

"You should've called ahead," Alexander said, setting down his fountain pen to pour her a glass of water.

Evelyn accepted it. "Didn't have your number."

Alexander froze, then hastily pulled out his phone to exchange contacts.

"My oversight."

"No need to apologize." She took a sip. "Just stating facts."

Alexander was speechless. This sister was nothing like the spoiled Isabella.

Remembering his mother's instructions, he straightened. "You'll be in Design Team Three. Any issues, come to me or Benjamin."

"Unnecessary." She set down the glass. "I prefer to remain an ordinary employee."

"But—"

"Don't worry. I won't tattle to the family."

Alexander choked back a laugh. This girl was something else.

Noting the awkward silence, Evelyn added, "If real trouble arises, I'll find you."

"Deal." Amused, he pressed the intercom. "Benjamin, escort her to Design."

Watching her slender figure leave, admiration flickered in his eyes. Though her credentials were modest, her poise was extraordinary.

In the design department hallway, Benjamin murmured, "You'll handle Vanity Jewelry's sapphire collection."

"Adrienne, your new recruit," he called toward the workstations.

A woman buried in sketches didn't look up. "Far corner desk."

It was a clutter-filled dead zone.

Benjamin frowned. "But she's assigned to Vanity—"

"And?" Adrienne smirked.

"Here's fine." Evelyn strode to the corner.

As she set down her bag, colleagues suddenly swarmed her.

"Miss Roland, take my seat!"

"Try my homemade cookies!"

"How are you related to Mr. Roland?"

Evelyn's eyes glinted. So the lobby incident had spread.

"Coincidental surname." Her tone was even. "The Vanity drafts were from my part-time work for the Rolands. Mr. Roland appreciated them."

The cookies vanished instantly.

"Ugh, just a fluke."

"Wasted effort."

The crowd dispersed, someone deliberately piling files on her desk.

"Borrowing space~"

Evelyn eyed their empty workstation, lips quirking.

"Must all be trash then."

Crash—

She dumped everything neatly into the bin.

"My sketches!"

"Are you insane?"

Amid shrieks, the girl opposite stifled giggles.

Adrienne's office door slammed open:

"Keep it down!"
###Chapter 13

Adrienne Klein strode into the design department in her high heels, immediately surrounded by three senior employees.

"Manager, the new girl threw away all our things!"

"She tore up my design sketches!"

"And my favorite mug..."

They clamored with accusations, one even squeezing out a few tears.

Adrienne frowned, scanning the room before her gaze landed on Evelyn Roland in the corner.

"A newcomer bullying veterans?" She smirked coldly. "I, Adrienne Klein, despise such power-tripping behavior."

Evelyn opened her mouth to explain, but Hannah Clementson from the opposite workstation interrupted timidly.

"N-no, that's not what happened..." Hannah stood up hesitantly. "They took Evelyn's seat first..."

Three pairs of venomous eyes immediately shot toward Hannah, making her nearly collapse back into her chair.

Adrienne narrowed her eyes. "Hannah, explain clearly."

Under the manager's piercing stare, the three seniors stammered incoherently.

"Consider your bonuses docked this month!" Adrienne snapped. "Next time, you're fired!"

They slunk back to their seats, shooting Hannah a murderous glare on the way.

"Evelyn Roland." Adrienne turned to the newcomer. "You're staying late tonight to clean the office."

She intended to put this privileged girl in her place.

To Adrienne's surprise, Evelyn simply nodded in calm acceptance.

Once the manager left, Jessica Rubinstein stormed over to Hannah.

"Traitor!" She raised her hand to strike.

A colleague quickly pulled her back. "Don't be rash. We'll deal with her later."

Hannah shrank into herself like a frightened rabbit.

"They..." she whispered to Evelyn. "Jessica has connections..."

Evelyn studied the kind-hearted girl and gave a slight nod. "Thank you."

After hours, Evelyn cleaned the office alone.

Adrienne, passing by, paused at the sight, a flicker of surprise crossing her face.

This socialite was actually doing the work properly?

Meanwhile, in the Valdemar Group CEO's office...

Sebastian Valdemar replayed the surveillance footage with a dark expression.

"Still no leads?" Zachary Merouin lounged on the sofa. "Maybe she's hideous?"

"Shut up," Sebastian said coldly.

His assistant Theodore Ashcroft entered. "We found the culprit. It was Isabella Langley, the Roland family's adopted daughter."

Zachary nearly fell off the couch. "Your fiancée tried to kill you?"

A dangerous glint flashed in Sebastian's eyes.

An engagement? He'd never cared about it.

But that mysterious woman... he couldn't seem to forget her.

"Prepare the car," he stood. "We're going to the Rolands'."
###Chapter 14

Qi Ruhai remained silent for a long while, the creases between his brows deepening.

"If I refuse to cooperate, does the Commander intend to render me completely powerless?" His voice was low when he finally spoke.

Ye Wudao's lips curved slightly. "General Qi's presence in the rear guard has indeed been... inconvenient. Why not attempt a collaboration first?"

"Collaboration?" Qi Ruhai narrowed his eyes.

"The encirclement operation." Ye Wudao pointed to the sand table. "The left flank remains the primary battlefield."

His finger traced the mountain range on the sand table. "General Qi will feign a falling-out with me. Take your most trusted men and flank from the right, circling through the Kingdom of Xihuang to strike the demonic cultivators from behind."

"What about the right flank's defenses during the two-day march?" Qi Ruhai frowned.

"The central army will assume control." Ye Wudao's tone left no room for doubt. "Focus solely on the pincer maneuver."

After a moment of contemplation, Qi Ruhai said, "I require written orders from the Commander."

Ye Wudao nodded. "Naturally."

His gaze sharpened abruptly. "This time, the elite forces of both the vanguard and central army will be deployed. We will annihilate every last demonic cultivator on the left flank—even if it means crossing into Xihuang territory!"

Ye Wudao knew all too well that the imperial court cared little for a minor kingdom like Xihuang. The hesitation to pursue beyond borders stemmed solely from the two princesses obstructing each other.

"I'll arrange for two severely injured Demon Kings to fall into your hands," Ye Wudao lowered his voice. "The rest of the merits... will depend on General Qi's own efforts."

A flicker of doubt crossed Qi Ruhai's eyes before he finally nodded. "Agreed."

"One more thing." Ye Wudao leaned in suddenly. "Spread word that our forces will launch a full-scale assault on the right flank."

Qi Ruhai's heart clenched. He understood—Ye Wudao had long been aware of his ties to the demonic cultivators. With a bitter smile, he said, "I truly have no knowledge of their defensive arrangements. Before the left flank engages, the Commander must specify the ambush locations."

"Your cooperation is appreciated." Ye Wudao clasped his fists solemnly.

Qi Ruhai studied him intently. "If the Commander keeps his word, this general is willing to serve the Sixth Princess."

Once Qi Ruhai departed, Ye Wudao immediately issued orders to the vanguard and central army. This time, he sought not minor skirmishes, but the complete eradication of the demonic cultivators on the left flank.

Outside the tent, dusk deepened. Ye Wudao gazed at the distant mountain silhouettes, his eyes glinting with cold light.
###Chapter 15

"I was wrong, Sebastian..."

Isabella Langley's eyes were red-rimmed, her voice trembling as her delicate fingers clutched at Sebastian Valdemar's sleeve.

Sebastian's sharp brows furrowed slightly before he coldly shook off her hand.

"Filthy."

He pulled out a handkerchief and meticulously wiped the spot she had touched.

Edward Roland's face darkened with suppressed fury. After all, it was his daughter who had committed those disgraceful acts first.

"Isabella!" Sophia Roland yanked her daughter back, hissing under her breath, "Haven't you humiliated us enough?"

Alexander Roland stepped forward, his voice low. "Since Mr. Valdemar insists on canceling the engagement, the Roland family has no objections."

Sebastian's long fingers tapped lightly against the armrest of the sofa, a dark glint flashing in his eyes.

"You misunderstand, Mr. Roland."

He lifted his gaze, sharp as a blade.

"I'm calling off the engagement with Isabella Langley."

The room fell so silent you could hear a pin drop.

"I heard the Roland family has found their biological daughter?" Sebastian's lips curved slightly. "According to the agreement between our families, she is my fiancée."

Sophia's face twisted. "Absolutely not! That girl grew up in the countryside—she's unworthy of the Valdemar family!"

Her voice cracked with desperation.

From the shadows of the staircase, Evelyn Roland held her breath, her nails digging into her palms.

This lunatic!

She had no intention of marrying a dying man and becoming a widow.

"Where is she?" Sebastian scanned the room, his gaze lingering on the stairwell.

"She's not home!" Sophia blurted.

Sebastian studied her for a moment before standing and straightening his suit.

"I expect to see her in three days."

With that, he strode out, his posture as unyielding as a pine tree.

Isabella collapsed to the floor, tears blurring her vision.

She couldn't accept this!

She had been so close to becoming Mrs. Valdemar—only for that country bumpkin to steal everything from her!

"Isabella, don't cry." Edward helped his daughter up, his voice tender. "He's not worth it."

Isabella bit her lip and nodded, but resentment churned in her eyes.

She would never let that bitch get her way.

Upstairs, Evelyn silently retreated to her room.

She studied her reflection in the mirror, a cold smirk playing on her lips.

He wanted to marry her?

Fine. Let's see who outplays whom.
###Chapter 16

Evelyn Roland stood at the corner of the staircase, her nails digging deep into her palms.

Sebastian Valdemar's icy gaze swept across the room, never once lingering on her. It seemed he truly didn't recognize her as the woman from last night.

"Mom, do we really have to marry Evelyn off to that devil?" Sophia Roland's voice trembled with tears.

Edward Roland rubbed his temples. "We're in the wrong here. The Valdemars aren't to be trifled with."

"Isabella, remember this lesson." Edward turned to his younger daughter, his tone stern. "Sebastian Valdemar is not someone you provoke."

Isabella Langley bit her lip and nodded, tears welling in her eyes.

Back in her room, Evelyn collapsed onto the bed. Sebastian's frosty expression flashed repeatedly in her mind.

Marrying a man like that would be pure torture.

Inside the black Maybach, Sebastian immediately noticed his assistant's unease.

"Mr. Valdemar..." The assistant's hands shook on the steering wheel.

"Speak." Sebastian's voice was like ice.

"Miss Olivia was in a car accident! She's at the hospital now!"

The car door slammed shut with such force the entire vehicle shuddered.

"When did this happen?" Sebastian's voice sharpened.

"Half an hour ago! Miss Olivia forbade us from telling you—"

The car shot forward like an arrow. Sebastian's clenched fists bulged with veins.

At fifteen, he'd lost both parents. The shadow of that tragedy still haunted him. Olivia Valdemar was the only warmth left in his world.

In the VIP ward, Olivia sat propped against the headboard, reading a book.

"Sis." Sebastian reached her bedside in three strides.

"Just a minor injury." She smiled faintly. "Though it did scare the baby."

Sebastian's eyes turned glacial. "The driver?"

"Already dealt with." Olivia took his hand. "But we should thank the girl who saved me."

Sebastian frowned. "Who?"

"A young woman trained in traditional medicine. If she hadn't acted quickly, the baby might have..." Olivia's hand drifted protectively over her stomach.

"I'll have her found." Sebastian's voice was steel. "I'll take care of Theodore these days."

At the mention of her eldest son, Olivia's expression dimmed. The boy's autism was her eternal heartache.

"Oh," she suddenly remembered, "I think the girl's surname was Roland..."
###Chapter 17

Olivia's eyes sparkled with anticipation as her fingers unconsciously twisted the hem of her blouse.

Sebastian gave a slight nod, signaling his assistant to pull up the highway surveillance footage immediately.

"That girl was quite beautiful," Olivia mused, narrowing her eyes in recollection. "Around your age, actually. You two would make a striking pair."

A mischievous grin suddenly played on her lips.

"Why not offer yourself as repayment for your sister's debt?"

Sebastian's expression remained impassive, not even a flicker of emotion crossing his features.

"Boring," Olivia huffed, rolling her eyes. "You've been this cold since you were a child."

Her smile faded as she turned serious. "You don't have to cling to that engagement. The Valdemar family is at its peak now—we don't need alliances to secure our position."

Sebastian responded with a noncommittal hum.

His life was already destined to be short. Love was nothing but an unnecessary burden. Maintaining the engagement with the Rolands was merely an extra layer of security for the family.

Olivia studied her brother's stoic profile, a pang of sorrow tightening her chest.

She had defied their family to marry a man with nothing, and now she lived in happiness. How she wished Sebastian could find his own joy.

The next morning, at KL Design Group.

Evelyn had barely stepped into the office when Jessica's shrill voice cut through the air.

"Hannah, is buying coffee beneath you?"

"Don't forget you arrived only days before Evelyn. Serving your seniors is basic courtesy!"

Hannah clutched a stack of files to her chest, flustered. "But the supervisor asked me to sort these drafts first..."

"You were quick enough to defend Evelyn yesterday!" Jessica sneered.

Evelyn's gaze darkened.

What a way to start the day.

Hannah bit her lip, eyes glistening with unshed tears.

"Problem?" Evelyn drawled, her tone deliberately languid. "Think the surveillance cameras missed your little bullying act?"

"Should I post the footage online and let the public judge?"

Jessica's face flushed crimson. "You—!"

A colleague quickly pulled her back, whispering that the supervisor was about to arrive.

"Thank you," Hannah murmured. "You helped me again."

Evelyn, unusually talkative, added, "The more you retreat, the more they'll push."

Hannah nodded firmly.

With Evelyn here, she suddenly found the courage to resist. At worst, she could quit—better than enduring this humiliation.

"Evelyn, the supervisor wants to see you."

Setting down her bag, Evelyn headed toward Adrienne's office.

"You did well with the cleanup last night," Adrienne said without looking up. "There's a new assignment for you today."

###Chapter 18

Sebastian again.

Top floor of Valdemar Group.

Expected.

###Chapter 19

Because your skills are pathetic.

A secret lay hidden there.

###Chapter 20 

The courtroom air turned to ice.

Old Man Ding's words detonated like a bomb, sending shockwaves through the gallery. Prosecutor Fang's face drained of color, his lips trembling soundlessly.

"Order!" Judge Guyuan slammed his gavel, his gaze sharp as a hawk's. "Old Man Ding, are you certain of your testimony?"

"Every word is true!" The old man dropped to his knees, his forehead striking the cold tiles. "Prosecutor Fang paid my family five hundred thousand to frame Commander Han... He threatened to kill us all if we spoke out!"

Gasps erupted from the spectators.

Fang shot to his feet, his chair screeching across the floor. "Lies! This senile fool is delusional!" Veins bulged on his forehead as he turned to the judge. "Your Honor, this is a blatant setup!"

The courtroom doors burst open. A bailiff hurried to Judge Guyuan's side, whispering urgently and handing him a stack of photographs.

The judge's frown deepened as he examined the images. Slowly, he lifted one for all to see—Fang standing atop the Grand Meridian Hotel, dozens of Six of Spades playing cards scattered at his feet.

"Impossible!" Fang staggered back. "These are doctored! I've never been there!"

"Seven journalists have also come forward," Judge Guyuan continued. "Each witnessed you using the Six of Spades' abilities on separate occasions."

The murmurs swelled. Fang clawed at his collar—and a single card fluttered free.

Six of Spades.
