The gavel fell.

"In light of new evidence, court is adjourned for thirty minutes." Judge Guyuan's voice was grave. "Detain Fang Lichang pending trial."

Fang's screams echoed down the hallway until the heavy doors sealed shut behind him.

The defense attorney straightened his papers, a faint smirk playing on his lips. "Your Honor, perhaps we might revisit the matter of Commander Han's bail?"

In the back row, a figure in a baseball cap slipped away unnoticed. Beneath the brim, a smile flickered and vanished.
###Chapter 21

Olivia Valdemar recognized Evelyn Roland at first glance, her voice trembling with excitement. "It's you!"

She grabbed Sebastian Valdemar's arm. "She's the one! If she hadn't intervened that day, the baby might have—"

Olivia rushed forward, clasping Evelyn's hands tightly. "What a coincidence! I'm Olivia Valdemar, this guy's older sister."

Tears of gratitude shimmered in her eyes. "Everything happened so fast that day. I never got the chance to properly thank you."

"Is there anything I can do for you? Just name it."

Evelyn calmly withdrew her hands and took half a step back. "It was nothing, Ms. Valdemar. Please don't dwell on it."

She lifted the file folder in her hand. "I was just delivering documents. Now that my task is done, I should be going."

As she turned, Evelyn exhaled quietly in relief. Thank goodness Olivia had shown up—otherwise, that damned birthmark secret would have been exposed.

The atmosphere in the office grew tense.

Sebastian's icy voice cut through the air. "Stop."

He strode forward, closing the distance between them. "Why are you refusing the examination? Guilty conscience?"

Olivia immediately stepped between them. "What examination? Sebastian, have you lost your mind?"

She shot her brother a reproachful look. "This woman saved my life. Is this how you treat her?"

For a moment, she'd thought her brother had finally come to his senses. But no—still the same cold, unapproachable man.

Olivia sighed inwardly. At this rate, the Valdemar family line might end with him.

"Stay out of this, Olivia." Sebastian's gaze locked onto Evelyn over his sister's shoulder. "I just want an answer."

A flicker of irritation crossed Evelyn's eyes. Why was this man so damn persistent?

Suddenly, her expression shifted. She ducked timidly behind Olivia. "Ms. Valdemar, your brother seems to think I stole something..."

Sebastian stiffened.

Stole something? She had some nerve.

Olivia's temper flared. "Is Valdemar Group's security system just for show? You're accusing a young woman of theft?"

"She stole my—" Sebastian bit back the words.

How could he possibly say, in front of his sister, that this woman had taken his virginity?
###Chapter 22

Evelyn Roland had long seen through his intentions, which was why she dared to put on such a brazen performance.

"Cat got your tongue, Mr. Valdemar? Or are you throwing a tantrum like a three-year-old?"

"A pat-down? What is this, a cop drama?"

Sebastian Valdemar fell silent under Olivia Valdemar's scolding.

Evelyn tugged lightly at Olivia's sleeve, her voice tinged with hurt. "I'm a designer at KL. Mr. Valdemar rejected our department's draft for personal reasons..."

"Don't worry, sweetheart. I'll handle this."

The way Evelyn called her "Olivia" made the older woman's heart swell with affection. She was ready to claim this sweet, clever girl as her little sister on the spot.

"Sebastian, I order you to approve KL's design proposal."

"Sis, I don't make decisions based on emotions. Their work genuinely doesn't meet our standards."

Olivia hesitated. She knew her brother well—he wasn't the type to jeopardize the company over petty grievances.

Evelyn seized the moment. "If Mr. Valdemar truly separates personal feelings from business, then give me a chance to redesign."

A flicker of doubt crossed Sebastian's eyes.

An intern, taking on such an important project?

As if reading his mind, Evelyn smiled calmly. "Just ten minutes. If you're not satisfied, I'll leave immediately."

"Fine."

She strode to his desk, pulled out paper and a pen, and began sketching.

Her pen danced across the page. In under ten minutes, a complete summer jewelry collection materialized.

A pale blue heart-shaped pendant shimmered like a clear spring, while undulating chains evoked the refreshing touch of ocean breezes.

"Exquisite!" Olivia gasped. "Sebastian, we're going with this!"

Sebastian's pulse quickened.

The design perfectly aligned with their unreleased "Breeze" theme.

He checked his watch: eight minutes.

"Satisfied?" Evelyn asked.

"Impressive." He handed her a contract. "Sign here."

As she took the document, a glint of triumph flashed in her eyes.

Not only had she defused the crisis—she'd secured the project.

This round belonged to her.

Olivia eagerly added her on WeChat and requested a custom piece.

Watching Evelyn leave, Olivia sighed. "What a delightful girl."

Sebastian smirked.

Delightful?

More like a cunning little fox.
###Chapter 23

Sebastian Valdemar's mind flashed back to that night at Le Bar du Ritz.

The scene of two spoiled heirs dragging Evelyn Roland between them.

A cold smirk curled his lips. "She plays the innocent well."

Olivia Valdemar rolled her eyes. "Since when did you become so bitter?"

"Don't tell me you've taken an interest in her?"

"Sister, since when did you start playing matchmaker?"

A secret crush?

Sebastian scoffed. In the Valdemar family, he took what he wanted by force.

Olivia gave him a knowing smile. "Stubborn. I've never seen you so fixated on a girl before."

"That's because—" Sebastian abruptly fell silent.

He couldn't very well admit he suspected this woman had slept with him.

"Because what?" Olivia arched a brow. "Never mind. I don't want to hear your excuses. Eat your food."

Sebastian stared blankly at the insulated lunchbox.

He had been paying unusual attention to Evelyn.

KL Design Group, Third Division.

The moment Evelyn stepped into the office, she felt the weight of countless stares.

Jessica Rubinstein sneered, "Look who's back—our little backdoor hire! Ready for Adrienne's storm?"

"Try not to cry, newbie."

Evelyn ignored her and walked straight to her workstation.

Hannah Clementson leaned over worriedly. "Evelyn, should I come with you to see Adrienne?"

"It's fine." Evelyn gave her hand a reassuring squeeze.

Jessica scoffed. "Hannah, such a suck-up. Too bad you picked the wrong horse."

Hannah lowered her head and resumed working without response.

Jessica's face flushed with anger.

Ever since Evelyn arrived, even the meekest girl in the office dared to defy her.

Third Design Division, Supervisor's Office.

Adrienne Klein blinked in surprise when Evelyn entered.

"You—"

She'd been ready to tear into the so-called nepotism hire.

Before she could speak, a document slid across her desk.

The bold letters of KL Design Group's contract with Valdemar Group glared up at her.

"You secured the deal?" Adrienne's voice cracked.

Evelyn nodded calmly.

Adrienne frantically flipped through the pages. Sebastian's signature and the Valdemar corporate seal stared back at her.

She looked up, stunned. "This can't be..."

What shocked her more—the design schematics had been altered.
###Chapter 24

Evelyn Roland's fingers trembled slightly as she handed the design draft to Adrienne Klein.

The blueprint had undergone a complete transformation, bearing no resemblance to the initial version submitted to Mr. Roland. Every detail had been meticulously refined, as if the most brilliant summer sunlight had been crystallized onto paper.

Adrienne studied the design for a long moment.

"Is this your work?" Her fingertip tapped the centerpiece necklace on the drawing.

Evelyn pressed her lips together and nodded.

"Impressive." Adrienne rarely showed approval. "Securing the partnership with Valdemar Group is largely thanks to you."

The office air conditioning hummed loudly, yet a thin layer of sweat formed on Evelyn's back.

She understood the subtext—this unqualified hire with only a vocational degree actually had real talent.

"However—" Adrienne's tone shifted abruptly. "Young people must guard against arrogance. The Third Design Department doesn't tolerate slackers."

She stood and walked to Evelyn's side, giving her shoulder a firm pat. The gesture wasn't harsh, but it made Evelyn's heart tighten.

"I understand." Evelyn met Adrienne's scrutinizing gaze.

She knew Adrienne's prejudice wouldn't vanish overnight. But time would tell.

As she exited the office, dozens of eyes locked onto her.

Hannah Clementson rushed over first. "Did the director give you trouble?"

Her voice was hushed but laced with concern.

Evelyn shook her head. "It's fine."

Her peripheral vision caught the colleague whose design had been replaced, sitting in the corner. She chose silence.

"Who do you think you are?" Jessica Rubinstein's shrill voice cut through the air. "Someone like Sebastian Valdemar—do you really think you can handle him?"

Hannah's face flushed with anger. "Weren't you the one who got kicked out of his office?"

The room fell dead silent.

Jessica's face darkened. "Hannah! Are you looking for death?"

She raised her hand as if to charge forward but was restrained by other colleagues.

Evelyn grasped Hannah's wrist. "Let's go."

Her calm tone only infuriated Jessica further.

"Evelyn Roland! What gives you the right?" Jessica shrieked behind them. "You're just a useless backdoor hire!"

Evelyn walked away without looking back.

In the hallway, Hannah still fumed. "How dare she speak to you like that?"

"It doesn't matter." Evelyn paused. "What matters is we secured Valdemar."

Hannah's eyes widened. "Really?"

Evelyn gave a slight nod.

The sound of shattering glass echoed behind them. Without turning, Evelyn knew Jessica had been eavesdropping.

Now, the real show would begin.
###Chapter 25

Jessica Rubinstein's nails dug deep into her palms as she glared at Evelyn Roland's retreating figure. Beneath that flawless makeup, the corners of her mouth twisted into a grotesque sneer.

"Who does she think she is?" she muttered under her breath.

The glass office door swung open abruptly.

Adrienne Klein strode in on ten-centimeter stilettos, her black blazer radiating authority. The entire design department fell silent.

Jessica's expression froze.

"Third Design Department dinner tonight," Adrienne announced, scanning the room before letting her gaze linger on Evelyn. "To celebrate Evelyn securing the Valdemar Group collaboration."

Hannah Clementson's folder hit the floor with a sharp slap.

"That's impossible!" Jessica blurted out.

Adrienne shot her an icy look. "Do you have a problem with that?"

Jessica's lips trembled, but no words came out.

Applause erupted like a tidal wave. Colleagues clapped while stealing glances at Jessica's ashen face.

Hannah sidled up to Evelyn with saccharine sweetness. "You're amazing, Evelyn~"

"Absolutely!"

"You've made our department proud!"

Amid the fawning chorus, Jessica's nails screeched across her desk. She shoved her chair back with a jarring scrape.

"I'm not feeling well. I'm leaving."

Hannah watched Jessica's retreating figure, her eyes crinkling with glee.

"Serves her right," she whispered.

Adrienne left after finalizing dinner arrangements. Hannah immediately latched onto Evelyn. "You knew this would happen, didn't you? You were waiting to humiliate her!"

Evelyn sorted through design drafts without looking up. "You're imagining things."

"Bullshit!" Hannah gesticulated excitedly. "You should've seen Jessica's face!"

Evening lights illuminated Grand Bliss Hotel as design team members gathered in the lobby.

Evelyn stood by the floor-to-ceiling window, fingertips lightly tapping the glass. Crystal chandelier light fractured across her profile.

"Well, well. If it isn't our 'hero'?"

A shrill female voice cut through the air behind her.
###Chapter 26

"Well, well, if it isn't the Lowell family's precious heiress."

Victoria Lowell's saccharine voice cut through the hushed ambiance of the hotel lobby. Clinging to Nathan Evans' arm, her pink dress swayed with each step, her meticulously styled curls gleaming under the chandeliers.

Nathan's gaze, however, remained fixed on Evelyn Roland. His dark eyes held an unreadable intensity, as if trying to pierce through her very soul.

Evelyn's crimson lips curved slightly, a flicker of mockery flashing in her eyes. She had long cast these two out of her mind, yet fate had a cruel sense of humor, bringing them face-to-face again.

Hannah Clementson immediately sensed the tension and stepped protectively in front of Evelyn. "And you are?"

"We're here for our engagement celebration," Victoria announced, tilting her chin up as her disdainful eyes swept over Evelyn's attire. "Evelyn, working here now, are we?"

Curious glances from nearby colleagues darted their way, but no one intervened.

Victoria feigned sympathy with a dramatic sigh. "If only you'd swallowed your pride back then, Father wouldn't have disowned you. Look at you now—how far you've fallen..."

Evelyn leaned back lazily against the sofa, her fingers tapping the armrest. She didn’t even bother lifting her eyelids, as if observing a tiresome circus act.

Hannah barely suppressed a whistle. This composure—no wonder Evelyn was a director.

The dismissive attitude made Victoria's face flush with anger. She despised Evelyn's unshakable calm, as if she herself were nothing but a ridiculous clown.

"Stop pretending to be above it all!" Victoria raised her voice sharply. "Today is mine and Nathan's engagement party. Care to join us and see how real society celebrates?"

She deliberately glanced around, ensuring everyone heard her next words. "After all, the Evans family only marries true heiresses... not some impostor."

Nathan frowned but stayed silent. His eyes remained locked on Evelyn, as if waiting for a reaction.

Evelyn finally lifted her gaze, her lips parting slightly. "Finished?"
###Chapter 27

Evelyn Roland finally lifted her gaze, her eyes icy, the corner of her lips curling slightly.

"So?"

Victoria Lowell stepped closer in her stilettos, the hem of her dress swaying gracefully.

"Everything that was yours... now belongs to me."

She tapped Nathan Evans' chest with a manicured finger, her smile triumphant.

Hannah Clementson clenched her fists, her nails digging deep into her palms.

So this was the "real heiress" who stole Evelyn's boyfriend.

Evelyn rose slowly, the fabric of her dress sweeping in an elegant arc.

"You've taken to garbage collection quite naturally."

Her tone was light, as if discussing the weather.

Nathan's face darkened, pain flashing in his eyes.

Victoria abruptly shook off his hand, her manicure glinting coldly under the lights.

"What did you just say?"

Nathan quickly grabbed her arm. "Victoria, don't make a scene."

Yet his gaze remained fixed on Evelyn, his throat bobbing.

Evelyn suddenly laughed, her eyes frosty.

"If you two want to perform a melodrama, I suggest doing it outside the courthouse."

She turned to leave but was stopped by a sickly sweet voice.

Jessica Rubinstein sauntered over, her red lips like fire.

"I heard Miss Roland secured the Valdemar deal?"

She feigned shock, covering her mouth. "Surely not through... special means?"

Victoria's pupils constricted. "What Valdemar deal?"

Jessica leaned in, whispering just loud enough for everyone to hear.

"Someone saw her leaving Mr. Valdemar's office looking disheveled."

The ballroom fell silent.

Evelyn's fingers traced the rim of her champagne flute before she suddenly raised her hand.

Splash.

The entire glass of red wine drenched Jessica's face.

"Feeling clearer now?"

She dropped the glass. The shattering sound made Jessica shriek.

"You—!"

"Next time you spread rumors," Evelyn pulled out a silk handkerchief, wiping her hands with a gaze sharp as a blade,

"Make sure you've bought insurance first."
###Chapter 28

Jessica Rubinstein's words cut through Evelyn Roland like a sharp blade. The atmosphere shifted instantly as every gaze in the room turned judgmental and probing.

Even without makeup, Evelyn's face glowed with a pearlescent radiance under the lights. Such beauty inevitably invited speculation.

Nathan Evans' expression darkened immediately.

"Oh!" Jessica suddenly covered her mouth, feigning regret. "Evelyn, I just think trading favors for business deals is... unseemly. A woman should value herself more. Someone like Mr. Valdemar is out of your league."

Evelyn's fingers curled slowly into fists.

These relentless vultures.

"I don't recall ever doing such a thing."

A frigid voice spoke from behind Jessica, making her shiver violently.

When she turned, her eyes locked onto a face so flawlessly handsome it left her momentarily speechless.

"Answer me."

Sebastian Valdemar's voice snapped Jessica back to reality. His deep-set eyes churned with dangerous undercurrents.

"I—I only heard rumors..."

"So you're spreading lies?"

His tone grew colder. Jessica finally grasped the gravity of the situation and waved her hands frantically. "We were just chatting! I didn't mean to spread rumors!"

Sebastian's gaze darkened further.

"Lawyer."

The single word drained the color from Jessica's face. She reached for him, but he sidestepped her effortlessly.

"Mr. Valdemar, I was wrong! I'll never do it again! Please forgive me!"

Hannah Clementson watched from the crowd, her lips curling in satisfaction.

Sebastian had been dragged to dinner by Zachary Merouin. Spotting a commotion in the lobby, he'd approached—only to overhear his own "scandalous affair" being discussed. And of all people, Evelyn stood at the center.

Amusing.

He had no patience for theatrics. With a quick call, he summoned Adrienne Klein, head of KL Design's third department.

Adrienne, working late, rushed over immediately.

Evelyn had seen enough. She turned and headed for the restroom.

As Sebastian moved to leave, Nathan blocked his path.

"Mr. Valdemar! What an honor. Would you join us for dinner?"

Sebastian's patience had evaporated. He didn't even glance at Nathan. "Move."

Undeterred, Nathan extended a business card. "Here's my contact. Perhaps another time—"

Sebastian stepped around him without a word.

Nathan's outstretched hand hung awkwardly in the air, his face twisting like a spilled paint palette.
###Chapter 29

The hallway gradually emptied as Sebastian Valdemar caught up to Evelyn Roland in a few long strides. He stepped sideways, blocking her path, his tall frame casting a shadow over her.

"In a hurry?"

Evelyn stopped abruptly and met his gaze with icy detachment. "Do you need something, Mr. Valdemar? I don't discuss business outside work hours."

"Just curious." A smirk played at the corner of his lips, but his eyes remained sharp as blades. "With your discerning taste, how did you ever settle for someone like Nathan Evans?"

"My personal life is none of your concern."

Irritation flared within her. This man was always so domineering and relentless. She refused to indulge him further. "It's ancient history. Not worth mentioning."

Sebastian's interest only deepened. "Your expression says otherwise."

Leaning closer, he lowered his voice. "If you're truly over him, prove it. Attend the engagement next door. A proper ex should be like the dead—silent and gone. Treat it as some stranger's wedding."

"How childish." She rubbed the faint red mark on her wrist, meeting his mocking gaze.

His eyes seemed to taunt her: See? You're still hung up on him.

Evelyn felt as though she'd swallowed something vile. "You're revolting."

"Well?" He arched a brow.

"Fine!" She shoved past him, storming toward the adjacent banquet hall.

Sebastian followed at a leisurely pace, his gaze fixed on her rigid posture.

Evelyn's chest tightened as she pushed open the doors. Guests turned in surprise, though decorum kept them from approaching—until Sebastian appeared.

The atmosphere instantly buzzed with energy.

"Mr. Valdemar! What a surprise to see you here!"

"Mr. Valdemar, remember me? From last night's dinner—"

Sebastian barely spared the man—some forgettable businessman from yesterday's gathering—a glance before nodding dismissively.

Yet the man persisted, desperate to ingratiate himself. Others soon swarmed around them, transforming the intimate engagement party into a networking event.

Nathan Evans and Victoria Lowell's smiles froze the moment they spotted Evelyn. Victoria clutched her silk dress so tightly her nails nearly tore through the fabric.

Standing beside Sebastian, Evelyn drew just as much attention. Murmurs spread among the guests:

"Is that Mr. Valdemar's companion? They make a striking pair."

"That's KL Design Group's lead designer, isn't she? So young and accomplished..."

Victoria forced a saccharine smile as she dragged Nathan through the crowd. "How thoughtful of you to attend our engagement, Evelyn." Her voice dripped honey, but her eyes gleamed with venom.

###Chapter 30

The engagement party was in full swing, with champagne flowing freely. Victoria Lowell clung to Nathan Evans' arm, her face adorned with a saccharine smile. Her gaze swept across the corner where Evelyn Roland sat, lips curling into a triumphant smirk.

"Look over there," she whispered to Nathan, barely concealing her glee. "I can't believe she actually showed up."

Nathan followed her line of sight, his expression flickering briefly before he schooled it into polite surprise. "It's wonderful that Evelyn came to celebrate with us."

Victoria let out a derisive hum and deliberately raised her voice. "Why is my dear sister sitting all alone in the corner? Did she forget to bring a gift?"

The surrounding guests immediately turned their attention toward Evelyn. Murmurs rippled through the crowd.

"Is that the eldest Lowell daughter? I heard she doesn’t get along with her family."

"How shameless—showing up empty-handed to her own sister’s engagement party."

Evelyn's fingers tightened around her wineglass, knuckles turning white. The urge to hurl the drink into Victoria’s smug face burned through her.

Just then, a tall figure stepped between them. Sebastian Valdemar stood with one hand casually tucked in his pocket, looking down at Victoria with icy disdain. "Miss Lowell, do you always take such an interest in my date?"

Victoria stiffened before forcing a brittle smile. "I was just concerned about my sister, Mr. Valdemar."

Sebastian reached into his suit jacket and pulled out a check, handing it to a nearby waiter without ceremony. "Consider this Evelyn’s gift to the happy couple."

The waiter’s eyes bulged. "O-one million?!"

Gasps erupted across the room. Vincent and Margaret Lowell immediately pushed forward, their faces alight with greedy delight.

"Oh my, this is too generous—" Margaret reached for Evelyn’s arm. "Darling, you shouldn’t have—"

Evelyn recoiled and instead linked her arm with Sebastian’s. She stared at her adoptive parents’ fawning expressions, nausea churning in her gut.

"Let’s sit over there," she muttered to Sebastian.

Once they were seated in the corner, Sebastian leaned close, his breath brushing her ear. "Not enjoying yourself?"

"Very generous of you," Evelyn hissed. "Using my name to throw money at my enemies. Clever move."

Sebastian arched a brow. "Ah, so that’s what’s bothering you." He tapped his phone screen a few times. "Just had accounting deduct it from your name."

Evelyn whipped her head toward him. "You—!"

"Joking." He pocketed his phone, a glint of amusement in his eyes. "But your temper is far more entertaining than that lifeless mask you were wearing earlier."

Across the ballroom, Victoria glared at the pair, her nails digging into her palms. Nathan followed her gaze, his expression unreadable.

"Stop staring," he murmured. "The press is watching."

Victoria forced a smile, though her mind seethed. She’d wanted to humiliate Evelyn publicly—instead, she’d handed her the spotlight.

Evelyn abruptly stood. "I need the restroom."

She needed air. The suffocating hypocrisy of this party, her revolting family, and the infuriating man beside her were too much.

As she turned the hallway corner, a hand suddenly grabbed her wrist. Evelyn turned to find Nathan staring at her, his eyes dark with emotion.

"Evelyn," he rasped. "We need to talk."
###Chapter 31

The ten-million-dollar check gleamed coldly under the lights.

Evelyn Roland's lips curled into a mocking smile as she pushed the check back toward Sebastian Valdemar with a flick of her fingers.

"Quite generous of you, Mr. Valdemar."

Her gaze swept over Nathan Evans and Victoria Lowell, who were forcing smiles on the stage. Disgust simmered in her eyes.

Sebastian raised an eyebrow, swirling his wine glass with long fingers. "Not enough?"

"Money is a wonderful thing," Evelyn said coldly. "But when spent on trash, even it becomes tainted."

The banquet hall buzzed with clinking glasses and laughter.

Victoria swayed through the crowd in stiletto heels, champagne flute in hand.

"Sister!"

The sickly sweet voice made Evelyn stiffen.

Before she could turn, icy liquid trickled down her neck and into her collar.

"Oh no!" Victoria gasped, feigning shock. "My hand slipped."

The sheer blouse turned transparent, clinging to Evelyn's skin.

All eyes turned toward them.

Victoria's eyes gleamed with triumph, though her face remained the picture of innocence. "You're not angry with me, are you?"

Evelyn paused.

Slowly, she untied the silk scarf from her hair, letting her dark locks cascade down to cover her damp back.

"Careless today, aren't we?" she murmured with a smile. "Perhaps the engagement has left you too excited to walk straight?"

Victoria's face froze.

A few knowing chuckles rose from the guests.

Nathan appeared just in time. "Victoria, didn't you prepare a spare dress for Evelyn?"

His gaze lingered on Evelyn's figure, his Adam's apple bobbing.

In the dressing room, Evelyn had just undone her buttons when the lock clicked.

"Leave the towel outside," she said.

But the footsteps grew closer.

She whirled around to meet a pair of hungry eyes.

"Evelyn..." Nathan locked the door behind him. "I've missed you."

His breath came fast, his collar damp with sweat.

"Get out," Evelyn hissed, clutching her collar.

Nathan ignored her, advancing step by step. "I know you still love me—"

Before he could finish, she drove her knee upward with brutal force.

"Ah!"

Nathan crumpled to the floor with a howl.

Evelyn seized his hair and slammed his head against the wall.

"That," she said through gritted teeth, "was for the girl I used to be."

Blood trickled down the wall.
###Chapter 32

"Everyone evacuate now!"

Evelyn Roland charged down from the third floor to find the corridor littered with wounded. She stood at the stairwell, her voice cutting through the chaos: "They're right behind us! Anyone who can move, follow me out the back!"

"Evelyn, we can't..."

Little Dog dragged his injured leg, his face smeared with soot from the explosion. Tears glistened in his eyes as he looked up. "The guys who just got sterilized can barely stand. Several are still in surgery getting bullets removed..."

"No time!"

Evelyn yanked the silk scarf from her neck and tied it around Little Dog's bleeding arm. Her nails dug into her palms. "We move now or die. Carry the critically wounded if you have to!"

Voices rose in ragged agreement down the hallway. Members of the Blenheim faction struggled to their feet—some hauling unconscious comrades on stretchers, others limping downstairs arm-in-arm. White-coated doctors wheeled IV stands while nurses followed clutching emergency kits.

The private hospital's neon lights glared harshly against the night.

"Triple the fee—get your director here!"

Evelyn slammed a stack of bills onto the reception desk. The nurse's hands shook as she grabbed the phone. Within minutes, every light in the building blazed to life, the sound of gurney wheels filling the corridors.

"Evelyn! Massachusetts General is on fire!"

Little Dog's shriek made her whirl around. The distant inferno painted her ashen face crimson. A sudden realization struck her like lightning, and she sprinted toward the flames without hesitation.

"Vincent's still inside!"

The night wind stung her cheeks. As Evelyn rounded the second intersection, seven shadowy figures emerged from an alley. The lead man wore a black balaclava, his voice grating like sandpaper. "Running straight to us, sweetheart?"

"Move!"

Her boot knife slid into her palm. The blade flashed—splitting the man's vest open, spilling entrails and blood. She seized his twin pistols and dropped two pursuers with headshots.

At the third gunshot, white-hot agony pierced Evelyn's ribs. The bullet exploded from her back in a fist-sized exit wound. Staggering, she felt the weapons grow leaden in her grip.

"Die, bitch!"

The masked man raised her own dagger, its tip inches from her throat. Evelyn shut her eyes—only to hear a sickening crack. Warm blood splattered her face. When she looked, a headless corpse toppled before her.

"Shouldn't you repay your savior with a kiss?"

A young doctor knelt beside her, surgical scissors already slicing through bloodied fabric. Evelyn turned away, tears mingling with blood at her temples. Her mind reeled with images of Vincent consumed by flames—until the sudden rip of her shirt snapped her back.

"Marry me now?"

"You—disgusting!"

Evelyn flushed scarlet, then convulsed from searing back pain. Dominic Laurent approached carrying an unconscious Vincent, his beard quivering with laughter. "Finally showing some sense, boy!"

In the hospital corridor, Little Dog burst into tears seeing the two wheeled into surgery together. The young doctor forced a pill between Evelyn's lips before scowling at the old man. "Grandfather, her tripled fee—"

"Save them first."

Dominic gripped his grandson's shoulder, scanning the deserted hallway. Not a single Blenheim guard remained—only this blood-soaked boy weeping alone. With a sigh, the elder retrieved a golden syringe from his medical kit's hidden compartment.
###Chapter 33

Evelyn Roland leaned against the ornate pillar, her fingertips tracing the rim of her wine glass. A faint smile played at the corners of her lips. To her, this farce was nothing more than a poorly staged performance.

"Nathan would never do such a thing!" Victoria Lowell stormed into the center of the crowd, her delicate makeup twisting with fury as she clutched her skirt.

I stepped forward gracefully, the silk of my gown shimmering like pearls under the chandeliers. "Oh, dear sister," I sighed, shaking my head. "Your judgment in men remains as flawed as ever."

Victoria opened her mouth to retort, but I raised a hand to silence the murmuring crowd. "Since we're at an impasse," I said, sweeping my gaze across the room, "why not consult the surveillance footage? After all..." I paused meaningfully. "Machines never lie."

The ballroom erupted in murmurs of agreement. The elite exchanged knowing glances, none willing to miss this unfolding drama.

"Pull up the footage!"
"We demand the truth!"

Victoria bit her lip and summoned the manager. The middle-aged man in a crisp suit hesitated. "My apologies, but the hotel's electrical systems are undergoing maintenance today..."

I scoffed. Even a child wouldn’t fall for such a flimsy excuse.

"No footage means you can twist the truth?" Victoria lifted her chin defiantly. "It was you who seduced Nathan!"

Sebastian Valdemar stood by the champagne tower, his long fingers idly stroking the stem of his glass. He watched as the woman in the deep red gown smiled with the poise of a languid Persian cat.

"Does anyone have a laptop?" My cool voice cut through the noise.

Sebastian arched a brow. His assistant immediately handed over a sleek silver notebook, its metallic surface gleaming under the lights.

As I took the laptop, my fingers brushed against his wristwatch. The cold metal sent a fleeting shiver through me—a stark contrast to the heat of his grip on my waist the night before, when that same watch had pressed into my skin.

The keyboard clacked crisply under my fingers. Victoria fidgeted, her crystal nails scraping against the fabric of her dress.

"Stop pretending!" she snapped.

The blue glow of the screen illuminated my face. I didn’t bother looking up. "Patience. The truth isn’t going anywhere."

Five minutes later, I breached the hotel’s security system. The large screen flickered to life, revealing Nathan Evans sneaking into the dressing room with a lecherous grin.

Silence engulfed the ballroom. I closed the laptop and turned, my skirt brushing against Sebastian’s trousers. He gazed down at me, his dark eyes swirling with something unreadable.

"Now," I smoothed nonexistent wrinkles from my sleeve. "Who owes whom an apology?"
###Chapter 34

"Finally, this day has come." Nathan Evans' eyes gleamed with greed as his fingers roughly tore open the woman's collar. "I'm going to savor every bit of you today."

Every detail was crystal clear on the high-definition screen. The mask of hypocrisy had been ripped away, leaving Nathan with no room for denial.

Victoria Lowell's face drained of color, then turned ashen before flushing crimson. Her fists clenched so tightly her nails dug into her palms.

"Vicky, this video is fake!" Nathan grabbed her arm in panic. "Someone must be framing me!"

Evelyn Roland smirked disdainfully. "Feel free to have it authenticated."

With a tap of her fingers on the keyboard, the screen split into nine squares—each showing Nathan entangled with different women in compromising positions.

The banquet hall erupted in chaos.

Gasps of shock rippled through the crowd. Vincent and Margaret Lowell looked ready to vanish on the spot, their faces twisted in humiliation.

What was meant to be a joyous engagement party had become a farce.

"Evelyn Roland!" Victoria shrieked hysterically, charging toward the stage. "I'll kill you!"

Madness burned in her eyes.

If not for this woman, she would have been the happiest bride. Now everything was ruined.

"Take your tantrum elsewhere." Evelyn tossed the words over her shoulder and walked away, leaving the Lowell family in disarray.

Sebastian Valdemar narrowed his eyes, watching the retreating figure with intrigue.

Hacking into a five-star hotel's surveillance system in such a short time—this woman was far from ordinary.

For the first time, someone had piqued his interest so intensely.

"Evelyn Roland," he murmured, striding after her.

At the hotel entrance, Evelyn massaged her aching ankles. The eight-centimeter heels made her steps unsteady.

She didn't notice the scorching gaze fixed on her back.

"Mr. Valdemar." Adrienne Klein's voice suddenly cut through the air.

Sebastian turned with a frown.

Jessica Rubinstein approached nervously. "Mr. Valdemar, those rumors at the celebration were just hearsay. Please don't take them to heart."

She kept her head bowed, not daring to meet his icy stare.
###Chapter 35

Jessica Rubinstein stumbled on the steps as her high heels caught the edge. She knew full well that if this deal fell through because of her loose tongue, the consequences would be unbearable.

Sebastian Valdemar stood beneath the streetlamp, his tall frame casting a long shadow. His lips parted, voice icy. "If you're going to apologize, direct it to the right person."

Following his gaze, the trio spotted Evelyn Roland waiting by the curb for a taxi. The night breeze lifted strands of her hair, softening the edges under the golden light.

Jessica dug her nails into her palms. Bowing to Evelyn was more bitter than swallowing a fly. But facing the Valdemar Group's formidable leader, she had no choice.

"I... I'm sorry." Jessica approached Evelyn, her hair falling forward to hide her contorted expression as she bowed.

Evelyn arched a brow in surprise. This woman, who had always been her adversary, now stood before her like a chastened schoolgirl.

"I spoke nonsense at the banquet earlier." Jessica's voice trembled. "I shouldn't have spread rumors about you and Mr. Valdemar."

A taxi's vacant light glowed as it pulled up. Evelyn opened the door, her gaze clear as she turned back. "Rumors die with the wise. Next time, try speaking with evidence."

As the taillights vanished around the corner, Sebastian's lips curved faintly. This woman was far more intriguing than he'd anticipated.

The shadows of plane trees flowed across the car window as they drove through the Beverly Hills estate. The moment Evelyn stepped out, Sophia Roland grabbed her arm. "Child, why take a taxi when we have cars at home?"

The garage gleamed with limited-edition sports cars, any one worth a fortune. Evelyn shook her head. "Taxis are more convenient."

She refused to reveal her identity. At KL Design Group, she was just an ordinary employee. She'd seen enough sycophantic smiles to last a lifetime.

"Fine, have it your way." Sophia lowered her voice. "If anyone at work bullies you, tell me immediately."

Upstairs, the curtains twitched violently. Isabella Langley gripped the fabric so tightly her nails nearly tore through. The harmonious scene below stabbed at her heart like a knife.

This sudden "sister" had stolen everything that should have been hers.
###Chapter 36

The crystal chandelier refracted dazzling light across the cheerful scene in the Roland family's parlor.

"Evelyn's recent performance reminds me of my younger self." Edward Roland took a sip of dragon well tea, satisfaction evident in his eyes.

Evelyn lowered her lashes, fingertips tracing the rim of her teacup. "You flatter me, Father. I still have much to learn."

"Mom, Dad, I'm home!" Isabella Langley fluttered into the room like a sparrow and nestled beside Sophia. "What are you talking about?"

Sophia set down her cup, gaze shifting between her daughters. "We were discussing your sister's latest major contract. Isabella, you should learn from her." She emphasized the last words deliberately.

"I'll definitely seek guidance from Alexander and Evelyn." Isabella's smile was radiant, but a shadow flickered in her eyes.

She tilted her head suddenly. "Why don't I intern at the company too? Now that I've graduated, it's time to gain experience." Her almond-shaped eyes sparkled with anticipation as she looked at her parents.

Edward exchanged a glance with his wife before laughing heartily. "Excellent! Young people should challenge themselves. Report tomorrow."

"Thank you!" Isabella clapped her hands, though her peripheral vision remained fixed on Evelyn's reaction.

Evelyn lifted her teacup calmly, steam obscuring her expression. She knew her sister's games all too well—but this time, she wouldn't retreat.

The next morning, KL Design Group CEO's office.

Sebastian Valdemar had barely stepped inside, his suit jacket still unbuttoned, when he pressed the intercom.

"Theodore. Now."

Outside, Theodore adjusted his tie, Adam's apple bobbing nervously. The CEO's stormy expression was darker than gathering thunderclouds.

"You summoned me, Mr. Valdemar?"

Sebastian stood before the floor-to-ceiling windows, his ramrod posture radiating icy intensity. "Terminate all collaborations with the Evans and Lowell families. Immediately."

Theodore's pupils constricted. "But sir, those projects account for 15% of our quarterly revenue. The penalty clauses alone—"

"I said terminate." Sebastian turned, his gaze sharp as a blade. "Need I repeat myself?"

The office temperature plummeted. A cold sweat trickled down Theodore's spine.
###Chapter 37

The phone rang abruptly just as Nathan Evans raised his glass in toast to Vincent and Margaret Lowell.

"Uncle, Aunt, I promise—"

His words were cut off by the shrill ringtone that shattered the intimate atmosphere of the private dining room.

Vincent's brow furrowed as he slammed his chopsticks onto the bowl with a sharp clatter.

"Answer it," his father hissed under his breath.

Nathan froze as if struck by lightning, nearly dropping the phone.

"Mr. Valdemar, please let me explain—"

"The penalty fee has been transferred to the company account," Sebastian interrupted. "And regarding your embezzlement, Legal will contact you shortly."

The dial tone echoed harshly in the stunned silence.

Vincent shoved his chair back with a screech, rising to his feet.

"Embezzlement?" He glared at Nathan, whose face had turned ashen. "This is your so-called reformation?"

Victoria grabbed her father's arm in panic. "Dad, there must be some mistake—"

"A mistake?" Vincent shook her off. "Is this how you raised your son, Mr. Evans?"

Beads of sweat formed on Nathan's father's forehead as he opened his mouth to speak—when another notification chimed.

A bank alert flashed on Nathan's screen: "Your account has been frozen..."

His legs gave out, sending him crashing to his knees.

As Victoria rushed to help him up, Vincent yanked her away.

"We're leaving!" he barked, storming toward the exit. "The engagement is over!"

Margaret hesitated, but a sharp look from her husband silenced her.

The door slammed shut behind them.

Nathan's father backhanded him across the face.

"You disgrace!"

Nathan clutched his cheek, eyes glazed with shock. "It's over... Everything's over..."

Meanwhile, in the Valdemar Group executive office...

Theodore Ashcroft placed a document on Sebastian's desk. "It's done, sir."

Sebastian skimmed the file, his gaze lingering on the final figure.

"Contact the press."

Theodore blinked. "Sir?"

"I want every headline tomorrow to feature Nathan Evans' embezzlement scandal."

Outside the floor-to-ceiling windows, twilight deepened.

Sebastian stood silhouetted against the skyline, fingertips tapping the glass.

"Evelyn Roland... I hope you appreciate this gift."

###Chapter 38

Mr. Evans' phone suddenly vibrated.

He frowned and pressed the answer button.

His fingers clenched around the phone.

"What did you say?" His voice rose sharply. "Valdemar is canceling our contracts?"

"It's confirmed." The assistant's voice shook. "The order came directly from Mr. Valdemar himself."

A vein pulsed at Mr. Evans' temple.

"Arrange a meeting with Sebastian Valdemar immediately." He commanded through gritted teeth.

After hanging up, his expression darkened like a thunderstorm. Valdemar's contracts were worth millions. The financial impact would be catastrophic.

Meanwhile, Vincent Lowell received the same news.

"Nathan, this doesn't make sense." Vincent stubbed out his cigarette violently. "Why would Valdemar suddenly turn against both our families?"

Mr. Evans gave a cold laugh. "Someone's clearly targeting us."

The atmosphere in the private room turned glacial.

"It must be Evelyn Roland!" Victoria Lowell jumped to her feet. "Who else would come after us like this?"

Vincent snapped at her. "Don't make baseless accusations!"

"Dad!" Victoria stomped her foot in frustration. "She's jealous of my relationship with Nathan!"

Mr. Evans interjected sarcastically. "Your family certainly raised an outstanding daughter."

"And what about your playboy son?" Vincent slammed the table as he stood. "Spending every night partying!"

Mrs. Evans quickly intervened. "Enough! Our priority is salvaging these contracts."

Both families exchanged uneasy glances. Against Valdemar Group's financial might, they stood no chance.

"Nathan," Mr. Evans said suddenly. "You and Victoria should go talk to Evelyn Roland."

"Why should I beg her?" Victoria shrieked.

Mr. Evans narrowed his eyes. "Unless you'd prefer both our families to go bankrupt?"

Victoria bit her lip until it bled, nails digging into her palms. Beg that bitch for mercy? Never.
###Chapter 39

Margaret gently pressed her palm over Victoria's trembling hand.

"Victoria, this isn't the time for stubbornness." Her voice dropped to a whisper. "The Lowells need you."

Victoria bit her lower lip until it bled.

The metallic tang spread across her tongue.

She understood her mother's unspoken meaning perfectly.

But how could she stand by while that impostor stole her rightful place?

KL Design Group.

Isabella strode into the design department in limited-edition stilettos.

Diamond bracelets glittered on her wrist under the office lights.

"Hello everyone~"

Her saccharine voice made several male colleagues look up.

From her Hermès bag, she produced exquisitely wrapped gift boxes.

"Handmade chocolates from Milan."

She placed them on each desk with calculated grace.

"Let's get along~"

"Are these...Venchi's Golden Collection?"

"Care to try one, sister?"

The box landed with a thud.

Evelyn kept typing without looking up.

"Allergic."

Jessica immediately scurried over.

"Don't mind her, Isabella. Some people have no appreciation."

"Only a true Roland heiress would give such extravagant gifts."

But something dark flickered in her eyes.

Adrienne pushed through the glass doors.

Just in time to witness the spectacle.

"Are we being paid to socialize?"

Her icy tone scattered the crowd like startled birds.

"Ms. Klein—"

She extended a navy velvet box.

The Patek Philippe logo gleamed faintly.

Adrienne didn't even glance up.

"This isn't a charity."

Her pen slashed across documents with brutal precision.

"Either prove your worth."

"Take your bribes and get out."

Isabella's face drained of color.

Her manicured nails dug into her palms.

She whirled toward the elevators.

And pressed the button for the top floor.

Through frosted glass, a tall silhouette moved in the CEO's office.

Isabella's lips curved.

"Sebastian..."
###Chapter 40

The elevator doors slid open. Benjamin Chamberlain immediately stepped forward. "Good afternoon, Ms. Langley."

Isabella Langley stormed past him in her stilettos. "Where's my brother?"

Evelyn Roland stretched after finishing her morning tasks and headed for the break room. As she reached the doorway, she collided with a distracted Hannah Clementson.

Splash!

Scalding coffee drenched Evelyn's pristine white suit.

Her hands paused mid-wipe. This was Hannah's third distracted moment today.

"Is everything alright?" Evelyn asked softly.

Her phone buzzed. The screen lit up—Hannah's face drained of color.
###Chapter 41

Hannah spun around abruptly, the water glass trembling slightly in her grip. She tilted her head back and gulped down the entire glass of cold water, her Adam's apple bobbing frantically.

Evelyn pressed her lips together. She could tell something was off with Hannah, but she didn't press further. "Take the day off if you're unwell," she murmured before turning toward her workstation.

The bottom of the glass reflected Hannah's bloodshot eyes. A single tear fell silently, creating tiny ripples across the water's surface.

During lunch break, the office building was filled with the mingled aromas of takeout. Hannah grabbed her bag and hurried out, her cap pulled low and a mask covering most of her face.

"Miss, you—" The security guard barely started speaking when a disheveled man suddenly lunged from behind a pillar and seized Hannah's wrist.

"Playing dumb now?" The man reeked of alcohol, his fingernails caked with grime. "Ignoring my calls?"

Hannah flinched. "Let go!"

Instead of releasing her, he tightened his grip. "Think you're too good for me now? Trying to ditch your old man?" He yanked off her cap and snarled at the guard, "This is a family matter—stay out of it!"

The guard froze. Hannah bit her lip hard—the drunken, smoke-stained man was indeed her biological father.

"I don't have money," she whispered, her voice shaking. "Really, I don't."

"Bullshit!" Richard snatched her bag and rifled through it. "A fancy office worker with no cash?" Finding only files and pens, he hurled the bag to the ground and started digging through her pockets.

"Enough!" Hannah finally snapped. "Five million in gambling debts! I couldn't pay that off in ten years even if I starved!"

"Then sell yourself!" Richard's eyes gleamed with sudden excitement. "Pretty thing like you—sleep with a few rich men..."

Across the lobby, Jessica was waiting in line for coffee. Hearing the commotion, she narrowed her eyes and discreetly raised her phone.

"You monster!" Hannah swung her bag at him, each strike punctuated by ragged sobs. "Why don't you just die!"

Richard staggered back, still slurring obscenities. "After all I've done for you—" Before he could finish, security dragged him out.

Hannah fled to the restroom, locking herself in a stall. The mirror showed her smeared lipstick, like a streak of blood.

"Scandal alert!" Jessica wriggled into the break room, waving her phone. "Someone in this company is turning tricks!"

Colleagues instantly clustered around. Jessica triumphantly played the video—Hannah hysterically beating a man while he shouted about her becoming a prostitute.

The cold glow of the screen illuminated their eager faces.
###Chapter 42 

"Isn't that Hannah Clementson?"

Hannah emerged from the restroom, her eyes still red. Carrying her lunch, she felt the hallway gazes prick her back like needles.

The office whispers died abruptly. She looked up to see coworkers hastily averting their eyes, phones still glowing in their hands.

Her phone vibrated. A video was spreading like wildfire in the main company group.

[SHOCKING! Female Employee's Secret Transactions Exposed]

"Hold her down!" Jessica shrieked.

Half a dozen hands seized Hannah. Her blouse tore at the shoulder, angry red marks blooming on her arm.

Evelyn Roland burst into the office to this scene: Hannah pinned on the floor, tear-streaked, Jessica's hand raised for another strike.

"Stop!"

Evelyn was shoved from behind. She stumbled into a desk, sharp pain exploding at her temple.

"Enough."

The voice cut through the chaos like a blade. Everyone froze.

Sebastian Valdemar stood in the doorway, his gaze glacial. It swept the wrecked office before landing on Evelyn's bruised forehead.

Jessica's hand still hovered mid-air. She paled, lips trembling. "M-Mr. Valdemar..."

Hannah curled on the floor, blouse gaping open. Her phone screen still displayed the looping video.
###Chapter 43

"The caliber of KL employees is truly eye-opening." Sebastian Valdemar's icy gaze swept across the room. "Perhaps our partnership requires reevaluation."

Evelyn Roland pressed her lips together, silent.

Evelyn stepped in front of Hannah, her voice sharpening. "Rumors die with the wise. Unfortunately, everyone here chose to be an accomplice."

Her piercing glare made the crowd lower their eyes—all except Jessica, who stubbornly lifted her chin, though her ears burned scarlet.

Under the lights, she gleamed like an unsheathed blade. Sebastian's throat tightened, something wild pounding in his chest.

Applause sounded from the doorway. Alexander Roland strode in with Isabella Langley in tow.

He’d expected trouble after seeing the group chat, but he hadn’t anticipated Evelyn dismantling the farce first.

Blood truly was remarkable. He shot her an approving glance.

"This might be forward, but if you need help, I’m here."

###Chapter 44

"Child's play."

Not only did they return every cent, they voluntarily handed over all their illegal records.

###Chapter 45

###Chapter 46

###Chapter 47

Dorian Wayne pulled out a stack of tissues and handed them over, his eyes filled with heartache. Jessica Rubinstein was his niece, whom he had watched grow up. Seeing her get fired from the company pained him more than anyone else.

The next morning.

Evelyn Roland had just settled into her workstation when her phone buzzed. A text from Hannah Clementson flashed on the screen: "Evelyn, I left in such a hurry yesterday that I forgot to sign my leave form. Can you help me with it?"

KL Group's policy required employees to notify HR a day in advance for leave requests. Failing to do so would affect their monthly attendance bonus.

Evelyn tapped a quick reply: "No problem. I'll handle it now."

In the HR office, a staff member handed her a form. "Fill this out and get it signed by Director Wang."

"Come in."

"Wait." He suddenly called her back, pointing to a pile of documents in the corner. "Take these outdated files to the shredder."

Evelyn glanced at the stack, nearly waist-high, and pressed her lips together. "Understood."
