###Chapter 48

"Understood, Director Wang."

Evelyn Roland had no idea a storm was brewing in the conference room on the thirtieth floor.

At exactly 10 a.m., all department heads of KL Design Group gathered in the meeting room. Alexander Roland's icy demeanor made the temperature in the room plummet. His long fingers struck the table with a sharp, unsettling rap.

"A three-hundred-million-dollar contract—vanished into thin air?"

The room was dead silent. Everyone kept their heads down, barely daring to breathe. It was the first time they'd seen the usually composed Alexander so furious.

"This document is tied to the company's most crucial project for the second half of the year." His voice was like frozen steel. "Do you understand the gravity of this?"

The CFO's pen clattered to the floor, the sound piercing the suffocating silence.

Suddenly, an assistant burst in, flustered.

"Mr. Roland, we found the file."

Sweat beaded on his forehead as his voice trembled.

"But... it's already been shredded."

The air turned to ice. Everyone held their breath, terrified of becoming the next casualty of Alexander's wrath.

"Investigate!" Alexander slammed his palm on the table, his knuckles white. "I want to know who did this!"

Surveillance footage was quickly pulled up. When Evelyn appeared on the screen, Alexander's pupils constricted.

"Evelyn Roland from the Third Design Department?" Dorian Wayne immediately jumped up, pointing accusingly at Adrienne Klein. "This is your team's doing! Who's going to cover the three-hundred-million loss?"

Adrienne's forehead glistened with sweat. Though she'd once doubted Evelyn's competence, working alongside her had changed her opinion entirely.

"Could there... be some misunderstanding?" she ventured weakly.

"Misunderstanding?" Wang sneered. "The footage is crystal clear. Are you trying to protect your own, Director Klein?"

At the far end of the table, Alexander's fingers tapped rhythmlessly against the wood. He needed to answer to the board—but he didn’t want Evelyn humiliated.

"Bring her here," he finally ordered, his voice taut with barely restrained tension.

Adrienne immediately dialed her phone. "Evelyn, come to the thirtieth-floor conference room. Now."

The elevator ascended slowly. Evelyn watched the numbers climb, her chest suddenly tightening with inexplicable dread. She pressed a hand to her heart, sensing something terrible was about to unfold.
###Chapter 49

The conference room door gave a soft knock.

Evelyn Roland stood outside, her fingertips still poised mid-air from rapping on the wood.

"Come in."

When she pushed open the door, the room fell into dead silence. Every executive's gaze snapped toward her, the air thick with tension.

Adrienne Klein sat at the head of the table, her expression grave. "A critical company contract was shredded in the printing room. Surveillance shows you were the only person who entered there this morning."

Evelyn's eyes swept across the assembled faces before landing on the Director of HR, Daniel Murphy. He was fiddling with a pen, the ghost of a smirk playing on his lips.

Suddenly, everything clicked.

"I did it," Evelyn stated plainly.

The room erupted. Whispers rippled through the crowd. Some shook their heads in disappointment. Others curled their lips in disdain.

Alexander Roland shot to his feet, but one sharp glance from her froze him in place.

"Since Miss Roland has confessed, we should proceed according to company policy," Daniel said airily, as if discussing the weather.

The head of marketing jumped in. "We happen to need someone for market research. She can collect sales data from department stores."

In the sweltering midsummer heat, it was clearly a punishment in disguise.

Before Adrienne could speak, Evelyn nodded. "No problem."

Her immediate agreement stunned everyone.

——

3 PM. The sun blazed overhead.

Evelyn entered the third department store's KL Boutique, the back of her blouse already soaked with sweat.

"Let me try that necklace." A saccharine voice rang out.

Victoria Lowell stood at the counter, pointing at a piece of jewelry behind the glass. Dressed in designer labels, the diamonds on her wrist glittered under the lights.

Evelyn pretended not to see her, approaching a sales associate to request sales figures.

"Oh my, if it isn't KL's little employee?" Victoria's voice sharpened. "Reduced to running errands now?"

Other customers turned to look.

Evelyn kept writing, her pen scratching against the notepad.

"Hey! I'm talking to you!" Victoria stomped over in her stilettos. "I demand service. Now!"

Her crimson-lacquered nails came dangerously close to Evelyn's face.
###Chapter 50

Victoria Lowell's nails dug into her palms as she strode into the jewelry boutique on stiletto heels. The humiliation Evelyn Roland had inflicted upon her at the charity gala resurfaced with a vengeance.

"Show me your most expensive pieces." Her chin lifted, voice sharp enough to cut glass.

The sales associate Jessica cast a nervous glance toward Evelyn, who stood observing calmly. The Lowell heiress always made extravagant demands but inevitably settled for the cheapest items.

Evelyn methodically slipped on white gloves, fingertips tapping twice against the glass counter.

"Which piece would you like to try, Miss Lowell?"

A malicious smile curled Victoria's crimson lips as her manicured finger swept across the display.

"All of them."

The boutique fell so silent one could hear a pin drop. Over twenty pieces—trying them all would take the entire afternoon.

Evelyn didn't even blink, retrieving the first necklace with practiced ease. She knew Victoria's type—the more attention paid, the worse the tantrums became.

"Is she insane?" whispered a new hire.

"Shh—rumor says Evelyn publicly humiliated her at last month's gala..."

The gossip died abruptly as a tall figure paused outside the glass doors.

Sebastian Valdemar's eyes narrowed. Through the window, he could see Evelyn's slightly reddened fingertips—she'd already fastened over a dozen necklaces.

"Mr. Valdemar?" His assistant halted in confusion.

The door chimed as Victoria sneered at a sapphire piece, "Who would display such hideous design?"

"Miss Lowell." Sebastian's voice held glacial precision. "Valdemar Group doesn't welcome clients of your caliber."

Victoria whirled around, face freezing mid-snarl. The Valdemar heir was the last person she expected here.

"I—I'm a paying customer!" Her bravado wavered.

Sebastian strode to Evelyn's side, effortlessly taking the necklace from her hands.

"Not anymore."

He pressed the service bell with measured force. "Security. Escort this woman out."

Victoria's face paled as she grabbed her purse and fled, shooting Evelyn one last venomous glare.

No one noticed the smartphone recording from the corner. By evening, #ValdemarHeirDefendsDesigner trended nationwide.

"...Valdemar Group stocks surged 5% today following the incident," the financial anchor reported, "reaching this year's peak..."

###Chapter 51

The entire mall fell silent the moment Sebastian Valdemar appeared.

He stood behind Evelyn Roland, his piercing gaze sweeping across the room. Everyone knew exactly whose side the Valdemar Group CEO was on.

"Finished?" Sebastian asked in a low voice.

Evelyn kept organizing the shelves without looking up. "Mm."

She turned to leave, but Sebastian caught her wrist.

"That's it?" He arched an eyebrow. "I came all this way to help, and not even a thank you?"

Evelyn shook off his grip. "None of your business."

Sebastian followed her relentlessly. "This happens to be my mall. Care to explain why you're here?"

Employees discreetly stepped back to give them space.

Evelyn finally stopped walking. "What do you want?"

"See this." Sebastian pulled out his phone and played a video.

The footage showed Evelyn standing over a debt collector, cigarette dangling from her lips, eyes sharp as daggers.

"Delete it." She lunged for the phone.

Sebastian easily dodged. "So fierce now? Where's that energy from when you helped your friend collect debts? Why take their insults today?"

"Fuck off." Evelyn turned on her heel.

Sebastian chuckled behind her. "Adorable."

The video went viral overnight. Netizens quickly uncovered Victoria Lowell's social media accounts, flooding her comments.

"This is the Lowell heiress? Classy."
"Someone audit Lowell Group's books."
"Already reported. You're welcome."

The next morning, Victoria got pelted with rotten eggs the moment she stepped outside. No suspects—just blind spots in the security cameras.

Worse, Lowell Group's stock began plummeting. Their website got overrun with mocking messages:

"Rebrand as Lowell Losers."
"With this heir, the company won't last three months."
"Waiting for bankruptcy filings."

###Chapter 52

Vincent Lowell kicked open the front door to find Victoria Lowell touching up her makeup in front of the mirror. Without a word, he stormed over and slapped her across the face.

The sharp crack echoed through the room as her lipstick clattered to the floor.

"Dad!" she shrieked, clutching her cheek.

"Shut up!" Vincent's veins bulged at his temples. "Look what you've done! Those photos are all over the internet!"

Tears spilled down Victoria's face. "It's all Evelyn Roland's fault! That bitch set me up!"

"You dare blame others?" Vincent grabbed her collar and shook her. "One more stunt like this, and I'll break your legs myself!"

Meanwhile, Valdemar Group's stock prices soared. The market responded enthusiastically to news of their collaboration with KL Design Group.

In the design department, Evelyn meticulously inspected the newly completed jewelry pieces. Three rare gemstones sparkled under the lights, perfectly set into the platinum bases she'd designed.

"Perfect," she murmured, closing the velvet case. "Send these to Sebastian for final approval."

Her assistant had just picked up the box when a crowd suddenly flooded the office.

"Wow! Is this the KL collection?" A female colleague gasped dramatically.

"Let us see!" A male coworker reached for the box.

The assistant stumbled back. "Be careful!"

"What's the big deal?" Someone snatched the case. "It's not like we'll break it."

Evelyn frowned. "Don't damage—"

Before she could finish, the group jostled around the box. Someone bumped into another—

Crash.

The sound of shattering gemstones pierced the air.

Silence fell.

"Not me!" The first grabber jumped away.

"You started it!"

"Bullshit! You're the one who pushed!"

Pale-faced, they all backed away, pointing fingers. The three priceless gems lay in fragments, their fractured surfaces mocking them under the lights.

Then a finger shot toward Evelyn.

"It's her fault! She dropped the box!"

###Chapter 53

"Did your design lack even the most basic protective measures?" A colleague pointed at the shattered gem fragments on the floor, her voice shrill. "If you'd included cushioning structures, the gem wouldn't have broken on impact!"

Evelyn Roland swept a cold gaze over the group.

"Why don't you just admit it was your design flaw to Mr. Valdemar?" Another colleague sidled closer, lowering her voice. "He dotes on you so much—he won't hold you accountable."

"Why should I take the blame for you?" Evelyn's lips curled into a mocking smile. "Even if I tell him the truth, he still won't fault me."

"You're heartless!" someone snapped, eyes red with panic. "This is a team project! If things go south, we all suffer!"

"No," Evelyn took a step back, crossing her arms. "Only you will suffer. Whoever dropped it should take responsibility. Don't drag me into this."

"This gem is priceless! How could we possibly afford to compensate?"

"We're doomed. Will Valdemar Group sue us?"

"Maybe we should just quit and run..."

"You can run, but you can't hide!"

Chaos erupted as fear twisted their faces.

Evelyn watched them dispassionately. These same people had just tried to guilt-trip her. Now they were scared?

Still, the damaged necklace would delay the project. A solution was needed—fast.

"Enough!" Adrienne Klein strode in on stiletto heels. Her pupils constricted at the sight of the fragments. As a seasoned designer, she recognized the genuine article instantly, her face draining of color.

"Useless fools! Can't even hold a piece of jewelry properly? Maybe you belong in a kitchen scrubbing dishes!"

The group fell silent. "Adrienne, please help us... Get Evelyn to intervene..."

Adrienne's tone softened when she turned to Evelyn. "This won't end well for anyone if it escalates. They can't pay for this, but the project can't stall... Could you go to Valdemar Group?"

Evelyn's expression eased slightly.

She respected Adrienne. For her, she'd make an exception. Besides, the problem wasn't unsolvable—she just despised her colleagues' hypocrisy.

Seeing her hesitation, Adrienne signaled the others.

"Sorry, Evelyn! We were desperate!"
"Please, be the bigger person and help us!"

Evelyn ignored their hollow apologies. "I'll go to Valdemar Group. But whatever happens next is on you."

Carefully gathering the fragments and remnants, she left without a backward glance.

——

Valdemar Group, Top-floor Office.

"Trouble?" Sebastian Valdemar arched a brow at Evelyn's unexpected visit, his gaze dropping to the velvet box in her hands.

###Chapter 54

The velvet box creaked open in Evelyn Roland's hands. Her expression remained unreadable. "It's broken. My apologies—our team was too heavy-handed."

Sebastian Valdemar lifted a finger. His assistant immediately placed a steaming cup of coffee before Evelyn. She took the seat, her posture slightly less rigid than before.

"KL is willing to comply with any solution Valdemar Group proposes."

"That complicates things." Sebastian tapped the desk with long fingers, his hawk-like gaze pinning her. "These gems were rare auction acquisitions—priceless. Now the project is delayed, and the losses are incalculable."

Evelyn dipped her chin. She had anticipated this. "I'll report to the CEO. Valdemar will receive compensation."

"No rush." His tone shifted abruptly. "There's another option—let me see the birthmark on your waist."

"What birthmark?" Her brow furrowed.

Sebastian didn’t flinch. Once he set his mind to something, he never wavered.

"Don’t play dumb. One look, and KL walks away debt-free."

"Dream on!" She shot to her feet. "The mighty Valdemar CEO is secretly a lecher? You expect me to undress in your office?"

"Just your waist."

"Is there a difference?" Ice flashed in her eyes. "How many women have fallen for this trick?"

"You misunderstand."

"Perverts don’t get excuses!" Her fingers trembled with fury. "Not a chance!"

The air turned glacial. They stood locked in a silent battle, tension crackling like a lit fuse.

Then Sebastian relaxed, his usual composure sliding back into place. "Fine. What’s your solution? These stones aren’t replaceable."

Evelyn’s gaze dropped to the box. Fractured gemstones glimmered under the light, casting prismatic shards across the table.

"What if... we redesign with the fragments?"

"What?"

She was already moving. Delicate fingers rearranged the pieces with surgical precision. Three central stones dissolved into asymmetrical shards, suspended from chains of varying lengths. Tiny diamonds clustered around them like scattered stardust.

Under her touch, the once-staid design transformed—elegance edged with rebellion, sophistication laced with wildness.

When she finally stepped back, the office was dead silent.

"Well?" She tilted her chin, strands of hair brushing her neck.

Sebastian studied the creation, already envisioning it gracing a woman’s collarbone.

His eyes lifted to hers. "No wonder they call you the design world’s prodigy."

###Chapter 55

"You flatter me, Mr. Valdemar." Evelyn Roland's lips curved slightly, but her eyes remained unreadable.

Sebastian Valdemar gazed at the piece displayed in the glass case. The scattered diamonds refracted delicate sparks under the lights, like stars strewn across the night sky. His long fingers traced the edge of the display as he murmured in a low voice, "How about 'Shattered Stars'?"

Evelyn's fingertips trembled imperceptibly.

Shattered Stars—even when broken, they still shine.

"A beautiful name," she heard herself say.

Sebastian immediately instructed Theodore Ashcroft to send the piece to the R&D department. Three days later, the Shattered Stars Collection launched for pre-sale, crashing the company's website within minutes. Social media platforms were flooded with posts about the jewelry, and fashion influencers rushed to review it.

Evelyn's phone buzzed incessantly with collaboration requests. Even her long-forgotten early works were suddenly unearthed and discussed enthusiastically by netizens.

Ding—

The vibration interrupted her pencil strokes on the design draft. A blot of ink spread across the paper as she glanced at the caller ID.

"Alex?"

"Mom and Dad miss you," Alexander Roland's voice came through the phone. "I'm downstairs."

By the time the black Maybach rolled over fallen leaves into the underground garage, Evelyn was tucking the seventh draft into her drawer. The elevator descended to F3, and when she opened the car door, the familiar scent of cedar enveloped her.

Headlights cut through the twilight as the car approached the villa. Two figures stood under the porch light, waiting eagerly.

"Evelyn!" Sophia Roland hurried forward, her silver-streaked hair fluttering in the breeze. Edward Roland waited on the steps, holding a steaming soup pot that fogged up his glasses.

Evelyn's nose stung unexpectedly.

"I promise," she said, gripping her mother's wrinkled hands tightly. "I'll visit every week from now on."

Sophia's eyes brightened. "You'd better mean it!" The elderly couple flanked her as they walked inside, shielding her like a treasure they'd finally recovered.

Under the dining room chandelier, their three shadows stretched across the floor-to-ceiling windows—warm enough to make her heart ache.

###Chapter 56

Isabella Langley descended the spiral staircase in stilettos, her fingertips grazing the carved banister. The living room buzzed with laughter as she lingered in the shadows, nails digging crescent moons into her palms.

"Little sister came home today?" Her practiced smile dripped honey as she spoke.

Evelyn Roland glanced up, lips curved in perfect politeness. The entire Roland family doted on her—except this stepsister whose eyes hid daggers.

Crystal chandeliers bathed the dining room in golden light. Sophia Roland piled Evelyn's plate with food until it resembled a miniature mountain.

"Mom, that's enough." Evelyn gently stopped her mother's hand.

"Look how sharp your chin has gotten." Sophia caressed her daughter's cheek. "Have you been staying up late again?"

Alexander Roland set down his spoon with a metallic clink. "Listen to your mother."

"Okay." Evelyn lowered her head over her rice bowl, strands of hair veiling her flushed earlobes.

Edward Roland tapped his wineglass. "I heard the Shattered Stars Collection sold out?"

"Just got the report from marketing." Alexander's crow's feet deepened with pride. "Three hundred percent year-over-year growth."

"Just luck." Evelyn's lashes cast delicate shadows as she demurred.

Sophia squeezed her daughter's hand. "Our Evelyn has always—"

Clatter. Isabella's chopsticks hit the porcelain plate. She bent to retrieve them, her expression twisting behind the curtain of her hair. One day, she'd make them all kneel before her.

——

On the penthouse floor of Valdemar Tower, fountain pen ink bloomed across gilded stationery. Sebastian Valdemar signed his name with finality before pressing the intercom.

"Theodore."

His assistant entered to find the CEO adjusting his cufflinks.

"Deliver this personally to Designer Roland." Sebastian extended the envelope.

The wax seal gleamed ominously under the lights. Theodore's pupils contracted—this was Valdemar Group's highest-tier invitation.

"Any message to convey?"

"Unnecessary." Sebastian turned toward the floor-to-ceiling windows, his reflection smirking back from the glass. "She'll come."
###Chapter 57

Theodore Ashcroft straightened his tie as he stood before the KL Design Group headquarters. He pulled out his phone to double-check the floor number Evelyn Roland had sent him.

The elevator doors slid open, revealing Evelyn in a beige pantsuit, her hair pulled into a sleek bun.

"Ms. Roland." Theodore stepped forward.

Evelyn paused mid-step, her gaze dropping to the gilded envelope in his hand.

"From Mr. Valdemar." Theodore presented the invitation with deference. "For the Shattered Stars Collection gala."

Her fingers traced the embossed lettering as she accepted it. The motion brought back the memory of Sebastian Valdemar's fathomless eyes in the elevator that day.

"Please thank Mr. Valdemar for me." She tucked the envelope into her briefcase. "But I won't be attending."

Theodore blinked. In his years delivering Sebastian's invitations, he'd never seen a woman decline one.

Evelyn was already turning toward the elevator. Her posture remained ramrod straight as her heels clicked against the marble floor.

Back at her design department workstation, Evelyn had barely sat down when her colleague Penelope leaned in.

"Was that Theodore Ashcroft from Valdemar Group downstairs?" Penelope whispered. "I saw him hand you something."

Evelyn slid the invitation into her desk drawer. "Just work correspondence."

"Let me see!" Penelope snatched the envelope before Evelyn could stop her. "Oh my God! The Shattered Stars gala!"

The office erupted into chatter. Several female coworkers clustered around, voices overlapping.

"They only invite top clients and partners!"
"You're so lucky, Evelyn!"
"Can you get us in too?"

Evelyn massaged her temples. Sebastian's scrutinizing gaze flashed through her mind, stirring an inexplicable irritation.

"Sorry, I have prior commitments." She shut the drawer with a decisive click.

Meanwhile, in the Valdemar Group executive suite...

Theodore stood before Sebastian's desk, a sheen of sweat on his brow as he relayed Evelyn's refusal.

Sebastian's fountain pen stilled mid-signature, leaving an ink blot on the document.

"Her exact words?"

"Ms. Roland said...she appreciated the gesture but had other plans." Theodore chose his words carefully.

Sebastian chuckled darkly. He set down the pen and picked up the intercom.

"Connect me to Department Three at KL Design."

When the line clicked open, his voice brooked no argument: "Adrienne, I require your entire design team's presence at tomorrow's Shattered Stars launch."

Hanging up, Sebastian turned to the floor-to-ceiling windows. The setting sun gilded the cityscape, reflecting his faint smirk in the glass.

###Chapter 58 

The phone rang, and Sebastian Valdemar's voice came through the receiver, deep and restrained.

"Valdemar Group is hosting the Shattered Stars Collection launch tomorrow night. Top designers in the industry will be there."

He paused, fingers lightly tapping the desk.

"I've already sent an invitation to Evelyn Roland from the design department."

Adrienne Klein tightened her grip on the phone. She caught the implication—the CEO was clearly hinting for Evelyn to attend.

"Don't worry, Mr. Valdemar. I'll handle it."

After hanging up, Adrienne immediately dialed the internal line. Within five minutes, Evelyn stood before her desk.

"Did you receive the invitation from Valdemar Group?"

Evelyn's lashes fluttered slightly as she nodded.

"You must attend tomorrow night," Adrienne said firmly. "It's a prime opportunity to network with industry leaders."

Evelyn pressed her lips together. She despised these superficial social events, but she had no choice. "Understood, Director."

News spread like wildfire through the design department.

In the break room, Isabella Langley crushed her paper cup in her hand. She glared at the news image of Valdemar Group on her screen, nails digging into her palm.

Why Evelyn again?

The sharp click of her heels echoed on the marble floor as she stormed into the CEO's office without knocking.

"Brother!"

Alexander Roland looked up from his documents, brows furrowed. "This is a workplace."

"Mr. Roland," Isabella corrected, though her tone remained defiant. "I want to attend Valdemar's event tomorrow night."

"Reason?"

"To learn!" She crossed her arms. "With so many master designers present, shouldn't I seize the chance to gain insights?"

Alexander closed the folder, his gaze sharp behind his glasses. He knew his sister too well.

"The invitations have already been sent."

"Then get another one!" She slammed her hands on his desk. "I'm a Langley heiress. Are you saying I can't even attend a gala?"

The air in the office turned icy.
###Chapter 59

"Suddenly interested in business galas?" Alexander Roland tapped the desk with slender fingers, understanding flashing in his eyes.

He knew his childhood companion too well.

Isabella Langley's ears turned pink. She abandoned pretense. "I want to learn from experienced professionals..."

"And see Sebastian Valdemar?" Alexander cut straight to the point.

The girl's lashes fluttered. A blush spread from her cheeks down her slender neck.

The man chuckled, retrieving a gilded invitation from his drawer. "Valdemar Group's invitation. Exactly what you wanted."

"Thank you, brother!" Isabella accepted it with trembling fingers, her excitement barely contained.

She traced the invitation's edge with determination. What was Evelyn Roland to her? She always got what she wanted.

The gala glittered under crystal chandeliers. Champagne flutes clinked amidst perfumed guests in evening wear.

Evelyn arrived hurriedly, still wearing her white work suit. Her dark hair was pulled into a sleek updo, standing out among the jeweled crowd.

"Miss Roland, your speech." Theodore Ashcroft materialized beside her.

"Speech?" She frowned.

"Last-minute addition." Theodore lowered his voice. "You're leading the Shattered Stars project."

Evelyn's gaze cut through the crowd, locking onto Sebastian's. The man stood where light and shadow met, his lips curved in a faint smirk.

His eyes clearly said: You can't escape.

"Mr. Valdemar insists you prioritize the company's interests," Theodore added.

Her knuckles whitened around the papers. "Understood."

As she turned, red wine splashed across her pristine white jacket. The stain bloomed like blood.

"Oh dear, how clumsy!" The waitress feigned shock, triumph gleaming in her eyes.

Evelyn's lips curled coldly. Such an amateurish performance.
###Chapter 60

Evelyn Roland's fingertips lightly brushed over the wine-stained hem of her dress, a cold smirk playing on her lips.

She lifted her gaze, scanning the crowd until her eyes landed on a familiar face—one adorned with flawless makeup.

Isabella Langley stood nearby, champagne flute in hand, her eyes gleaming with malicious delight.

"My apologies, miss..." The waiter's trembling hand offered her a napkin.

Evelyn accepted it, dabbing at the stain with deliberate slowness. The red wine had spread across the pale fabric like an ugly, blooming flower.

"Evelyn, how careless of you," Isabella cooed, her voice dripping with false sweetness as she approached. "You're about to give your speech, too."

Her nails dug into her palms.

How dare this country bumpkin get the chance to speak at the Valdemar event? Just because of that fluke "Shattered Stars" design?

Evelyn didn't even spare her a glance, striding straight toward the restroom.

Across the ballroom, Theodore Ashcroft leaned in. "Mr. Valdemar, Miss Roland's dress—"

"Send the spare," Sebastian Valdemar replied, his gaze fixed on Evelyn's retreating figure.

The restroom lights were harsh and unforgiving.

Evelyn frowned at her reflection. The wine had seeped deep into the fabric, leaving a sprawling stain at her waist.

"Miss Roland?" A female manager knocked before entering, holding an elegant box. "From Mr. Valdemar."

Inside lay a pink fringed gown, its waistline adorned with dazzling diamonds that caught the light.

After a brief hesitation, she changed into it.

The transformation was instant. The fringes swayed with her movements, the diamonds scattering light like stars. The dress hugged her curves perfectly—most surprisingly, it concealed the scar at her waist.

When she reentered the ballroom, Sebastian stood at the entrance.

His gaze lingered.

"It suits you," he murmured, his voice low.

Evelyn tucked a loose strand of hair behind her ear, her expression calm. "Thank you. Though if not for that speech, I'd rather leave now."

Sebastian arched a brow but said nothing. His eyes never left her.
###Chapter 61

The grand ballroom doors swung open slowly.

Sebastian Valdemar extended his right arm slightly, his gaze signaling Evelyn Roland.

After a brief hesitation, she rested her delicate fingers lightly on his forearm.

They entered the venue side by side, instantly becoming the center of attention.

Under the crystal chandeliers, Evelyn's champagne-colored gown shimmered brilliantly.

Alexander Roland turned from the front row, his pupils contracting.

He never imagined his long-lost sister could possess such grace.

Without any pretension, her every movement exuded aristocratic refinement.

That innate elegance couldn't be cultivated in ordinary households.

"Is that Mr. Valdemar's companion?"

"I heard she's the designer of Shattered Stars."

"My God, she's so young and beautiful!"

"They look absolutely perfect together."

The whispers reached Isabella Langley's ears.

Her knuckles turned white as she clenched her wine glass.

Jealousy burned in her eyes like wildfire.

Even after being drenched in wine, Evelyn still managed to shine.

"Bitch. Let's see how long your moment lasts."

She downed the entire glass, the alcohol burning her throat.

The host took the stage, announcing the official start of the event.

"Please welcome Mr. Sebastian Valdemar, CEO of Valdemar Group."

Sebastian ascended the podium with measured steps.

Taking the microphone, he went straight to the point.

"Tonight's true star is Ms. Evelyn Roland, designer of Shattered Stars."

Spotlights suddenly illuminated Evelyn.

She raised her glass gracefully, her smile perfectly poised.

At the microphone, she delivered her speech flawlessly.

Every word crisp, every syllable precise.

Even Theodore Ashcroft in the corner couldn't help being impressed.

"Thank you all for listening."

Evelyn curtsied elegantly, her skirt blooming like flower petals.

In the shadows, Isabella's nails dug deep into her palms.

"The real show is about to begin."

Suddenly, a chorus of phone notifications erupted.

[Breaking News: Shattered Stars Accused of Plagiarism!]

[Valdemar's New Designs Leaked!]

Within minutes, trending lists were flooded with related hashtags.

The atmosphere in the ballroom shifted instantly.

Alexander stared at his phone screen, brow furrowed.

His gaze through gold-rimmed glasses turned complex as he looked at Evelyn on stage.

He'd witnessed her talent firsthand.

Yet the current situation forced him to doubt.

Was this coincidence... or carefully orchestrated deception?
###Chapter 62

Sebastian Valdemar's fingers tapped lightly on the desk, his brow furrowed.

On the trending list, the hashtag #ShatteredStarsPlagiarism was climbing at an alarming rate, quickly reaching the top three.

"KL Group insider exposes Evelyn Roland's alleged design theft!"

The comments section exploded.

"I knew it. How could a rookie create something so stunning?"

"Valdemar Group is finished. Their stocks will plummet."

"Plagiarists should be banned from the design industry!"

Isabella Langley stood in the corner, a cold smirk playing on her lips. Watching the flood of hateful comments on her phone, she felt a surge of satisfaction.

"Ms. Roland, how do you respond to the plagiarism allegations?" A reporter suddenly shoved a microphone in Evelyn's face.

The camera flashes were blinding.

Sebastian moved to intervene, but Evelyn gently stopped him. Her expression remained calm, as if she were merely an observer.

"Mr. Valdemar, should PR handle this?" Theodore Ashcroft whispered urgently.

Sebastian shook his head. "Wait."

Just then, commotion erupted at the entrance.

The crowd parted like the Red Sea.

"It's Master Edmund Grandelle!"

The white-haired elder strode forward, his sharp gaze fixed on the Shattered Stars display.

"This design is from my sketchbook twenty years ago." His quiet voice silenced the room.

Reporters snapped photos frantically.

Isabella nearly laughed aloud. Feigning concern, she approached Evelyn. "Little sister, it's not too late to apologize—"

Evelyn's icy glare made her instinctively step back.

"Master Grandelle," Evelyn said evenly, "are you certain this is your work?"

The old man stroked his beard, adopting a sorrowful expression. "Taking shortcuts is understandable, but plagiarism is despicable."

Boos erupted from the audience.

Sebastian's face darkened. Before he could speak, Evelyn suddenly smiled.

That smile sent an inexplicable chill down Grandelle's spine.

"Since you claim this is your sketch," Evelyn pulled a flash drive from her bag, "shall we review the surveillance footage?"

Grandelle froze.

Every camera lens swiveled toward the tiny device.

Isabella's heart plummeted. Her nails dug into her palms as she stared at the flash drive.
###Chapter 63

Isabella Langley stood beside Evelyn Roland, her face etched with concern as she affectionately looped an arm through hers.

"If I’m accused of plagiarism, shouldn’t there be proof?"
###Chapter 64

Sebastian watched silently, his expression unreadable. Only now did he understand—Evelyn hadn't been desperately salvaging valuables, but cherished mementos of a loved one.

Vincent and Margaret Lowell rushed in, followed by flustered servants who helped Victoria up. She shrieked hysterically, "Call the police! Now!"

Sirens wailed outside moments later. The officers hesitated when they saw the slender young woman before them. "You're under arrest for assault. Come with us."

Evelyn nodded calmly and stepped into the patrol car.

At the station, Victoria refused any settlement. But soon, the Lowells delivered a Letter of Forgiveness—too afraid of Sebastian to escalate matters.

"Call your family to arrange bail," an officer said, handing her the phone.

Evelyn held the receiver with chilled fingers. She didn't want to involve the Rolands, and hesitated over whether to call Dylan Orlando.

"I'll post her bail."

A deep voice spoke from the doorway. Sebastian stood there, accompanied by a sharply dressed lawyer.

"From this moment," the attorney said smoothly, presenting his card, "I represent Miss Roland in all legal matters."
###Chapter 78

Evelyn Roland was led into a quiet reception room. Sebastian Valdemar leaned against the window, an unlit cigarette between his fingers.

Silence stretched between them.

Three hours later, a lawyer entered and nodded at Sebastian. "Mr. Valdemar, all the paperwork is complete."

Evelyn tightened her grip on her bag strap. She hadn’t expected Sebastian to be the one to help her in the end.

"Thank you."

It was the second time today she’d thanked this man. The first was when he’d rushed into the burning building to save those priceless paintings.

Sebastian lifted his gaze, his voice low. "No need. Valdemar Group shares responsibility for this."

His eyes flickered over the scrapes on her arm. Suddenly, he suggested, "Get a medical checkup."

There was something probing in those deep eyes. He needed to confirm—confirm the hazy memories from that night at the hotel, confirm the faint crescent-shaped mark on her waist.

Last time, he hadn’t gotten a clear look. But this woman felt unnervingly familiar.

Evelyn tucked a loose strand of hair behind her ear and declined politely. "It’s just a minor injury."

Sebastian arched a brow, his tone turning firm. "The Shattered Stars Collection enters its critical phase next week."

He deliberately slowed his words. "I can’t afford any delays caused by unforeseen circumstances."

The excuse was flawless, leaving no room for argument.

Under normal circumstances, Evelyn would have complied. But all she could think of now was Victoria Lowell’s pale face.

"Mr. Valdemar, my health—"

"KL and Valdemar Group have had a fruitful partnership," Sebastian interrupted, tapping the desk lightly. "To ensure everything goes smoothly, this checkup is necessary, don’t you think?"

His voice was calm, but the underlying authority was unmistakable.

Evelyn’s lashes fluttered. Finally, she forced a professional smile. "Fine. Let’s get it done."

A flicker of triumph crossed Sebastian’s eyes as he pulled out his car keys. "We’re going now."

The car was so quiet she could hear their breathing. Evelyn stared at the passing scenery, desperate for this absurd examination to end.

The moment the black sedan stopped, she pushed the door open. "Mr. Valdemar, I can handle this alone. You’ve already done enough today."

Sebastian stepped out leisurely. "It’s no trouble. Valdemar Group prioritizes the well-being of our partners."

The nurse at the station seemed prepared, greeting them warmly. "Mr. Valdemar, Miss Roland, please follow me."

For the next two hours, Evelyn was subjected to a full-body examination. Blood tests, CT scans, MRIs… She felt like a fish on a chopping block.
###Chapter 79

The corridor lights stretched Evelyn Roland's shadow into a long silhouette.

She stood outside the examination room, fingers unconsciously tightening around her purse strap. Every word of Sebastian Valdemar's conversation with the nurse had reached her ears.

"Mr. Valdemar, Miss Roland indeed has no birthmark on her waist," the nurse's voice carried clearly.

Sebastian's brow furrowed almost imperceptibly.

A cold smile curled Evelyn's lips. She shoved the door open violently, the metal handle banging against the wall with a sharp crack.

"Does this amuse you, Mr. Valdemar?" Her voice dripped with ice.

Sebastian turned to face her furious gaze. He opened his mouth, but she cut him off.

"I'm not the person you're looking for." Evelyn took a deep breath. "Stop playing these ridiculous games."

Her stilettos clicked sharply against the tiled floor as she walked away. Sebastian watched her retreating figure, the doubt in his eyes gradually fading.

Night had deepened.

The grandfather clock chimed eleven times as Evelyn pushed open the front door. She tiptoed inside, careful not to wake the household.

The crystal chandelier suddenly blazed to life with a snap.

"Evelyn?" Sophia Roland's voice floated down the staircase.

Evelyn quickly hid her injured wrist behind her back. But Sophia had already descended, grabbing her arm with trembling hands.

"What happened?" Sophia's voice shook.

Edward Roland followed, his brow furrowed. "Did someone hurt you?"

Footsteps sounded from the second floor. Isabella Langley appeared in her robe, wearing perfectly measured concern. "Oh my, how did you get hurt?"

She reached for Evelyn's wound, only to be deftly avoided.

"Just a scratch from working late," Evelyn said lightly.

A shadow flickered through Isabella's eyes before she linked arms with Sophia. "Mother, don't worry. Our capable Evelyn can take care of herself."

But Sophia's eyes reddened. "Why won't you tell us when something's wrong?"

Evelyn gazed at their concerned faces, warmth rising in her chest. Yet she knew—some truths weren't ready to be revealed.
###Chapter 80

Isabella Langley approached with a teacup in hand, her face adorned with a saccharine smile.

"Evelyn, I heard you were injured. Are you alright?" Her doe-like eyes glistened, her voice dripping with honeyed concern.

I suppressed the urge to grimace.

At that banquet, it was those very same innocent-looking eyes that had discreetly signaled the waiter to spill red wine on me.

"Thank you for your concern. It's nothing serious." My tone was icy as I averted my gaze and took a sip of tea.

The warmth of the tea did nothing to thaw the chill in my heart.

The entire Roland family adored this seemingly angelic girl. Only I saw through the schemes hidden beneath her sweet smile.

Exposing her now would only backfire.

"Evelyn, are you really okay?" Sophia Roland reached for my hand, her brow furrowed with worry. "Should we take you to the hospital for another check-up?"

I shook my head gently. "It's already been treated. The doctor said it's just a superficial wound."

Alexander Roland abruptly set down his newspaper. "How did you get hurt?"

The air in the living room instantly grew heavy.

Lowering my lashes, I recounted the incident briefly. When mentioning the fire, I deliberately downplayed my actions.

"You ran into a burning building?" Alexander's voice sharpened.

Sophia gasped, exchanging a stunned glance with Edward Roland.

"The artworks were saved," I quickly added. "I couldn't let Charles Lowell's life's work be destroyed."

At the mention of Charles, my throat tightened. That kind old man, even on his deathbed, had fretted over seeing me married.

"We'll prepare the east room tomorrow," Sophia said, patting my hand. "It'll be dedicated to storing your artworks."

I nodded gratefully before remembering something. "Do you know any professional art restoration experts?"

Alexander frowned. "How many pieces were damaged?"

"Not many, but they need specialized treatment."

Edward suddenly stood. "I know Professor Li from the Metropolitan Museum. I'll contact him tomorrow."

Watching my family bustling about for me, warmth blossomed in my chest.

This hard-won familial love—I would cherish it dearly.

As for Isabella... My lips curved slightly as I caught sight of her clenched fist hidden beneath her skirt.

The fox's tail would reveal itself eventually.
###Chapter 81

Alexander Roland's heart ached as he took in Evelyn Roland's pale complexion. He gently grasped her hand, his voice firm. "Leave the artwork restoration to me. I've already contacted the top expert team in the country."

Evelyn gave a slight nod, her eyes growing warm with unshed tears.

For the first time, she realized that aside from Isabella Langley, the entire Roland family treated her as one of their own. This unconditional protection left her feeling overwhelmed.

Perhaps... she could try lowering her guard and learning to rely on these people who genuinely cared for her.

The next morning.

In Edward Roland's office, documents were signed in rapid succession. His expression was icy as he issued orders. "Terminate all collaborative projects with the Lowell family immediately. Notify all our partners—anyone who continues dealings with the Lowells will be considered an enemy of the Roland family."

Within half a day, Lowell Group's stock price hit the limit-down three times.

By the tenth canceled partnership call, Vincent Lowell could no longer remain seated. He slammed his phone down, beads of cold sweat forming on his forehead. "What the hell is going on? Why would the Rolands suddenly target us?"

Margaret Hill rushed in, her high heels clicking frantically against the floor. "Vincent, the board is in complete chaos!"

"I know!" He yanked at his tie irritably. "It's the Rolands pulling the strings behind this."

"When did we ever offend the Rolands?" Margaret's face drained of color. "They're the kind of family that can make the entire business world tremble with a single step!"

Vincent froze. He recalled Victoria's smug expression when she returned home yesterday—and the name she'd mentioned. Evelyn Roland.

"Don't tell me..." His voice shook. "That Evelyn has ties to the Roland family?"

The thought sent a chill down his spine. If true, the Lowell family might not survive this blow.

He immediately dialed his assistant. "Find out everything about Evelyn Roland's connection to the Rolands. Now!"

After hanging up, his hands still trembled. Margaret gripped his arm. "You think that little bitch is behind this?"

"I hope not." Vincent's eyes darkened. "Otherwise..."

He left the sentence unfinished, but they both understood the gravity of the situation.

The entire afternoon passed in oppressive silence at the Lowell estate. Every ring of the phone felt like a death knell, stretching their nerves to the breaking point.

When the assistant's call finally came, Vincent almost couldn't bring himself to answer.
###Chapter 82

Vincent Lowell stood by the floor-to-ceiling window, cigarette ash crumbling from his fingertips.

The cityscape stretched before him, its bustling traffic mirrored in the storm brewing behind his eyes.

Going head-to-head with the Roland family would be suicide.

But if it came to that...

"Done."

Evelyn smiled.

L might be greedy, but he was efficient.

Most importantly—with enough money, he could make the dead walk.

She closed the file, a glint of steel in her gaze.

If the Lowells wanted dirt, she'd give them an avalanche.
###Chapter 83

Evelyn Roland set down her phone, her fingers flying across the keyboard.

Dylan Orlando's efficiency had always been reliable.

###Chapter 84: Undercurrents

She wasn't some fragile flower needing parental protection.

###Chapter 85

KL Design Group Headquarters.

Evelyn's fingers turned cold at the memory of being locked in that room. She wasn't one to hold grudges, but she wouldn't easily trust someone who'd schemed against her.

###Chapter 86

###Chapter 106

"Useless boy!" Sophia turned and jabbed Alexander's forehead. "Can't even protect your sister, despite your size!"

Her chest heaved at the thought of her daughter's suffering.

In the corner, Isabella Langley dug her nails into her palms until they left crescent marks. Since Evelyn's return, the family's attention had been completely stolen.

Their eyes were only for their biological daughter. Where did that leave her, the adopted one? If this continued, there'd be no place for her in the Roland family.

"Evelyn," Edward suddenly proposed, "how about you take over KL?"

"What?"

The siblings spoke in unison, clearly stunned by the suggestion.

Isabella nearly ground her teeth to dust. After all these years in the Roland household, she'd never even set foot in KL. How could Evelyn waltz in and take over the family business?

"No." Evelyn refused firmly. "CH is at a critical stage. I don't have the bandwidth for anything else."

She paused, then added, "Besides, Alexander manages it perfectly."

Sophia took her daughter's hand gently. "We'll support whatever you want to do."

Even if Evelyn asked for the stars, the Rolands would find a way to build a rocket.

"Of course, let Isabella gain some experience." Sophia agreed readily—after all, she was also her daughter.

"Oh," Edward remembered something. "Evelyn, would you like to go back to school?"

During her years with the Lowells, Evelyn hadn't even completed junior college—a lingering regret.

Evelyn's eyes lit up. Campus life would provide both cover and ample free time. Perfect.

"Okay." She agreed immediately.

With the Rolands' connections, Stanford University admission was secured within three days—a tier above Isabella's alma mater.
###Chapter 107

Morning sunlight streamed through the gap in the curtains.

Evelyn Roland stood before the full-length mirror, tucking the last strand of hair behind her ear. The pale blue dress hugged her slender waist, making her skin glow like porcelain.

Sebastian Valdemar.

The room erupted in murmurs. It was the first time Professor Valdemar had ever called on a tardy student.

A girl beside her slid a textbook over. Evelyn glanced at it and shook her head.

"First, establish an accurate user persona." She rose, her tone measured. "Then analyze consumption scenarios..."

As she articulated her points with precision, the classroom gradually fell silent.

A flicker of surprise crossed Sebastian's eyes. He hadn't expected such sharp business acumen from this seemingly ornamental girl.

"Well answered." His fingers tapped the lectern. "Now, what solutions would you propose for stagnant inventory?"

Each question grew more challenging.

Evelyn met his probing gaze, her red lips parting.

In the hallway, Evelyn exhaled in relief.

"Evelyn?"

A familiar voice made her head snap up.
###Chapter 109

Evelyn's gaze lingered briefly on Victoria's abdomen, her lips curling in derision. As a medical student, she saw through the lie instantly—the taut stomach, heavy perfume, and those precarious heels all betrayed the pathetic ruse.

It seemed the Lowells were truly desperate, resorting to such cheap tricks.
###Chapter 110

The Lowells' days of prosperity were numbered.

Since Victoria had delivered herself to Evelyn's doorstep, she shouldn't blame Evelyn for showing no mercy.

This performance was only just beginning.
###Chapter 111

###Chapter 112

That kind of obsession couldn’t just disappear.

###Chapter 113

This wasn't concern—it was a power play.

Harvard MBA?

Evelyn recalled the institution's massive accreditation scandal three years prior. With Isabella's mediocre intellect, that degree undoubtedly came courtesy of family connections.

Colorado Mines?

Evelyn's eyes sharpened.

Before taking over CH Jewelry, she'd meticulously analyzed mineral distributions. Those eastern deposits were nearly exhausted, with recent seismic activity making them accident-prone. Any investment there would hemorrhage money.

Despite everything, she offered a warning: "That's a poor investment choice."

Isabella's derisive snort filled the car.

###Chapter 114

Though skeptical, Nathan grew more convinced. A smug smile spread across his face.

Initially, he'd pursued Evelyn only because she was Celadon. But Isabella was the real deal—a genuine Roland heiress, far more worthy of his efforts.

"Just wait, Isabella!" Nathan vowed silently, already plotting his next move.

A sharp pain shot through his head. He grimaced, his expression darkening. "Evelyn Roland, once I win Isabella over, we'll see who's laughing then."

"Celadon? Just some nobody designer. Against the Rolands, you're nothing."

He could already picture Evelyn begging for mercy. During his recovery, he instructed his mother to prepare gifts for his grand romantic gesture.

Three days later, in the KL Design Group CEO's office...

Alexander Roland's slender fingers tapped the desk as he studied the design sketches. He picked up his phone and dialed his sister.

"I'm working on my designs. What is it?" Evelyn's voice came through.

"The new collection's blueprints feel incomplete. Could you come take a look?"

Alexander got straight to the point. He knew Evelyn was busy with her graduation project.

Evelyn glanced at her half-finished sketches. "Fine. I'll head over now."

"I'll have Benjamin meet you downstairs."

After hanging up, Evelyn packed her tools and rushed out. The journey from Stanford to KL Design spanned half the city.

When she arrived, a crowd had gathered outside KL Tower. Instinctively, she tensed—until a familiar voice pierced through the noise:

"Isabella, I love you! Be my girlfriend!"

Nathan's public declaration echoed clearly. Frozen in place, Evelyn found her feet moving toward the commotion against her will.
###Chapter 121

Evelyn Roland had just stepped into KL Design Group when a commotion caught her attention.

At the center of the crowd, Nathan Evans knelt on one knee, holding a bouquet of roses, his face filled with exaggerated devotion. Opposite him stood Isabella Langley, her flawless makeup unable to mask her ashen expression.

"Isabella, from the moment we first met—"

"Shut up!" Isabella snapped, her nails digging into her palms.

This was supposed to be her carefully orchestrated scheme to humiliate Evelyn in public. Instead, this idiot Nathan had turned the tables on her.

Whispers rippled through the crowd. Forcing a strained smile, Isabella hissed, "Nathan, you've mistaken me for someone else."

"No!" He lunged forward desperately. "Those were all misunderstandings—you're the only one in my heart!"

Isabella stumbled back, nearly twisting her ankle in her heels. Then she spotted Evelyn at the edge of the crowd—the mocking smirk on her lips made Isabella's blood run cold.

"Nathan Evans!" She finally shed her facade. "Security! Drag this lunatic out!"

Gasps erupted. The usually demure Langley heiress now looked like a spitting, feral cat.

Two guards rushed forward to restrain Nathan. He thrashed. "Isabella, how could you? We were—"

"Silence!" She snatched the roses from his hands and smashed them to the ground. "You think you're worthy of me?"

As petals scattered, she leaned in and whispered a single venomous word only he could hear: "Pathetic."

The guards promptly gagged him and hauled him away. The crowd parted like the Red Sea, watching the spectacle's lead actor get tossed out the doors.

Evelyn turned to leave—until a sickeningly sweet voice called out: "Evelyn, darling~"

Isabella scurried over, linking arms with her, all traces of hysteria erased. "You should've told me you were coming!"

Her smile was flawless again, as if the shrieking harpy from moments ago had never existed.
###Chapter 122

Evelyn Roland subtly sidestepped, her long lashes casting delicate shadows beneath her eyes.

"My apologies for you witnessing such a scene."

"There's truly nothing between us. If you still have feelings for him—"

"When he was hospitalized after my birthday gala, I only visited out of courtesy. I never expected him to misinterpret it."

Isabella Langley deliberately raised her voice, ensuring every passing employee could hear. She needed to salvage her dignity and shift the blame for this farce entirely onto Nathan Evans.

The onlookers exchanged knowing glances, quickly offering their sympathy.

"Don't take it to heart, Manager Langley. That kind of delusional man is revolting."

"Benjamin, let's go."

The assistant glanced at Isabella behind her and nodded silently.

The elevator doors closed, and Isabella's smile twisted into something venomous.

"Just you wait, Evelyn Roland." Her fists clenched, nails digging crescent moons into her palms.

In the office, Alexander Roland retrieved design blueprints from the safe.

"KL's new collection. Take a look."

Evelyn accepted the sketches, her fingertips tracing the paper thoughtfully.

"The proportions here could be adjusted to better accentuate the wearer's elegance."

"This design is too conservative. It needs a more avant-garde approach."

Her critiques were precise and methodical. Alexander's eyes lit up with admiration.

"Truly worthy of the Celadon title." His praise was genuine. "These suggestions are impeccable."
###Chapter 123

Alexander Roland gazed at his long-lost sister with admiration shimmering in his eyes. He hadn't expected Evelyn Roland to possess such unique insights in design.

His slender fingers rolled up the blueprint as he casually poured her a glass of warm water.

"The design team will revise according to your suggestions." A faint smile touched Alexander's lips. "How's Stanford treating you?"

"It's fine." Evelyn accepted the glass, her fingertips absently tracing its rim.

His brotherly concern still felt unfamiliar. The glass clinked sharply against the table as she set it down abruptly.

"Don't touch that mining project in Colorado." Her gaze locked with his. "I can't explain why now, but steer clear of it."

She knew Isabella Langley was overseeing that venture. Since reasoning with Isabella proved futile, cutting it off at the source was the only solution.

"I should return to campus." Evelyn rose, still unaccustomed to familial interactions.

After seeing his sister out, Alexander promptly issued Isabella's suspension notice.

Meanwhile, Isabella was trashing her office in a rage. The notification made her tremble violently, nails digging crescent moons into her palms.

"Since when does he take orders from her?" She ground her teeth. "This project will happen—no matter what!"

Her trailing words twisted Sophia's heart.

###Chapter 124

"My father treated me well, but his kindness always felt... off."

Though court had been suspended today, he should return to the palace soon—lest his grandfather worry.

......

Clutching the returned deposit, Alina hurried toward Westminster Abbey.

She'd prepared excuses for Marco Lombardi, unaware the entire envoy now languished in prison.

Henry knew little of the Khmer Empire.

This kingdom, called Angkor by its people, was known elsewhere as the Khmer Empire.

Though well-read, his knowledge came only from Ministry of Rites reports.

He immediately summoned Minister Xavier Valence.

"Your Highness." The minister bowed.

"At ease. Be seated."

The minister stole a glance at the prince, wondering if he'd taken interest in the princess.

Little did he know Henry had already claimed the Khmer princess the night before.

"How fares their nation now?"

As Xavier elaborated, Henry grasped the situation.

The once-mighty Angkor, after six centuries, now teetered on collapse.

That their Crown Prince relied on marriage alliances revealed how far the empire had fallen.

......

Alina stood panic-stricken before Westminster Abbey.

Inquiries revealed Marco had been arrested by the Embroidered Uniform Guard—that dreaded agency few entered alive.

Yet she knew nothing about him beyond his surname.

###Chapter 125

The surveillance footage spread like wildfire across the internet. Though swiftly deleted, the damage was already done.

###Chapter 126

Sunlight streamed through the carved window lattice, casting intricate patterns across the hall. Evelyn Roland squinted slightly—the scene felt eerily familiar. Half a year ago, she'd stood in this very spot after catching Vincent Lowell with Isabella Langley.

According to the original plot, she should've been the adored wife. But the author's last-minute revisions had turned her into a doormat.

The porcelain trembled in the Dowager's grip. Evelyn noted the whitened knuckles clutching the armrest.

Evelyn eyed this mama's boy. In the original story, she'd mistaken his obedience for virtue. What blindness.

Vincent's face purpled like a strangled rooster.

The Dowager massaged her temples. "Men taking concubines is natural. Vincent waited three years to bring Isabella home—that was consideration."

The gaslighting was textbook. Her former CEO had used identical tactics—blame the employee, never the company.

The Dowager's eyes gleamed. Vincent jutted his chin. "Beg the Emperor's pardon, and I'll forgive this folly."

"Perjury?" Evelyn clutched imaginary pearls. "How thoughtful—inheriting my dowry requires my execution first."

The Dowager's sleeve twitched. Bullseye.

Perfumed air announced Isabella's entrance. "Please don't blame Sister!" She fluttered in, tear-stained. "This is all my fault—"

Evelyn smirked. The scripted lines, the dramatic timing—what a consummate White Lotus.
###Chapter 127

The sky darkened ominously, the clouds hanging oppressively low. Evelyn Roland gripped the steering wheel, flooring the accelerator as she sped toward the eastern suburbs.

Raindrops began pelting the windshield.

"Isabella, what are you trying to do...?" She bit her lower lip, her fingers turning white. She couldn't risk alarming her parents—she had to handle this alone.

Two black sedans closed in like phantoms.

But her own vehicle had reached its limit.

He stepped closer abruptly, his icy aura pressing in. "You'd risk your life for the Colorado Mines project? What's your real connection to the Rolands?"

Raindrops traced the sharp line of his jaw.

Her heartbeat stuttered, but she lifted her chin. "Alexander Roland saved my life. That's all."

"Is that so?" His eyes narrowed.

"What else would it be?" She met his gaze head-on, a faint smile playing on her lips. "What do you suspect, Mr. Valdemar?"

The rain softened, but the tension between them crackled like live wires.
###Chapter 128

Sebastian Valdemar took a step back and turned toward the black sedan parked by the roadside.

Evelyn Roland gave a slight nod and quickly followed. The Rolls-Royce's engine rumbled low before vanishing into the night.

At the Colorado Mines.

###Chapter 129

Through the rain, Evelyn watched the groaning operatives, slowly wiping blood from her cheek. Distant sirens wove with the miners' angry shouts—a long-delayed reckoning approaching.
###Chapter 130

###Chapter  131

The mine shaft was damp and cold. Sebastian Valdemar leaned against the rocky wall, his labored breaths echoing in the silence.

"You even know about mines?" His voice was low. "Seems I've underestimated you."

Evelyn Roland didn't respond. She turned and lit a few still-functional oil lamps. The dim glow pushed back the darkness, revealing the glint of a dagger embedded in his arm.

Blood had soaked through half his sleeve.

"Don't move." She pressed her fingers against his wrist, feeling the sticky warmth.

Sebastian smirked. "Not dying yet."

Evelyn frowned. In these conditions, infection was deadlier than blood loss.

She swiftly built a fire and sterilized a torn strip of cloth. The flames cast shadows over his clenched jaw.

"Brace yourself."

Before he could react, she yanked the blade free. Sebastian's muscles locked, his Adam's apple bobbing, but not a sound escaped him.

"Screaming helps."

As she bandaged the wound, she added a layer of chalcedony powder. Sebastian paled, his voice weak. "My sister was right. You do know medicine."

When she returned, Sebastian was in trouble.

His skin burned feverishly, his body convulsing. This wasn't ordinary illness—it was an old poison flaring up.

"Sebastian!" She pinned his thrashing arm. "Look at me!"

His eyes remained shut, his entire frame curled tight like a wounded beast. Cold sweat traced the sharp angles of his face, dripping onto Evelyn's hand.

It was worse than she'd thought.
###Chapter 132

"Pain..."

A low groan escaped Sebastian Valdemar's throat.

He had always endured suffering silently. Moments ago during the bone-scraping detoxification, he hadn't even flinched. Now he curled into himself, knuckles turning white.

Evelyn Roland stared at the veins bulging along his neck, her heart trembling.

This poison was terrifyingly potent.

To reduce such an iron-willed man to this state—she'd never witnessed such a vicious toxin before.

The blade glinted coldly in the firelight.

Without hesitation, she sliced open her own wrist.

As the first drop of blood fell, Sebastian's eyes flew open. Those crimson orbs locked onto her like a predator sighting prey.

"Drink." She pressed her wrist to his lips.

His fingers clamped around her arm with bruising force. As the warm liquid slid down his throat, the bloodlust gradually faded from his gaze.

This was her deepest secret.

At six years old, she'd discovered her blood could alleviate pain. Charles Lowell had rushed her to a martial arts school that very night, gripping her shoulders fiercely before leaving: "Take this secret to your grave."

Now for him, she'd broken that vow.

Sebastian's breathing steadied. Evelyn quickly bandaged her wound, the fabric darkening with blood.

"I'll get you out."

As she turned, she missed how his pupils contracted violently.

Rainwater had washed away the concealer on her waist.

The crescent birthmark shone clearly.

Sebastian's fingers trembled. That exact mark—he'd seen it on a woman's waist seven years ago during a rainstorm.

She'd been right under his nose all along.

His lips curved soundlessly.

A draft whispered through the mine shaft.

Evelyn counted her steps. At four hundred paces, her fingers brushed against a narrow crevice.

"Anyone there?" She knocked on the rock wall.

Frantic shouts answered from the other side: "Help! We're trapped!"

"Are you rescuers?"

Evelyn pressed against the gap. "Hold on! I'll get you out!"

Cheers erupted beyond the wall. As she prepared to respond, scorching heat suddenly pressed against her back.

Sebastian's breath ghosted over her ear: "Found you, little liar."
###Chapter 133

The cheers echoing through the mine shaft pierced Evelyn Roland's eardrums like needles.

Her fists clenched so tightly her nails dug into her palms.

"We're saved!"
"Finally going home!"

The workers' excited voices bounced off the narrow tunnel walls.

Evelyn's throat tightened.

How could she tell them the truth?

That those flashing police lights outside weren't for rescue—but to seal their fate?

That she was just as trapped as they were?

"I..."

She took a deep breath.

"Help is coming, but the passage is too narrow for equipment."

"Conserve your energy. We'll get out soon."

Muffled sobs rose from the darkness.

"Thank God...my daughter's waiting for me..."
"My wife's seven months pregnant. I can't die here..."

Evelyn bit her lower lip.

In desperate times, hope was more precious than oxygen.

"Stay put. Save your strength."

She grabbed a sharp rock and began sketching rapidly on the tunnel wall.

From the sounds, the trapped workers were in the adjacent shaft.

Mentally mapping the mine's layout based on her own path, she pinpointed their location.

Her fingers brushed damp soil. She rubbed it thoughtfully between them.

"Here."

She pointed to a spot on the wall.

"This is our way out."

Her legs trembled with exhaustion, but she couldn't stop.

Five lives.
And Sebastian Valdemar.

All depending on her.

"You can't climb that alone."

A hoarse male voice spoke behind her.

Evelyn whirled around.

Sebastian leaned against the wall, his face ghostly pale.

"You're awake?"

She hadn't expected him to regain consciousness so quickly.

Evelyn knew that.

But they had no other options.

"Together."

"Your injuries—"

Sebastian gave a grim smile. "Not fatal."

They moved through the tunnel until they reached the narrow opening.

Without hesitation, Sebastian dropped to one knee.

"Up."

Evelyn hesitated, eyeing his shaking arms.

"Keep waiting and we all die here."

His tone brooked no argument.

Gritting her teeth, she stepped onto his shoulders.

Sebastian surged upward with a pained grunt, his body swaying dangerously.

She felt his muscles tremble beneath her.

No turning back now.

Scrambling upward, her fingertips finally caught the ledge.

A heavy thud sounded below.

"Sebastian!"

She clung to the edge, peering down into darkness.

Silence.

Outside, the storm lashed the mining site, washing away all traces of crime.

"Evelyn! Over here!"

Dylan Orlando's shout cut through the rain.

Unable to reach Evelyn, he'd mobilized a team to the mines.
###Chapter 134

Dylan Orlando's pupils constricted sharply when he saw Evelyn Roland covered in blood. His knuckles turned white as he clenched his fists, hissing through gritted teeth, "Those animals!"

Outside the mine, several shadowy figures were furtively cleaning up the scene. Spotting Evelyn's escape, they immediately closed in.

"Boss, is it them?" Dylan's eyes burned with fury.

Behind him, a dozen well-trained bodyguards assumed offensive stances.

"Leave them." Evelyn pressed a hand on Dylan's shoulder.

The black-clad men retreated hastily at the shift in dynamics.

"The storm will trigger another collapse." Evelyn wiped rainwater from her face. "Find the signal jammer first. Contact rescue teams."

She directed the group to the trapped miners' location, digging a small opening to drop a walkie-talkie and glucose packets inside.

"Stay on comms. Conserve energy," she shouted into the hole.

Dylan's men began excavating an escape tunnel.

Evelyn turned and sprinted back to her original exit point, leaping into the collapsed mine shaft without hesitation.

Sebastian Valdemar curled in the darkness, his body burning with fever. Though the toxin's effects were temporarily suppressed, infection from his high temperature was eroding his consciousness.

"Cold..." he murmured deliriously, clutching Evelyn like a lifeline.

In his haze, he relived the sunless dungeon—the whippings, starvation, endless dark. Doctors had said he wouldn't survive past twenty.

"Don't be afraid." Evelyn wrapped her coat around him.

Sebastian stilled abruptly, like a child who'd found sanctuary.

"She's alive?" Her coffee cup shattered on the floor, brown liquid splattering everywhere.

Forcing composure, she ordered, "Eliminate the foreman. Find a scapegoat. I'm coming now."

News of the mining disaster had spread. Isabella knew distancing herself from the incident before her parents was now critical.

Changing into work clothes, she rushed to the Colorado Mines. Under public scrutiny, she plunged into the collapsed shaft without hesitation...

Sirens from rescue teams wailed across the mining site.

At the Roland estate, phones rang incessantly.

"Both daughters are unreachable?" Sophia Roland paled as she hung up.

Breaking news footage showed rescue workers carrying stretchers from the ruined mine...
###Chapter 135

Sophia whipped her head around, raindrops clinging to her lashes. Her lips parted—but no sound came out.

A distant rumble shook the ground. A plume of dust erupted from the mine's depths.
###Chapter 136

###Chapter 137

His tone brooked no argument.

The terms weren't unreasonable.

After several turns, they were led to the most desolate corner of the amusement park.

The woman whirled around, the jagged glass aimed at their throats.

"Let's talk this through," Evelyn stepped forward, softening her voice.

"Liar! You're all out to get me!" The woman let out a hysterical laugh, her eyes unfocused.

Sebastian moved silently behind her.

"Why would we hurt you?" Evelyn inched closer. "Put the glass down, okay?"

The woman suddenly snarled, "Tell me! Do I look crazy to you?"

The shout made Evelyn's ears ring.

"You're perfectly fine," she steadied her breathing. "Careful, you might cut yourself."

The woman glanced down at the weapon in her hand.

Now!

Sebastian lunged forward, kicking the woman to the ground.

Evelyn seized the chance to scoop Hugo into her arms.

"It's okay, I've got you," she murmured, feeling the child's small body tremble violently against her.

After checking Hugo for injuries, she exhaled in relief.

A ragged gasp came from behind.

Hugo's eyes widened, his face pale. "S-sister! Behind you!"

Evelyn froze—this was the first time she'd heard Hugo speak a full sentence.

"What?"

"The crazy lady has a brick!" The child cried out.

Evelyn spun around.

The madwoman charged at them, a brick raised high above her head, her face twisted with rage.

She was only a step away.
###Chapter 192

The last golden rays of the setting sun streamed through the car window, casting a warm glow on Evelyn Roland's profile.

Hugo suddenly wrenched his hand free and darted across the street.

"Watch out!" A screech of brakes pierced the air.

At the critical moment, Hugo yanked Evelyn's sleeve, pulling her back onto the sidewalk.

An out-of-control electric bike whizzed past, grazing the hem of her skirt.

"You bitch!" A disheveled woman tumbled off the bike, brandishing a fruit knife as she lunged toward them.

Sebastian Valdemar sprang forward, his long fingers clamping around the woman's wrist with precision.

A sharp snap echoed as the knife clattered to the ground.

His eyes turned icy. In three swift motions, he twisted his tie around her wrists, binding them behind her back.

Hugo blinked his large eyes before breaking into a radiant smile. "Mm! I can talk now!"

Sirens wailed in the distance.

The setting sun stretched their three shadows long across the pavement, intertwining them into a warm silhouette.

"Get some rest." Sebastian shrugged off his suit jacket and handed it to her.

She murmured drowsily before her head lolled against the window.

Frowning, Sebastian carefully lifted Hugo onto the opposite seat.

Then, with deliberate gentleness, he cradled the back of Evelyn's head and guided it to rest on his shoulder.

The faint scent of gardenias enveloped him.

He glanced down. Her lashes cast delicate shadows under her eyes, and for a moment, his breath hitched.

"We're here." The driver's voice snapped him out of his daze.

Evelyn rubbed her eyes awake, flushing crimson when she realized she'd been leaning on Sebastian.

Evelyn looked down at the folded suit in her arms, still carrying the faint aroma of cedarwood.
###Chapter 193

Evelyn handed Sebastian his coat, her fingertips accidentally brushing against his wrist. She froze for a split second before quickly withdrawing her hand.

When had she become so careless? Falling asleep in someone else's car. She frowned, absently rubbing the cuff of her sleeve.

"We're here." Sebastian's voice snapped her out of her thoughts. He stepped out smoothly and opened the passenger door for her.

The manor was ablaze with lights. Henry Laurent had prepared dinner long ago and was waiting for them.

Evelyn held Hugo's hand and gently nudged him forward. "Hugo, say hello."

Henry's teacup slipped from his fingers and shattered on the floor. He stood frozen, as if struck by a spell.

"Dad!" This time, the voice was clear and bright.

Henry sank to his knees, his hands trembling as they cradled the child's face. "Say it... one more time?"

Evelyn watched from the side, warmth flooding her chest. Her gaze instinctively sought Sebastian, catching the faint smile playing on his lips.

"It's like a dream..." Henry choked out, pulling the boy close as tears finally spilled over.

Suddenly, the formidable business tycoon dropped to his knees and bowed deeply.

"Don't!" Sebastian moved swiftly to stop him.

Evelyn rushed forward to help him up, only to have something cold pressed into her palm.

It was an exquisitely crafted key, its metal surface gleaming under the lights.

"This is the lifeblood of the winery." Henry's voice was hoarse. "I trust you with it."

Evelyn's hand grew heavy. This key represented the Laurent family's century-old secret recipes—a coveted business secret many would kill for.

She looked up at Sebastian, seeing the same surprise reflected in his eyes.

"Once Hugo recovers further, I'll take him traveling the world." Henry lifted his son with a peaceful smile. "The winery... is in your hands now."

The key grew warm in her palm. Evelyn suddenly understood—this wasn't just trust. It was an immense responsibility.
###Chapter 194

Evelyn Roland tightened her grip on the key and looked up at Sebastian Valdemar.

"We'll keep this key together," she said.

Sebastian slid his hands into his pockets, his expression indifferent.

"I have no interest in wine."

The corner of his lips curved slightly.

"My sincerity is trusting you."

Evelyn's fingers twitched before she tucked the key back into her bag.

She halted mid-step.

"Not interested," she cut in bluntly.

"Fiona Valentine..." he murmured, eyes glazing over with infatuation.

"Professor Jameson, I recommend Fiona Valentine for the competition!"

The professor adjusted his glasses.

"Is she skilled enough?"

"Absolutely top-tier!" Felix thumped his chest. "Far better than Evelyn Roland!"

Professor Jameson pondered briefly. Remembering the sting of rejection, he slammed his desk.

"She's in!"

Felix beamed, already envisioning Fiona's grateful smile.

Meanwhile, Evelyn stood at a crosswalk.

The red light flashed. As cars streamed past, Sebastian's enigmatic gaze flickered through her mind.

There was something in those depths she couldn't decipher.
###Chapter 195

"Don't worry, Professor Jameson. I'll handle this." Felix Valentine thumped his chest before darting out the door.

He sprinted toward the music building in long strides.

"Fiona!"

Fiona Valentine was packing her sheet music when she heard her name. She looked up to see Felix with his garish rainbow hair, earrings glinting in the sunlight.

This spoiled heir had pursued her relentlessly before.

Compared to Sebastian Valdemar, he might as well be dirt beneath her feet.

Her mind was filled with Sebastian's image these days—even in her dreams.

"Don't be so cold." Felix stepped closer. "I got you something good."

Fiona subtly retreated.

Unfazed, Felix beamed. "I secured you a spot in the International Piano Masters competition."

Her eyes lit up at the mention. Winning this prestigious event would make her the center of attention.

Better yet, she'd learned Sebastian was sponsoring it.

This was her chance to rise.

"Professor Jameson wanted Evelyn Roland to go, but she refused. So I recommended you instead."

The words felt like ice water dumped over her head.

Her lashes lowered as nails dug into her palms.

Why was she always Evelyn's second choice? The resentment burned hotter.

"Thank you." Fiona forced a sweet smile, eyes crinkling like crescent moons.

Felix stared, mesmerized. His goddess looked divine when she smiled.

He'd do anything for her.

Fiona noted his infatuation with disgust. This fool had his uses.

Meanwhile, at Aether Medical Lab...

Evelyn Roland peered through the microscope, brow furrowed.

The toxin in Sebastian's blood was more complex than she'd imagined.

Who would plot against him for over a decade?

She carefully added a blood sample to a test tube, then a reagent.

A sudden knock made her hand jerk, nearly overdosing.

Evelyn yanked off her goggles, scowling.

She'd specifically ordered no interruptions.

"Boss!" Dylan Orlando grinned obsequiously. "Finally caught you!"

"What do you want?" Evelyn glared.

That look always meant trouble.

"Uh... boss, I need saving!"

"What mess did you make now?"

Evelyn leaned against the doorframe, arms crossed.

"I didn't!" Dylan batted his lashes. "I just need you to judge a piano competition."

"Busy."

A piano competition? She had bigger concerns.

As she moved to shut the door, Dylan blocked it with his body. "Wait! Hear me out!"

Here we go again.

"Fine. Talk." Evelyn massaged her temples.

"You're the best!" Dylan dropped to his knees, clutching her leg. "I'm dead without you!"

Evelyn recoiled, shaking him off. She dragged over a chair and sat cross-legged. "Out with it. What disaster now?"
###Chapter 196

"Boss, I really got played this time." Dylan Orlando hung his head, nervously twisting the hem of his shirt between his fingers.

That sly old fox!

"Hmm?"

"The organizers of the piano competition heard I know Maestro. They deliberately provoked me into inviting them as a judge."

Evelyn Roland fixed him with a piercing stare. Dylan felt chills run down his spine.

The boss's gaze was terrifying.

"So you fell for it?"

"Waaah! Boss, don't look at me like that!"

"The worst part is, if I can't get you to come, I have to publicly kneel and apologize!" Dylan wailed pitifully.

"You can't just abandon me!"

As Dylan began his dramatic sobbing again, Evelyn massaged her temples. "Shut up. I'll go."

He immediately stopped, sniffled, and broke into a grin. "You're the best, boss."

Evelyn sighed at the sudden praise.

Must be repaying a debt from a past life.

Fine. She'd indulge him just this once.

Two days later, the piano competition commenced as scheduled.

Evelyn hadn't anticipated the event clashing with Hugo's acupuncture treatment.

Between Dylan's pride and Hugo's health, she chose the latter without hesitation, heading to the Laurent residence first.

"Big sister!"

Hugo flew into her arms like an excited little bird.

"You've grown taller." Evelyn casually ruffled his hair.

"Miss Roland." Henry Laurent greeted her with a warm smile.

She nodded politely.
