"Thank you for the offer, Mr. Laurent, but I have another engagement."

Evelyn checked her watch as she walked.

Time was tight.

She arrived at the competition venue in a hurry, only to find the judges' panel already fully seated.

Late, as expected.

Whispers circulated among the judges.

"Wasn't Maestro supposed to come?"

"The competition has started. Where are they?"

"Probably not showing up."

"What a shame. I've always wanted to meet Maestro."

One judge looked particularly disappointed.

Evelyn quietly took a seat beside the judges' table, her simple attire making her blend into the background.

Sebastian Valdemar sat in the investors' VIP section, bored out of his mind.

Then a familiar figure caught his eye.

White blouse, high ponytail, gold-rimmed glasses—none other than Evelyn Roland.

What was she doing here?

A contestant, perhaps?

The dull competition suddenly became interesting.
###Chapter 197

Sebastian Valdemar's slender fingers traced the competition list, his brow slightly furrowed.

Evelyn Roland's name was conspicuously absent.

Fiona Valentine stepped onto the stage with graceful poise, her white gown shimmering like pearls under the lights.

This melody... it was too familiar.

She pressed her lips together, sitting quietly in the audience.

Fiona's performance flowed effortlessly, leaving the concert hall in awed silence.

As the final note faded, thunderous applause erupted.

"Miss Valentine's original piece is truly remarkable," praised Professor Jameson, a renowned musician on the judging panel.

"Genius!"

Her again!

###Chapter 198

Interesting.

Felix Valentine paled, sweat beading on his forehead. Maestro? Evelyn Roland was Maestro? The realization sent chills down his spine.

Lowell?

Evelyn's lips curled into a cold smile. Of course. Her dear stepsister Victoria Lowell. Back in the Lowell household, Victoria had "contributed" plenty of stolen compositions.

"Wow, this scandal just got bigger!"

Whispers spread through the crowd.

Evelyn's gaze darkened. Victoria's title as a piano virtuoso had been built entirely on plagiarizing her work.

Fiona's excuses sounded feeble as tears streamed down her face.

###Chapter 199

The auditorium fell into dead silence.

Sebastian Valdemar's deep voice resonated through the air like a hammer striking every heart.

She felt one step closer to becoming Mrs. Valdemar.

This woman ruined everything!

###Chapter 200

Mr. Valentine's face turned ashen.

This disgraceful daughter had utterly humiliated the Valentine family today.

###Chapter 201

###Chapter 204

"No need. I recorded our entire conversation."

The man was shrewd.

He'd activated his recorder beforehand.

"One month deadline."

Other staff members stared at Evelyn like she'd lost her mind.

Doubling Château Laurent's profits without using the ingredient vault?

Preposterous.

"Bold words, Miss Roland. If you actually pull this off, I'll be the first to respect you!"

A burly man slammed the table as he stood.

"Agreed! We'll all acknowledge you!"

The others chimed in.

"Remember your words."

Sebastian Valdemar observed Evelyn's confident demeanor from the sidelines.

His tense nerves finally relaxed.

He opened his mouth to speak.

But Evelyn had already turned to leave.

A faint breeze stirred as they brushed past each other.

The employees watched Evelyn depart, then stole furtive glances at Sebastian.

This icy-faced executioner was their second-in-command.

Having publicly contradicted him, they feared retaliation.

Sebastian merely gave them an inscrutable look before striding out after her.

Evelyn walked a hundred meters from the winery.

The familiar scent of mint trailed behind her.

She didn't need to turn around to know who it was.

Irritated, she halted abruptly.

"What do you want?" She spun around.

They stood close enough to feel each other's breath.

Sebastian stumbled back, averting his face.

"I came to apologize. And explain."

"Don't bother. Since you chose to help Olivia, see it through."

Evelyn had no patience for conversation.

She just wanted him gone.

Sebastian grew visibly agitated.

"Evelyn, you've misunderstood. I never took her side."

"Not my concern." Her voice turned glacial. "If you can't comprehend basic English, Mr. Valdemar, I'll repeat myself: Stay away."

The temperature between them plummeted.

A nameless fury rose in Sebastian's chest.

As the standoff continued,

He suddenly clutched his temples, brows furrowing.

The pained expression vanished as quickly as it appeared.

Another migraine? Evelyn's hand twitched toward him instinctively.
###Chapter 206

Evelyn Roland's fingers tightened slightly, her nails nearly digging into her palms. She took a deep breath, forcing down the turbulent emotions swirling in her chest.

Sebastian Valdemar noticed her hesitation instantly, his tone softening unexpectedly. "The headaches have been getting worse. I probably need a second treatment."

A faint sheen of sweat glistened at his temples under the light as he frowned slightly.

Evelyn's gaze lingered on his strained expression. Her instincts as a healer wouldn't allow her to ignore a patient's suffering.

"I can treat you today."

A flash of triumph flickered in Sebastian's eyes before he schooled his features back into weakness. "Thank you, Miss Roland. After all, you promised to cure me."

This man really knew how to seize an opportunity. Evelyn rolled her eyes internally.

Even more absurd—she thought she detected a hint of vulnerability in his deep voice. She must be hearing things.

The sharp edges of Sebastian's aura melted away instantly. His lips curved. "Much obliged."

Only after settling into the black Maybach did Evelyn realize she'd been led by the nose again.

Fine. Consider it professional compassion.

The Valdemar villa remained eerily quiet, as if uninhabited. While preparing her silver needles, Evelyn glanced around.

"Do you live here alone?"

Sebastian lay on the sofa, cracking one eye open. "Why? Feeling sorry for me?"

This batch was thicker than last time.

Sebastian closed his eyes again. "Do your worst."

As each needle found its mark, beads of sweat formed along his hairline. Noticing his clenched jaw, Evelyn unconsciously lightened her touch.

"Any thoughts about boosting the winery's sales?" Sebastian asked abruptly.

Evelyn's hand jerked, nearly missing the acupuncture point. She steadied herself. "Traditional sales methods are outdated."

"Oh?" Sebastian sounded intrigued. "Go on."

"It's the age of digital influence." Adjusting a needle's angle, she continued, "I'm planning online campaigns and considering a brand ambassador."

Sebastian's lips quirked. "Not bad."

His approval made her ears burn. She hurriedly bent over the needles to hide her reaction.

Outside the door, Olivia Valdemar muffled a giggle, tiptoeing away to avoid disrupting the charged atmosphere.

These two were practically made for each other. She was already calculating how large a wedding gift to prepare.
###Chapter 207

Sebastian's stomach twisted at the mention of Fiona's pretentious mannerisms.

The celebrity's name alone made her recoil.

The film set's chaos snapped her from her thoughts.

"Cut! Perfect! Ten-minute break!"

The director's shout barely faded when a saccharine voice pierced the air. "Cousin, you're amazing~"

Evelyn's pupils constricted.

Fiona Valentine, clad in costume, clung to the lead actress's arm. When they turned, six eyes collided in midair.
###Chapter 208

###Chapter 209

###Chapter 210

The director's fingertips trembled slightly.

This young woman had recognized his long-buried debut film at first glance. Fresh out of film school back then, he'd poured his soul into that arthouse project—winning Best New Director at an international festival.

Utterly destroyed.

###Chapter 214

"Miss Valdemar is still shaken. Stay with her." I stood by the hospital room door, fingertips lightly tapping the wall. "There are matters at the winery that need my attention."

Inside the Valentine family villa.

He saved her. That meant he loved her!

Destroy the winery, and she’d destroy them both.

Filming day.

I led Blake through the winery grounds. The workers initially shied away from the cameras—until they realized the documentary was about them.

These seasoned employees, who’d never been on screen before, lit up with excitement. Under the lens, their labor took on a quiet dignity.

Watching the rough cut, I nodded in approval.

I hadn’t misjudged him.

###Chapter 220

Sebastian Valdemar moved faster than expected.

By dawn the next day, the winery's official account released a bombshell announcement—the establishment of the Laurent Mental Health Foundation.

The statement clearly outlined free counseling and treatment services for all young people struggling with psychological issues.

Then she saw the news.

Her finger hovered over the screen for three full seconds.

She never expected Sebastian to intervene personally.

Even less did she anticipate this masterstroke.

The foundation's announcement swept through like a cleansing breeze, dispelling the dark clouds over the winery.

Sales began a slow but steady recovery.

Young people flocked to sign up for counseling services.

The storm Fiona Valentine had unleashed with her life faded into silence.

On a drizzly morning, Evelyn stood deep in the cemetery under a black umbrella.

Her slender frame was outlined by a simple black dress.

The silk ribbon in her hair fluttered in the wind.

"We could have been friends."

Her gaze lingered on the photograph etched into the headstone.

Fiona's smile was forever frozen at eighteen.

From her bag, Evelyn withdrew an exquisitely crafted piano miniature.

Custom-made for this moment.

"Next life, just be an ordinary, happy person."

Raindrops clung to her lashes.

As she turned, seven masked figures materialized on the steps below.

Black fabric obscured their faces.

Only their murderous eyes remained visible.

"Hand over the Divine Elixir!"

The leader's voice was a rasping growl.

Evelyn tightened her grip on the umbrella. "I don't know what you're talking about."

"Take her!"

They lunged as one.

The umbrella slashed through the air with lethal precision.

Two attackers crumpled instantly.

But the numbers were overwhelming.

Evelyn soon found herself outmatched.

Seizing a split-second opening, she spun and fled.

Footsteps pounded behind her.

In the chaos, her phone slipped from her bag.

The screen illuminated with a single glaring name:

Sebastian Valdemar.

The call connected.

The device lay abandoned in the rain.
###Chapter 221

Dark clouds loomed overhead as violent winds whipped up swirling sands, casting the entire city in an oppressive pre-storm gloom.

Inside the CEO's office of Valdemar Group, floor-to-ceiling windows reflected Sebastian Valdemar's tall silhouette. He was casually reviewing documents when the vibrating phone on his desk interrupted his thoughts.

His fingers stilled at the name flashing onscreen.

Evelyn Roland?

They hadn't seen each other in half a month. This sudden call raised his suspicions. The moment he answered, an unexpected male voice assaulted his ears instead of her familiar tone.

"Grab her! The Divine Elixir must be on her!"

The gruff shout mixed with chaotic footsteps, followed by Evelyn's ragged breathing. Then the line went dead, leaving only hollow static.

Sebastian's pupils constricted violently.

Those two words - Divine Elixir - stabbed into his memory like a blade. Months ago during the mining disaster, that mysterious pill had saved his life. He'd later posted a bounty on the dark web just to trace its origin.

Could it be...?

He shot to his feet, long fingers flying across the keyboard. Three seconds later, satellite coordinates locked onto a cemetery on the city outskirts.

"Mr. Valdemar! The board meeting is about to—"

Theodore Ashcroft barged in with an armful of files, only to be shoved aside as Sebastian streaked past like a released arrow. "Cancel all appointments," came the terse command.

A black sports car became a blur on the highway. Sebastian's knuckles whitened on the steering wheel, Evelyn's pale face flashing through his mind. If his momentary curiosity had endangered her...

Meanwhile, on the desolate grounds outside the cemetery, Evelyn staggered against a gravestone. Blood gushed from her waist, blooming a grotesque crimson stain across her beige trench coat.

Five black-clad figures advanced in a semicircle. The leader twirled a dagger with a cold smirk. "Hand over the Divine Elixir, and we'll make it quick."

"I don't know what you're talking about," she panted, heels hitting solid stone.

"Playing dumb?" The man lunged without warning, blade aimed at her throat. "Ask the devil in hell then!"

Steel flashed—

A dark shadow materialized like a specter. The sickening crunch of shattering bones preceded the attacker flying several meters like a ragdoll.

Familiar cologne enveloped her.

"Hold on." Sebastian caught her collapsing form with one arm while deflecting another blade with his free hand. Warm blood splattered across his chiseled profile, painting eerie patterns.

Evelyn's lips moved soundlessly. Darkness flooded her vision, the last image searing into her consciousness—those crimson-ringed eyes burning with fury.
###Chapter 222

Sebastian's pupils constricted violently. The woman in his arms was drenched in blood, her body temperature frighteningly low like a block of ice.

The black-clad men exchanged glances before retreating reluctantly.

He removed his suit jacket and wrapped Evelyn securely. She felt weightless as he carried her effortlessly into the car.

Evelyn's eyelashes trembled. Even unconscious, her expression remained tormented, as if trapped in an inescapable nightmare.

The elevator at Valdemar Tower ascended directly to the penthouse.

Sebastian carried her down the corridor, his leather shoes muffled against the plush carpet. Only after placing her on the office sofa did he realize his back was drenched in sweat.

"A hospital would be safer," he murmured, fingers absently tracing the armrest. "But Olivia can't handle any more shocks right now."

The first aid kit landed heavily on the coffee table.

His Adam's apple bobbed as he stared at her bloodied collar. After a hesitation, his fingers brushed the first button.

The shirt slipped away, revealing a vicious wound. Fresh blood seeped from below her collarbone, staining the sofa cushions.

"Mr. Valdemar, the meeting materials—"

Documents scattered across the floor. The manager's glasses slid down his nose as he froze mid-step.

Sebastian materialized like a specter before the sofa. The room temperature plummeted.

"Out."

The manager scrambled backward, nearly catching his fingers in the door. Pressing his ear against the wood, his expression suddenly cleared with understanding.

"So the boss prefers this type?"

Inside, Sebastian dabbed alcohol-soaked cotton against the wound. Evelyn whimpered faintly in her unconscious state.

"Bear with it," he softened his movements. "Almost done."

When Evelyn awoke, the first thing she noticed was the faint scent of sandalwood. She twitched her fingers, sending sharp pain radiating from her shoulder.

"Don't move."

Sebastian stood silhouetted against the floor-to-ceiling windows. Noticing her consciousness, he poured a glass of water.

"Were they after the Divine Elixir?"

Their fingers brushed as she accepted the glass. Both recoiled simultaneously, nearly shattering it.

"About today—"

"I'll handle it." He checked his watch. "Rest here. I'll escort you home after my meeting."

Pausing at the door, he added without turning, "Fresh clothes are in the dressing room."

Only when the door clicked shut did Evelyn realize she wore his shirt. The subtle ambergris scent enveloped her, inexplicably soothing.
###Chapter 223

Sebastian's suit jacket still carried a faint trace of ambergris. Evelyn watched his retreating figure, the wound between her shoulder blades throbbing with sudden pain. She bit her lip to stifle a gasp, but her trembling hand knocked over a glass on the coffee table.

The shattering sound was followed by a glow from her phone wedged between the couch cushions.

[Mr. Valdemar, someone on the dark web is offering a billion for the Divine Elixir formula.]

Evelyn's finger hovered above the screen. The message slithered into her vision like a venomous serpent. She remembered Sebastian's bloodstained hands in the mine shaft—proof he'd never stopped hunting for answers.

"Of course..." Her lips curled into a mirthless smile as the jacket slid from her shoulders. Fresh blood bloomed across the beige upholstery, vivid as the crimson moon over the mines that night.

The taxi driver glanced at his rearview mirror for the third time.

"Miss, do you need a hospital?"

Evelyn concealed her bloodied hand in the shadows. "Stop at the next alley." She counted out bills, leaving faint scarlet smudges on their edges.

Rusted hinges screeched as she pushed open the abandoned pharmaceutical factory's gate.

Joanna froze mid-experiment, the liquid in her test tube emitting an eerie blue glow. "Boss?" Her goggles clattered onto the counter as she knocked over two racks of petri dishes.

The metallic tang of blood filled the air. Evelyn leaned against the doorframe with a strained chuckle. "Still have that bloodhound nose, I see."

"You're hit?" Joanna peeled back the blood-soaked fabric and gasped. Three knife wounds resembled viper fangs—the deepest one exposed a sliver of white bone.

"Too many strays at the cemetery." Evelyn collapsed onto the operating table, watching the flickering overhead lights. "Check who's been stockpiling Rh-negative blood lately."

Joanna's forceps tightened around the alcohol swab. "The Elixir again?"

Amid the hum of refrigeration units, Evelyn closed her eyes. The blinding "1 billion" on her phone screen merged with Sebastian's fathomless gaze. The surgical lamp burned crimson against her eyelids—just like the rain-soaked night when he'd cradled her face with bloodied hands.
###Chapter 224

The laboratory was silent except for the rhythmic tapping of keyboards.

Joanna focused intently on the screen, her fingers flying across the keys. Evelyn reclined in her chair with closed eyes, long lashes casting delicate shadows beneath them.

"Strange..."

Joanna suddenly stopped typing and turned to Evelyn. "The usable footage from the cemetery surveillance has been deleted. Those men in black vanished without a trace."

Evelyn slowly opened her eyes, a cold glint flashing in their depths. "Stop investigating." She stood, her black trench coat swaying slightly with the movement. "If they dared strike in broad daylight, they’ve already covered their tracks."

"Should I arrange for bodyguards?" Joanna frowned. "We got lucky this time, but next—"

"No." Evelyn cut her off. "More people will only get in the way."

After seeing Joanna out, the lab fell into silence once more.

Outside the window, the night was ink-black. Evelyn stood by the glass, her reflection showing a profile as cool as moonlight. She flicked the switch, and artificial light instantly banished the darkness.

With practiced ease, she retrieved the first-aid kit and lifted the hem of her shirt. The wound had scabbed over, the dark red crust stark against her pale skin.

Just as she reached for the antiseptic, faint footsteps sounded behind her.

"Who's there?"

Evelyn whirled around—and met a pair of smiling, peach-blossom eyes.

The man wore a simple white shirt, its collar slightly open to reveal elegant collarbones. Bathed in the light, he seemed to glow with a soft radiance.

"Quite the fierce greeting, Ms. Roland." He held up his phone, the screen displaying a job posting. "I'm here about the assistant position."

He took a step forward, the corner of his mouth tilting in a lazy smirk. "Silas Eisner. Pleasure to meet you."

Only then did Evelyn recall posting the vacancy. She cleared her throat. "My apologies. It's been a hectic week."

As she handed him a glass of water, their fingers brushed—and an inexplicable sense of familiarity washed over her.

That voice... Had she heard it somewhere before?
###Chapter 225

"Miss Roland?"

Silas Eisner set down his water glass, brows slightly furrowed. The woman before him had remained frozen in the same stance for three full minutes.

Evelyn Roland's pupils constricted abruptly.

Memories flooded back—Olivia Valdemar's terrified, distorted face, the glinting surface of the pool, the cacophony of screams... and that silver brooch being handed to her.

Her head snapped up.

The handsome face before her perfectly overlapped with the figure who'd extended a helping hand in her moment of crisis.

"So it was you."

Her fingers trembled slightly as she retrieved the brooch from her pocket. The silver surface gleamed coldly under the light, resting quietly in her palm.

Silas's gaze dropped to the brooch, his lips curving into a meaningful smile.

"Surprising. You actually remember me."

He didn't take it immediately. Evelyn followed his line of sight and noticed the tiny inscription on the brooch's underside.

"See this engraving?" Silas tapped the text with a slender finger. "Should be familiar to you, Senior Roland?"

"St. John's Medical College?" Evelyn's eyes widened. "You're—"

"Class of 2015, Clinical Medicine." His boyish grin revealed sharp canines. "Getting into our alma mater was my proudest achievement."

The tension dissolved instantly.

"So you're my junior." A soft laugh escaped her as she pressed the brooch into his hand. "Something this valuable should return to its owner."

She paused, expression turning earnest. "And about that day—thank you."

"Just doing my duty." He pocketed the brooch, gaze intent. "Regarding the assistant position..."

"You're hired." Evelyn stood, extending her hand formally. "Welcome to Aether Medical Lab."

Silas blinked, then scrambled to shake her hand. "I won't let you down."

Mid-conversation, his eyes caught the bloodstain on her collar.

"You're injured?"

"Minor scratch." She retreated half a step smoothly. "There's a first aid kit in the lab. I'll handle it."

Glancing at the darkening sky outside, she added, "Let's end here today. Report tomorrow for orientation—I'll introduce you to another colleague."

Silas took the hint and bid farewell.

Meanwhile, at the Roland Estate.

Night draped the grounds like ink, tree shadows swaying. A black Maybach crunched through fallen leaves, coming to a silent stop in the courtyard's center.

The door opened. Polished oxfords met flagstone. The man's tall silhouette stretched long under the streetlamp, his tailored suit radiating an impenetrable chill.
###Chapter 226

The night was ink-black, the moonlight casting a cold gleam on the black sedan parked in the courtyard.

"Sebastian Valdemar, how long do you plan to hide?"

The low voice carried an icy edge, cutting through the silence of the garden.

Sebastian stepped out from behind the car, his tall frame casting a long shadow under the streetlight. "Waiting," he said flatly, his gaze scanning the surroundings.

"Waiting?" Alexander Roland let out a humorless laugh, his eyes flickering toward the faint figures lurking in the shadows. "You've surrounded the Roland estate like a fortress. Quite the show of force."

The air grew thick with tension.

"Just precautions," Sebastian replied, his tone steady. "Times are uncertain."

"Precautions?" Alexander's eyes sharpened like blades. "Since when does an outsider get to decide how my sister should be protected?"

A sudden gust of wind sent dead leaves skittering across the ground.

Sebastian leaned against the car, fingers tapping lightly on the door. "Some threats can't be ignored."

"Hmph." Alexander closed the distance between them in one stride. "Then tell me, Sebastian—what gives you the right to interfere in Roland family affairs?"

Dappled shadows swayed between them, the moonlight drawing a stark line across the ground.

Sebastian lifted his gaze, something dark swirling in his eyes. "That answer isn't mine to give."

"Spare me the theatrics." Alexander scoffed. "If you won't speak plainly, then leave."

A distant branch snapped.

"Last warning," Alexander bit out. "Stay away from my sister."

Sebastian straightened, the air around him turning glacial. "Let her tell me that herself."

The front door creaked open.

Old Joy peeked out, beads of sweat forming on his forehead as he took in the standoff. He retreated inside and dialed with trembling fingers.

"Miss Evelyn, you need to come home immediately."

On the other end, Evelyn Roland had just finished changing her bandages. "What's wrong?"

"Master Alexander and Mr. Valdemar..." Joy whispered, "they're having a confrontation in the courtyard."

Evelyn grabbed her coat and bolted for the door. "I'm on my way."
###Chapter 227

The night was deep, with street lamps casting mottled shadows. Among the swaying trees, Sebastian Valdemar stood tall like a pine, his face obscured in the darkness.

"Mr. Valdemar, you should leave." Alexander Roland's lips curled into a cold smile. "Our humble Roland family can't handle such a grand display."

His sharp gaze swept over the black-suited bodyguards, his tone growing even more cutting. "My sister's safety is none of your concern."

Evelyn Roland had just stepped out of the car when she sensed the tension in the air. She had never seen her usually gentle third brother so confrontational.

She intended to observe from the shadows, but as the standoff escalated, she had no choice but to step forward. Her slender fingers tightened around her bag strap as she positioned herself beside Alexander, discreetly studying his expression.

When she turned, she met Sebastian's penetrating gaze. A cigarette dangled between his fingers, its ember flickering, casting his chiseled features in and out of the smoke.

"We need to talk," he said, his voice low.

Alexander scoffed, interrupting him. "What's left to discuss? Even you—"

Before he could finish, Sebastian shifted his attention solely to Evelyn. The air grew thick with silence.

Alexander's face darkened with fury at being ignored. "Sebastian Valdemar, you—"

"Third Brother."

The soft address made Alexander stiffen. He turned to her, disbelief and complex emotions swirling in his eyes.

It was the first time Evelyn had called him that.

Though they had grown close since her return to the Roland family, twenty years of separation had left an invisible barrier between them. That single word—like a key—gently unlocked something in his heart.

Seeing his stunned expression, Evelyn pressed her lips together. "There are some private matters I need to settle with him. You should go back first—Mom and Dad will be waiting."

Another "Third Brother" shattered his resistance. After shooting Sebastian a warning glare, Alexander finally turned and left.

Watching him disappear inside, Evelyn exhaled in relief. She walked to the stone bench in the courtyard, her fingertips brushing the cool surface.

"Have a seat," she said, gesturing to Sebastian. "It's better to clear the air."

The delicate aroma of tea rose as she pushed a celadon cup toward him. "Try it. Premium Longjing."

Sebastian stubbed out his cigarette, his well-defined fingers tracing the rim of the cup. After a moment of silence, he spoke abruptly. "I came to apologize."

The night breeze carried his rare admission of guilt. "Those rumors online about the Divine Elixir—they started with me. I never expected it would cause you so much trouble."

He turned to meet her gaze, his words deliberate. "I'm sorry."
###Chapter 228

The room was so quiet the ticking of the clock echoed clearly.

Sebastian Valdemar suddenly heard a soft chuckle.

Evelyn Roland turned to face him, her lips curved slightly, but her eyes remained cold.

"I saw the messages on your phone."

"At this point, I don't want to dwell on it."

She paused, tapping her fingers lightly against the desk. "But your previous investigation did cause me quite a bit of trouble."

The atmosphere between them was eerily calm.

Sebastian set down his teacup, the porcelain clinking against the wood.

"What exactly is this Divine Elixir? Why are they so desperate to get it?"

"My blood."

Evelyn said it plainly, as if discussing the weather.

Sebastian's pupils constricted.

She had just revealed the secret so casually?

"I wasn't planning to keep it from you any longer."

Evelyn saw his shock and sighed. "Absurd, isn't it? Even I don't understand why my blood has this effect."

She pressed her lips together. "I'm still investigating the reason behind it."

If not for Charles Lowell's protection all these years, she would have been in grave danger long ago.

Sebastian's expression darkened, his chest tightening.

"If the Divine Elixir is your blood..." His voice turned grave. "Then you're in far more danger than we thought. If they discover the truth, not just you—everyone around you will be at risk."

"They shouldn't know yet."

Sebastian's gaze burned into her. "But you need to leave. Now."

This was a question Evelyn had agonized over countless times.

She lowered her lashes, silent for a long moment.

If her family suffered because of her, she could never forgive herself.

"I understand." She finally spoke. "I'll leave tomorrow."

She had just returned to the Roland family. She refused to become their curse.

"Good." Sebastian nodded. "I'll come for you tomorrow."

"Come for me?" Evelyn frowned. "I can handle it myself."

"You're moving in with me."

Evelyn shot to her feet, the chair screeching against the floor.

"What did you say?"

"My estate has top-tier security. It's the safest place for you." Sebastian stood as well. "Besides, I bear responsibility for this."

"The Divine Elixir existed long before you got involved."

Evelyn massaged her temples. "Thank you for saving me today, but I'll handle the rest myself."

Living with Sebastian?

Preposterous.

She turned to leave, but a strong hand suddenly seized her wrist.
###Chapter 229

Evelyn Roland turned to leave when a strong hand suddenly clamped around her wrist.

She spun around and found herself drowning in Sebastian Valdemar's bottomless gaze.

"The Rolands still don't know about your kidnapping," he said in a low voice. "And you have no intention of telling them."

"Why should I?" Evelyn frowned, trying to pull away but failing. Mid-sentence, her eyes widened in realization.

"Sebastian Valdemar!" Her voice turned icy. "Are you threatening me? If I refuse to move in with you, you'll expose this to my family?"

Upstairs by the floor-to-ceiling window, Isabella Langley dug her nails into her palms.

She glared at the entangled pair below, jealousy burning in her eyes.

Sebastian's grip on Evelyn's wrist was unyielding, their bodies nearly touching.

"That bitch..." Isabella seethed, itching to rush down and tear them apart.

Sebastian remained silent for a long moment, his dark eyes growing even more inscrutable.

"My place is the safest," he finally said, his tone brooking no argument. "I can't trust anywhere else."

Evelyn was caught off guard by his sudden concern.

She took a deep breath. "Let go."

Sebastian immediately released her.

Clutching her bag strap, Evelyn hesitated before relenting. "Don't come for me tomorrow. I don't want another confrontation between you and my brother."

The tension in Sebastian's jaw eased. "Fine."

Watching the black Maybach disappear down the driveway, Evelyn rubbed her temples.

Had she really just agreed to live with Sebastian Valdemar?

The thought made her pulse quicken. Images of their daily interactions flashed through her mind, warming the tips of her ears.

"Evelyn, you're back?"

Sophia Roland's voice snapped her back to reality. In the living room, Edward Roland was speaking with his wife, who beckoned her over.

"Alexander is in the study," Sophia said, pulling her onto the couch and stroking her cheek worriedly. "You look exhausted."

"I'm fine. The company is running smoothly," Evelyn forced a smile.

Edward set down his teacup. "Don't overwork yourself. Delegate more."

"Your father's right," Sophia agreed. "Look at you—you've lost color in your face."

Evelyn lowered her head to hide her unease.

She couldn't possibly tell them what she'd just agreed to.
###Chapter 230

Edward Roland set down the financial magazine, his eyes crinkling with amusement. "That incident at the vineyard would've given anyone a migraine. Yet you handled it flawlessly."

Sophia Roland gazed at her daughter's delicate profile, a pang of sorrow tightening her chest. She'd missed twenty years of this child's life. Now reunited, the girl stood before her as a fully capable woman.

"Evelyn, I'm so proud of you."

Her fingers trembled slightly as she tucked a stray lock behind Evelyn's ear. Sunlight streamed through the floor-to-ceiling windows, bathing the trio in golden warmth.

Evelyn's lips curved upward at her parents' approving expressions.

"Thank you, Mom. Dad."

"Sweetheart, no need for formalities with us."

Evelyn's breath hitched. She quickly tucked her wrist deeper into her sleeve. "Just a minor fall. Already seen the doctor."

Sophia's eyes glistened. "I just hate seeing you bear everything alone."

"I'm a Roland." Evelyn winked. "Anyone who messes with me answers to you two first."

Laughter bubbled through the drawing room. The sound floated up the spiral staircase like shards of glass to Isabella Langley's ears.

At the landing, her nails dug crescent moons into her palms. The cozy scene below burned her vision—and her pride.

Why?

Why did this interloper waltz in and steal everything that rightfully belonged to her? Even that man had fallen under Evelyn's spell.

Isabella's chest heaved as she glared at the figure below. Her skirt snapped like a whip as she spun away.

Just you wait, Evelyn Roland.

Downstairs, Evelyn hesitated before speaking. "Mom, Dad... There's something I need to discuss. I might not be home much in the coming days."
###Chapter 231

Sophia Roland's teacup paused mid-air, the liquid inside rippling slightly. She lifted her gaze to her daughter, brows knitting together. "Why bring this up so suddenly?"

Edward Roland set aside his newspaper, concern evident behind his glasses. "Isn't the winery stable now?"

Evelyn Roland tucked a loose strand of hair behind her ear, her fingers absently tracing the rim of her teacup. "The new season's tasting event requires extensive preparation. It would be more convenient to stay near the winery."

Sunlight streamed through the floor-to-ceiling windows, casting a soft glow on her profile.

"Mother, you know I've always valued my independence." She reached for Sophia's wrist, her voice softening. "I promise to visit every weekend."

At dawn the next day, Evelyn tiptoed downstairs with her suitcase in tow.

A black Maybach waited beneath the plane tree, its window rolled down to reveal Sebastian Valdemar's sharp profile.

"You—" Evelyn instinctively glanced back at the second-floor windows before lowering her voice. "Why are you here so early?"

Sebastian took her luggage, the corner of his mouth lifting. "Didn't want to risk you changing your mind."

As the car pulled into the Valdemar estate, sunlight broke through the clouds. Evelyn stood by the guest room window, lost in thought as she gazed at the blooming roses in the garden.

A knock interrupted her reverie.

She turned to find Sebastian at the door, holding a steaming cup of floral tea.

"Tired?" His eyes flickered to the faint sheen of sweat at her temple. "Rest for a while. We'll go shopping this afternoon."

The midday sun was warm when Evelyn descended the stairs, dressed and ready. Sebastian waited by the foyer, his rolled-up sleeves revealing toned forearms beneath a slate-gray casual shirt.

They walked along the tree-lined path in comfortable silence.

"Does the wound still hurt?" Sebastian stopped abruptly.

Evelyn shook her head, but before she could respond, she collided with a solid wall of muscle. Stumbling back, she was steadied by Sebastian's firm grip on her shoulders.

"Miss Roland? What a coincidence."

Silas Eisner stood three paces away, his damp hair still dripping. His gaze flickered between them before curving into a knowing smile. "And this is...?"

"A friend," Evelyn answered quickly, her nails digging into her palms.

Silas tilted his head, studying Sebastian before chuckling. "A friend who makes you this nervous must be quite special."
###Chapter 232

Silas Eisner blinked his peach-blossom eyes and drawled, "After all, our Aether Research Lab—"

"Exactly! No need for formalities between friends."

Evelyn Roland's heart skipped a beat. She swiftly cut him off, shooting him a warning glare while forcing a polite smile. "We're in a hurry. Let's catch up another time."

She gritted her teeth. Sebastian Valdemar only knew about her medical skills, not her connection to the Aether Research Lab.

Silas froze, looking at her with puppy-dog eyes like an abandoned stray.

"I'll get lovesick if I don't see you."

His mournful tone made Evelyn sound like some heartless playgirl.

She paused mid-step and glared over her shoulder. "See you tomorrow."

Only then did Silas leave satisfied, tossing her a flirtatious wink before disappearing.

Evelyn exhaled in relief once he was gone.

Too close. That idiot almost blew her cover.

She stole a glance at the man beside her, meeting Sebastian's probing gaze.

"Promises?"

"Lovesick?"

"Meeting tomorrow?"

His sarcastic tone dripped with enough vinegar to sour the air.

"We just met yesterday," Evelyn sighed, rubbing her temples. "Who knows what's wrong with him—"

She abruptly cut herself off.

Wait. Why was she explaining?

At most, they were just temporary roommates.

"The mall's here. Let's go." She quickly changed the subject, striding ahead.

Sebastian remained rooted, watching her retreating figure with an unconscious smirk.

In a corner of Starbucks, Isabella Langley stirred her coffee elegantly before brightening at the entrance. "Cousin!"

Vanessa Valrose stormed in and plopped down, gulping half her coffee in one go.

"Well?" Isabella masked her distaste.

Vanessa leaned in conspiratorially. "I stayed up all night and finally came up with a brilliant idea."

"What idea?"

"Marry Evelyn off!" Vanessa whispered, eyes gleaming with calculation. "Once she's wed, she'll have to leave the Roland family for good!"
###Chapter 233

"Marriage?"

Isabella Langley scoffed, leaning back lazily in her chair, her fingers lightly tapping the rim of her coffee cup.

"That's it? You stayed up all night just to come up with this ridiculous idea?" She rolled her eyes. "That girl hasn't even dated anyone. By the time she gets married and leaves, it'll be too late."

Vanessa Valrose took a slow sip of her coffee, lowering her voice mysteriously. "Hear me out."

Isabella raised a skeptical eyebrow, gesturing for her to continue.

"I have a distant cousin, Oliver Valrose." A calculating glint flashed in Vanessa's eyes. "On the surface, he's the most presentable young talent from the Valrose family—charming, handsome, and well-mannered."

Isabella's eyes lit up. "You want him to..."

Isabella clenched her fists, her nails digging into her palms. The memory of Sebastian Valdemar's gaze at Evelyn last night sent a surge of jealousy through her.

"I'll create an opportunity today." She stood abruptly, her sunglasses hiding the malice in her eyes. "Tell your cousin to wait outside the Roland estate."

The sharp click of her heels echoed as she strode out of the café without a backward glance.

Vanessa watched her leave, a knowing smile curling at her lips.

The next evening.

"Isabella, what a surprise that you have time to take a walk with me today." Sophia Roland affectionately linked arms with her younger daughter.

Isabella smiled sweetly. "Since Evelyn moved out, I didn’t want you to feel lonely."

As they strolled toward the estate gates, Isabella spotted a black sedan parked nearby. Her phone conveniently rang.

"Mom, I need to take this." She hurried to the corner and quickly sent a text: When the car comes, make sure he plays the hero.

The black sedan suddenly accelerated, heading straight for Sophia.

At the last second, a figure in gray lightning-fast pulled her to safety. The car roared past them, missing by inches.

"Are you alright, ma'am?" The man's voice was gentle, his tailored suit exuding an air of refinement.

Isabella rushed over, feigning panic. "Mom! You scared me to death!"

###Chapter 234

His deep voice startled her, sending heat rushing to her ears.

He untied the apron with the grace of removing a silk tie. A faint smile played on his lips. "Try it."

A memory flashed—twenty years ago in the Valdemar mansion's empty kitchen, a scrawny boy straining on tiptoes to reach bread in the cabinet.

All those solitary nights now swirled in the depths of his eyes.

"I'm going to Stanford today," Evelyn blurted.

Sebastian's fingers stilled. "Reason?"

"To submit an assignment." She poked at the egg yolk. "I'll be back soon."

Silence settled over the dining room. His gaze lingered on the crown of her head, darkening.

Some things she'd never know. Like how he'd deliberated thirty minutes over ingredients this morning. How he'd secretly cataloged every food preference of hers.

"I'll drive you." Three measured words were all he offered.

Could it be...?

The man seemed to read her thoughts, his lips quirking slightly. "Not what you're thinking."

Relief washed over her, and Evelyn awkwardly rubbed the tip of her nose.

But how did Sebastian always know what she was thinking? Did he really have some kind of mind-reading ability?

"Theodore has severe autism," Sebastian's voice dropped lower. "My sister took him to every top specialist, both here and abroad. Nothing worked."

"He doesn’t speak or interact with people. Building blocks are the only thing he’s ever shown interest in."

Evelyn’s heart clenched. Her gaze drifted back to the little boy, now completely absorbed in his blocks.

Such a beautiful child... How could...?

After a moment’s hesitation, she couldn’t help but ask, "Theodore’s father... isn’t he here today?"

Sebastian’s eyes turned icy, his voice laced with undisguised contempt. "He claimed to be busy with work."

"Work?" Evelyn arched a skeptical brow.

Even a business titan like Sebastian could make time. How could his own father use work as an excuse?

She was about to press further when she felt a gentle tug on her sleeve.

Theodore had looked up, his large, dark eyes fixed on her. He scooted over slightly, making space beside him.

Evelyn’s face lit up with delight. She quickly sat down and joined him in building. Sebastian watched from the side, a flicker of surprise in his eyes.

As the party was about to start, Evelyn stood—only for Theodore to immediately rise with her, his small hand clutching her sleeve tightly.

"Would you like to go downstairs with me to find your mom?" she asked softly.

The little boy’s eyes sparkled. He nodded emphatically.

When the three of them appeared at the top of the stairs, Olivia Valdemar nearly dropped her champagne glass.

"Theodore, he..." She stared at her brother in disbelief.

Sebastian smiled faintly—a rare sight. "He likes Ms. Roland."
###Chapter 264

Olivia Valdemar's eyes instantly welled up with tears. The soft touch of Theodore's little hand sent a warm current through her heart.

"Let me try treating Theodore's condition." Evelyn Roland's voice was gentle as flowing water. "It may take some time."

Olivia's throat tightened with emotion. Theodore's progress today felt like sunlight piercing through her gloomy world.

From the corner, Isabella Langley watched coldly, her nails digging deep into her palms.

She pulled out a pre-written note and stopped a passing waiter. "Please give this to the gentleman in the suit."

When Oliver Valrose unfolded the paper, his lips curled into an amused smirk. Adjusting his tie, he strode briskly toward the elevator.

Isabella's crimson lips twisted into a sneer.

At the same moment, Evelyn's phone vibrated abruptly.

"Room 203." A mechanical electronic voice spoke through the receiver.

Olivia inquired with concern, but Evelyn merely shook her head. Her gaze lingered thoughtfully toward the stairwell before excusing herself to the restroom.

Hiking up her skirt with practiced ease, her heels clicked sharply against the marble floor. Outside Room 203, Evelyn drew a steadying breath.

The turning doorknob echoed unnaturally loud in the empty hallway.

Inside, an eerie silence hung under the cold glow of a crystal chandelier. The moment Evelyn stepped forward, the scuff of leather shoes sounded behind her.

The door slammed shut with a resounding thud.

Oliver lunged like a starved wolf, his tie askew. "Evelyn, I knew you'd come."

Evelyn sidestepped with feline grace, her back pressing against the icy wall. Narrowing her eyes, she demanded, "Who sent you?"
###Chapter 265

"Miss Roland, why the prudish act with me?" Oliver Valrose sneered, his gaze roaming over her body with vulgar intent. "We're alone here. No need for pretenses."

He took a step closer, his voice dripping with sleaze.

Evelyn Roland clenched her fists, the air suddenly feeling thick with repulsion.

"Back off." Her eyes turned glacial. "Take one more step and I won't hold back."

"Oh, playing hard to get?" He licked his lips. "You're the one who invited me."

"If you enjoy dangerous games, I'll gladly oblige."

Seeing his determination to assault her, Evelyn gave a cold laugh.

It seemed this scoundrel needed a lesson he'd never forget.

She tossed her designer bag aside and flexed her wrists. The hem of her gown was already knotted neatly behind her, allowing full mobility.

The moment Oliver lunged, she drove her knee upward with brutal precision.

"Ah—!" The man crumpled, his face contorted in agony as he gasped on the floor.

"Exciting enough?" Evelyn tilted her head, danger flashing in her eyes. "Shall we escalate?"

"You bitch!"

Oliver staggered up, his expensive suit now wrinkled beyond recognition. Spittle flew as he hurled obscenities.

Evelyn's gaze sharpened. Kicking off her heels, she advanced and delivered two stinging slaps across his face.

"Still coherent? I must've gone easy on you."

Snatching her bag from the floor, she rained blows upon him. Oliver scrambled like a cornered rat, his curses dissolving into pitiful whimpers.

The commotion drew a crowd outside Room 203. When Olivia Valdemar arrived with the Roland brothers, the hallway was packed.

"Move!" Olivia shoved through the onlookers.

The door swung open to reveal Oliver, battered and bleeding, crawling toward escape—only to be slammed against the wall by Julian Roland's expert restraint.

"Help! This woman's insane!"

All eyes turned to Evelyn, now smoothing her skirt with perfect composure as she slipped back into her heels. Not a hair was out of place—only the faint redness of her knuckles betrayed the violence.

"Evelyn!" Alexander Roland and Olivia rushed forward.

"I'm fine." She gave Olivia's hand a reassuring squeeze and winked at her brother.
###Chapter 266

Oliver Valrose clutched his bleeding nose, crimson droplets seeping between his fingers. His swollen eyes were bloodshot, all traces of his usual aristocratic charm gone.

"You're the one who invited me here!" He glared venomously at Evelyn Roland. "Stop pretending to be some innocent saint!"

Julian Roland's expression darkened. Another brutal punch landed on Oliver's face. The sickening crunch of bone made the guests gasp.

"A note?" Evelyn caught the key detail, stopping her brother mid-swing. "What note?"

Grimacing, Oliver yanked a crumpled paper from his pocket and hurled it at her.

The note arced through the air. Evelyn caught it effortlessly, unfolding it with deliberate slowness.

A soft laugh escaped her lips as she held it up. "Look at this smudged ink." Her slender fingers traced the paper. "Only sweaty palms could blur writing like this."

She suddenly spread her pristine hands under the lights—spotless. "This special ink stains on contact. Yet my hands—"

Whispers erupted before she could finish.

Oliver's face turned ashen. "A server gave it to me!" He jabbed a finger toward the crowd's edge. "Her!"

A uniformed figure was edging toward the exit. Julian moved like lightning, hauling her back like a ragdoll.

Isabella Langley stood beside Alexander Roland, nails digging into her palms. Her venomous gaze locked onto the trembling server.

She'd warned this wretch in the restroom last time...

"Who put you up to this?" Evelyn's voice was glacial.

The server shook like a leaf, head bowed.

"Silence?" Evelyn stepped closer. "Who do you fear more—the Roland heiress, or the adopted daughter?"

The words struck like daggers. The server's head jerked up, her eyes flickering to Isabella's bloodless face. "I-It was Miss Isabella Langley!"

Gasps filled the room.

Isabella staggered back, toppling a champagne tower. Amid shattering glass, she shrieked, "You lying snake!"

"Sister..." She turned tearful eyes to Evelyn. "She's clearly been bribed—"

Evelyn smiled faintly, unfolding the note again. "Notice the signature—just 'Roland.'"

Her gaze settled meaningfully on Isabella. "If you and Oliver are truly in love, why hide it? Father and Mother adore you. They'd never oppose this match."

Isabella stood frozen, as if struck by lightning.
###Chapter 267

Evelyn Roland offered Isabella Langley a reassuring smile, ignoring her stunned silence. "Please excuse us," she said gently. "This was supposed to be Isabella's date with Oliver Valrose. I accidentally walked into the wrong room, causing this misunderstanding."

The onlookers at the door murmured in realization before dispersing.

"So it was Isabella and Mr. Valrose all along. No wonder the invitation only had 'Langley' written on it."

"The Valrose family may not be as prestigious as the Rolands, but Oliver is quite handsome. They make a decent match."

"Let's hope it works out for them."

Isabella's face paled at the whispers. Her ears rang.

Her? With Oliver Valrose?

That playboy?

But it was too late to protest. She couldn’t possibly admit she had set Evelyn up. Swallowing her bitterness, she remained silent.

Sebastian Valdemar lingered at the edge of the crowd, observing Isabella’s expression. He stepped aside to let others pass, his lips pressed into a thin line, amusement flickering in his eyes.

Once the crowd thinned, Olivia Valdemar finally exhaled in relief. Her pregnant belly ached from standing too long, and the commotion in Room 203 had nearly given her a fright.

Evelyn noticed her pallor and quickly helped her sit. "Olivia, are you okay?"

"I'm fine." Olivia squeezed her hand guiltily. "But you must be shaken. I should’ve double-checked the hotel arrangements."

"This is my fault," Evelyn said remorsefully. "I ruined your lovely party."

"Just a minor hiccup." Olivia tenderly rubbed her belly. "The baby’s been calm through it all."

A shadow fell over them.

A man in his early thirties approached, dressed in an impeccably tailored suit. Though unremarkable in looks, he carried an air of mature charm. Yet something about him unsettled Evelyn.

Olivia blinked in surprise before lighting up. "Honey? How did you—"

"Careful!" Evelyn stopped her from standing. "You shouldn’t exert yourself."

The man hurried forward, gently steadying his wife. "Easy. I’m right here."

Olivia settled back, her eyes soft with concern. "Weren’t you in a meeting? Did you rush back? You must be exhausted."

He clasped her hand, his gaze tender. "Seeing you makes it all worth it."
###Chapter 268

A derisive snort came from nearby.

Evelyn Roland turned toward the sound, catching only the retreating figure of Sebastian Valdemar as he walked away.

His tall frame paused at the end of the hallway. It was impossible to tell how long he had been standing there, observing.

Olivia Valdemar seemed unfazed, as if accustomed to such behavior. Suddenly remembering something, she turned to Evelyn with an apologetic smile. "Evelyn, I haven't introduced you yet. This is my husband, Howard Merouin—Theodore's father."

Howard gave a polite nod, his lips curving into a perfectly measured smile.

Evelyn returned the gesture with a faint smile of her own. But as she stepped closer, a delicate, elusive scent drifted toward her.

"Mr. Merouin, your cologne is quite distinctive," she remarked casually. "Is it 'Winter Spice' by Master Matsubara?"

For the briefest moment, Howard's pupils contracted almost imperceptibly.

"You must be mistaken," Olivia interjected with a light laugh. "Howard never wears cologne."

"Perhaps it's from the flight," Howard smoothly wrapped an arm around his wife's shoulders. "Let's go see Theodore. I've missed him."

Evelyn watched them coolly, finally understanding the source of Sebastian's hostility.

"Evelyn should get to know Theodore better too," Olivia suggested.

When the three of them entered the child's room, the little boy was engrossed in a picture book.

"Sweetheart, look who's here?" Olivia called softly.

Howard enthusiastically spread his arms, but Theodore didn't even glance up before darting straight into Evelyn's embrace.

Howard's outstretched arms froze midair before he lowered them with a self-deprecating chuckle and sank onto the sofa. "I suppose I haven't spent enough time with him."

"Don't say that," Olivia immediately took her husband's hand. "Theodore has always been slow to warm up to people."

Touched, Howard pulled his wife into a hug. Evelyn observed the picture-perfect couple, a chill settling in her chest.

What kind of spell had this man cast over Olivia?
###Chapter 269

Evelyn's gaze shifted between Howard and Olivia. Their demeanor appeared natural, yet something felt off. She pressed her lips together subtly.

"Olivia, I'd like to evaluate Theodore alone."

Olivia stiffened, her fingers tightening around Howard's arm.

Howard's lips curled into a knowing smile. "Don't worry, darling. Since Ms. Roland is the expert, we should cooperate with the treatment." He patted Olivia's hand reassuringly. "Theodore will get better."

The way he said "darling" dripped with affection, yet it sent a chill down Evelyn's spine.

As the door clicked shut, Evelyn immediately locked it. Turning around, she found Theodore staring at her with timid eyes.

"Would you like to talk to me, Theodore?"

The little boy's lashes fluttered.

"Mommy..." His voice was barely a whisper. "Mommy holds me when I sleep."

Evelyn's heart softened. She crouched to his eye level. "Your mommy must love you very much."

"But..." Theodore suddenly gripped his shirt, his face turning pale. "Daddy hits me..."

The words stabbed through Evelyn like a knife. She pulled him into a tight embrace, feeling his small body tremble violently.

"Don't be afraid. I'm here." She stroked his back gently. "You're so brave."

The child clutched her collar, hot tears soaking her shoulder. The desperate grip twisted Evelyn's heart—it was the instinctive reaction of a traumatized child.

By the time Theodore fell asleep in her arms, Evelyn's nails had dug deep into her palms. She wiped his tear-stained cheeks, her eyes icy with fury.

Outside, Olivia paced anxiously.

"Evelyn!" She seized Evelyn's wrist. "How is Theodore...?"

Evelyn studied Olivia's red-rimmed eyes—then noticed the faint bruises on her wrist. The pieces clicked into a horrifying truth.

"Olivia," she said softly but firmly. "We need to talk."
###Chapter 270

Evelyn Roland had just stepped out of the children's room when Olivia Valdemar rushed forward eagerly. Behind her stood Howard Merouin in a crisp suit, both staring intently at Evelyn.

"How is he?" Olivia twisted her fingers nervously.

Evelyn shook her head slightly. "It's too early to tell." Her gaze lingered on Howard. "But a child's psychological issues often stem from their home environment. Olivia, may I speak with Mr. Merouin alone?"

Olivia visibly stiffened, instinctively looking at her husband.

Howard squeezed his wife's hand reassuringly. "Go rest. I'll join you after my talk with Ms. Roland." He pressed a kiss to her forehead. "Don't worry."

The moment Olivia left, the warmth in Howard's smile faded.

"What did you want to say, Ms. Roland?"

"Theodore is terrified of you." Evelyn cut straight to the point. "Not just shyness—actual fear."

Howard's eyes flickered. "I travel frequently. It's natural for children to be wary of strangers."

"No." Evelyn took a step closer. "He trembles at the mere mention of you. Mr. Merouin, why would a three-year-old be so afraid of his own father?"

The air turned glacial.

All pretense of politeness vanished from Howard's face. He adjusted his cufflinks with deliberate slowness, his voice icy. "Mind your words, Ms. Roland."

"I'm stating facts." Evelyn held her ground. "If Theodore's condition stems from you, it's my duty to investigate."

"Investigate?" Howard suddenly smiled, though his eyes remained frigid. "I suggest you know your limits. We'll find another specialist for Theodore. Your services are no longer required."

He gestured toward the door.

Evelyn smirked. "I was hired by Mrs. Valdemar. You have no authority to dismiss me." She picked up her bag, pausing to give Howard a meaningful look. "By the way, Theodore drew something quite... interesting earlier."

Howard's pupils constricted.

Evelyn strode toward the exit without looking back. She could feel his venomous gaze coiling around her like a serpent.

The moment the door clicked shut, a deafening crash echoed behind her—the sound of something heavy being hurled against the floor.
###Chapter 271: Walking Together in the Rain

Evelyn Roland strode out of the hotel elevator, her stilettos clicking sharply against the marble floor. Her nails dug unconsciously into her palms. Howard Merouin's smarmy face lingered in her mind, every evasive word he'd spoken seeming to hide some dark secret.

Outside the revolving glass doors, rain fell in a fine, unrelenting mist. She checked her phone—her brothers should be long gone by now. Just as she braced herself to dash into the downpour, steady footsteps sounded behind her.

A black umbrella snapped open above her head.

Sebastian Valdemar appeared at her side without warning, tilting the umbrella slightly in her direction. Raindrops slid down the ribs of the umbrella, leaving dark stains on the shoulders of his impeccably tailored black trench coat. The sharp line of his jaw seemed even more pronounced in the dim light.

"I'm heading that way," he said tersely.

Rain streaked the car windows like winding rivers. The warmth inside the vehicle made her drowsy. Evelyn stared at the blurred neon lights outside before speaking abruptly, "Howard's afraid."

Soft music played in the background. Sebastian tapped his fingers twice against the steering wheel.

"Theodore has an episode every time he sees him," Evelyn continued, turning to face the road ahead. "This isn't just about an absent father."

The traffic light shifted from green to red. Sebastian pressed the brake. In the rhythmic sweep of the windshield wipers, his profile was gilded by the glow of streetlights. "What are you suggesting?"

"Domestic violence? Infidelity?" Her fingers absently traced the seatbelt. "Or something worse."

The sound of tires cutting through water suddenly turned harsh. Sebastian's lips pressed into a thin line, his eyes darker than the night outside. The car's display screen lit up with a new notification.

"Nine tomorrow morning," he said abruptly. "Come to my office. I'll show you the files."

The rain had stopped by the time they reached her home. Evelyn stood at her front door, surprised to find the porch light on. When she turned, Sebastian's car was still idling at the curb, its taillights painting twin red streaks on the wet pavement.

"Sebastian?" she called out before she could stop herself.

The window rolled down. He rested one arm on the sill, his watch glinting coldly under the light. "Something else?"

The night wind carried the scent of osmanthus into the car. Evelyn shook her head, her hair lifting slightly in the breeze. "See you tomorrow."

Only after her slender figure disappeared behind the door did Sebastian start the engine again. His Bluetooth earpiece crackled to life with his assistant's voice. "Sir, we've uncovered Howard's spending records in Los Angeles from three years ago—"

The steering wheel jerked sharply. Tires screeched against asphalt. Sebastian's gaze remained fixed on the rearview mirror, where the Roland estate grew smaller in the distance. His voice was ice. "Keep digging. I want every move he's made in the last five years."
###Chapter 272

Sunlight streamed through the gap in the curtains as Evelyn Roland stretched lazily. She had slept unusually well last night, not even a single dream disturbing her rest.

While washing up, she studied her reflection in the mirror. Her complexion looked much better than before, and the dark circles under her eyes had noticeably faded.

Her phone suddenly vibrated.

"Hello?" She dried her hands and answered.

"The documents are ready," Sebastian Valdemar's voice came through the receiver. "I'll be there in thirty minutes."

After hanging up, Evelyn quickly changed into a light gray tracksuit. She tied her hair into a high ponytail, giving her a crisp, professional look.

The sound of a car engine rumbled in the driveway just as she finished applying sunscreen.

Sebastian was driving a black Range Rover today. Evelyn opened the passenger door and spotted a manila folder on the seat.

"Is this everything?" She fastened her seatbelt and picked up the folder.

"Everything we could find, from birth till now." Sebastian turned the steering wheel. "Focus on the last five years."

Evelyn raised an eyebrow at the thick stack of papers inside. When she reached the third page, she froze.

"Villa Tuscany..." She pointed at two identical addresses. "Domestic and international?"

Sebastian smirked coldly. "I checked it out personally yesterday. It's just a high-end club."

"A club?"

"Outwardly a private residence, but in reality..." He paused. "People are kept there."

Understanding dawned on Evelyn instantly. She flipped to the photos and saw two different women—one of Asian descent, the other blonde with blue eyes.

"One's a Chinese-American, the other's a foreigner." Sebastian's voice was icy. "The timeline matches right before Theodore was born."

Evelyn inhaled sharply. Howard Merouin was keeping mistresses both at home and abroad—how audacious.

"Does Olivia know?" she couldn't help asking.

Sebastian shook his head. "My sister trusts him too much."

Remembering how Olivia had defended Howard last night, Evelyn's heart sank. That kind of loyalty didn't seem fake—it was genuine trust.

"This alone won't be enough," she murmured.

Sebastian gave her an approving glance. "Exactly. My sister would think it's a setup."

As the car merged onto the main road, sunlight spilled through the window onto the documents. Evelyn suddenly noticed a detail.

"Wait..." She pointed at one page. "Howard makes regular monthly transfers to these two accounts."

Sebastian's eyes sharpened. "Did you check the recipients?"

"One is the villa's butler, the other..." She turned the page, and her pupils constricted. "A private hospital."

They exchanged a glance, both realizing the implication.

"Theodore's birth certificate..." Sebastian's voice dropped low. "Might be forged."
###Chapter 273

Evelyn's fingertips trembled slightly.

She stared at the thick stack of documents on the table, her chest heavy as if weighed down by a boulder. Olivia's ever-smiling eyes flashed in her mind, tightening her throat.

"Howard is nothing but a complete fraud."

Sebastian's voice was icy. His slender fingers traced the red-marked dates on the documents, each one horrifying.

"The day Theodore was born, he was popping champagne at a nightclub."

"When Theodore had his first fever and was hospitalized, he was gambling in Macau."

"On your anniversary, he booked an entire hotel floor... with three women."

Evelyn slammed the file shut. The crisp sound of paper echoed sharply in the silent living room.

Howard tenderly helped her remove her coat, his gaze dripping with affection.

Evelyn's stomach churned.

"Olivia." She took a deep breath and pushed the file forward. "Look at this."

Curious, Olivia flipped open the first page. Her smile froze. Howard glanced over her shoulder and paled instantly.

"Darling, this is a setup!" He dropped to his knees, his voice cracking with desperation. "I swear I’ve never done any of this!"

Sebastian let out a cold laugh, his eyes sharp as blades.

Olivia's fingers tightened slowly. The paper crumpled in her grip, emitting a strained rustle.

"Last year, on Theodore’s birthday..." Her voice was barely audible. "You said you were in New York for a meeting."

Beads of sweat formed on Howard’s forehead. "I was! These photos are photoshopped!"

The room plunged into dead silence.

Evelyn watched as Olivia’s eyes slowly reddened, but her spine remained rigid.

"Olivia—"

"Enough." Olivia stood abruptly, shredding the documents in her hands. The white fragments fluttered down like a ridiculous snowstorm.

Howard opened his mouth to protest but was silenced by her glare.

"Get out."

Her voice was soft, yet it plunged the room into icy cold. Evelyn had never seen Olivia like this—a drawn sword, terrifyingly sharp.

Howard scrambled to his feet, stumbling toward the door. Just before it closed, Evelyn caught the venomous glint in his eyes.

"Olivia..." Evelyn reached out, but Olivia gently pushed her away.

Bending down, Olivia picked up a torn piece of paper and suddenly laughed. "I’ve known for a while."

The words struck like thunder.

"Then why—"

"Because of Theodore." Olivia traced the date on the scrap, tears finally falling. "Every time he missed his father, Howard would magically appear."

She lifted her tear-streaked face, a bitter smile on her lips. "How ironic. Even being a good dad was just an act."
###Chapter 274

Sebastian's knuckles turned white as his fists clenched. His burning gaze locked onto his sister's forced composure.

"How long are you going to keep lying to yourself, Olivia?" His voice was low but razor-sharp.

"That scumbag Howard doesn't deserve your forgiveness. You know the truth—you're just refusing to face it. Wake up."

A flicker of triumph crossed Howard's face as he started to rise—until a small figure barreled into him, knocking him flat.

Theodore planted himself protectively in front of his mother, tiny fists balled. His eyes burned red with fury. "Get out! Don't touch Mommy!"

The air turned to ice. Howard sat sprawled on the floor, his expression darkening before twisting into a sickening smile. "Come here, Theo—"

Olivia went deathly pale. She knelt slowly, her voice barely audible. "Who... who hurt you, baby?"

Fat tears rolled down Theodore's cheeks as he pointed a trembling finger. "He took me to see mean lady... She pinched me... slapped me..." His little body shook violently. "Said... said if I tell, he'll make Mommy poor..."

"Lies!" Howard lunged to his feet, face contorted with rage. "You little brat—"

Olivia swung her handbag with all her strength. The blow cracked across his face.

"You monster!" Her scream tore through the room. The bag burst open, scattering its contents. A lipstick rolled to Howard's feet like a drop of blood.

Silence. Evelyn gasped behind her hands. Sebastian's rigid jaw finally relaxed—his sister's reaction exceeded even his expectations.

Howard sat stunned, clutching his cheek. Suddenly he grabbed Theodore's ankle. "Tell them you made it up, son—"

"Don't touch him!" Olivia swayed, her pregnant belly throwing her off balance. Evelyn rushed forward as she doubled over, retching. Cold sweat beaded on her forehead.
###Chapter 275

Olivia Valdemar raised her hand to stop them, her lips curling into a bitter smile.

That smile was more heartbreaking than tears.

"Evelyn, forgive me for this unsightly display."

Evelyn Roland opened her mouth but only shook her head with a sigh.

"Howard, I've known about every single thing you've done these years." Olivia's voice was hoarse. "I never questioned the financial flows from Villa Tuscany."

She bit her lower lip until she tasted blood.

"The lipstick stains on your shirts, the perfume clinging to you—I pretended not to see." Her voice grew fainter. "All because I couldn't let go of the past."

Olivia lowered her head, the light in her eyes dimming.

"But Theodore is my line in the sand."

Her head snapped up, gaze sharp as a blade. "This marriage ends now. You'll return everything you took from me—principal and interest."

A tear traced down her cheek. She wiped it away carelessly.

"See you in court tomorrow."

Howard Merouin's face drained of color.

"Darling!" He dropped to his knees, clutching her legs desperately. "For our child's sake, give me another chance!"

Olivia pried his fingers off one by one.

"Don't touch me." Her voice was glacial. "Disgusting."

Howard collapsed onto the floor, watching his pregnant wife's retreating figure with growing horror.

The mansion. The luxury cars. The social status.

All gifts from Olivia. If she really sued...

He'd be left with nothing.

Bloodshot eyes burned with rage.

That bitch was trying to ruin him!

In a flash of movement, Howard lunged at Olivia.

"Ah!"

Scalp screaming in pain, Olivia was yanked backward. Two brutal slaps cracked across her face.

She staggered, hands clawing uselessly at the air.

The baby!

Evelyn and Sebastian Valdemar rushed forward simultaneously.

"Thud!"

Olivia hit the ground hard. She curled into a fetal position, sweat drenching her clothes instantly.

A spreading crimson stain bloomed beneath her.

"Olivia!" Evelyn dropped to her knees, pressing hard on Olivia's philtrum. "Stay awake! Look at me!"

Behind them came the sickening thuds of fists meeting flesh and Howard's shrieks of pain.

"Sebastian!" Evelyn's voice trembled. "Help her first!"
###Chapter 276

Sebastian's hand hung frozen in midair, his knuckles white as bone. The gruesome wound on his hand wept crimson, droplets splattering onto the floor.

In silence, he scooped up the unconscious Olivia and strode toward the exit. The servants had already whisked Theodore to safety, leaving only wreckage and Howard's barely breathing form in the living room.

The hospital corridor reeked of antiseptic.

When the operating light flickered on, Sebastian slammed his back against the wall. He stared at his bloodstained hands—the dark stains looked like indelible proof of his sins.

Evelyn stood nearby, the metallic tang of exertion still clinging to her throat.

She'd never seen Sebastian like this—the always-composed man now curled in the corner like a wounded beast, his shoulders heaving violently.

"Olivia will be fine." Kneeling, she began wiping the blood from his hands with a damp cloth.

Sebastian's head snapped up. His bloodshot eyes burned into hers, desperate for reassurance.

Then he yanked her into his arms.

"I can't lose her." His voice was raw, his breath scorching against her neck.

Evelyn stiffened briefly before returning the embrace. "I promise," she whispered. "Even if Death comes, I'll drag her back."

The hallway lights flickered.

His grip tightened until Evelyn gently pushed away. "Let me check inside." She nodded toward the OR. "I know the director."

Sebastian released her slowly, clarity returning to his gaze. "Howard..." he rasped.

"Leave him to me." Squeezing his hand, she added, "Olivia needs you strong."

The contact made them both freeze.

Suddenly he pulled her back into a crushing embrace. Evelyn felt his heart hammering against her.

"I'll be right back," he murmured, his warm breath grazing her ear.

She watched him disappear down the corridor. The OR light still glowed. Taking a deep breath, Evelyn turned and pushed through the staff entrance.
###Chapter 277

Sebastian Valdemar's tall figure cast a long shadow under the corridor lights. He took one last look at the glaring red light above the operating room before turning away, his polished shoes clicking urgently against the floor.

From the shadows of the corner, a pair of eyes observed everything.

Evelyn Roland strode swiftly through the sterilization corridor, the hem of her white coat fluttering. She pulled on sterile gloves with practiced ease, though her fingertips trembled slightly.

"The fetus has..." The nurse hesitated, then turned her face away as she handed over the surgical gown.

Under the surgical lights, Olivia Valdemar's pale face looked as fragile as paper. The monitor emitted a shrill alarm as her blood pressure continued to plummet.

"Hemostat." Evelyn's voice was terrifyingly calm.

The lead surgeon's forehead beaded with sweat. "Dr. Roland, the blood loss is too severe—"

"I said, hemostat."

The scalpel in her hand traced a precise arc. Blood splattered across her goggles, but she didn't even blink.

"Olivia, can you hear me?" Evelyn suddenly raised her voice. "Howard is filing for custody of Theodore."

The EKG on the monitor spiked violently.

"Howard will move into the Valdemar estate with that woman who hit you." Her hands never stopped working, but her voice softened. "Do you really want Theodore calling another woman 'Mom'?"

A single tear slid from the corner of Olivia's tightly shut eyes.

"Blood pressure rising!"
"Prepare for transfusion, now!"

The operating room erupted into frantic activity. Only when the lines on the monitor stabilized did Evelyn realize her back was drenched in cold sweat.

Meanwhile, at the Valdemar mansion.

Howard Merouin struggled to rise from the pool of blood, his ribs screaming with excruciating pain. He fumbled for his phone—thirty-seven missed calls lit up the screen.

All from his lawyer.

The latest text message froze the blood in his veins: "Ms. Valdemar suffered a miscarriage with severe hemorrhaging. Currently in critical condition."

The phone clattered to the floor. Howard suddenly remembered the look in Sebastian's eyes before he left—it wasn't anger.

It was the look one gives a dead man.
###Chapter 278

Howard Merouin struggled to his feet, the metallic taste of blood filling his mouth. He spat out a mouthful of bloody saliva, a broken tooth mixed in.

Just as he was about to leave, he suddenly stopped.

"You little brat, come with me!" He yanked Theodore up roughly. The child trembled at the sight of his blood-covered body, squeezing his eyes shut in fear.

Howard collapsed, unconscious.

Olivia Valdemar's condition had finally stabilized.

"Give me the medication." She reached out for the bottle the nurse handed her.

"This isn't the right drug!" Her voice sharpened. "It's been switched!"

"Go get the correct one!" Another nurse reacted swiftly, sprinting away.

Minutes later, the surgery was completed successfully.

Leaning against the wall to catch her breath, Evelyn suddenly remembered something and rushed to the surveillance room.

On the way, she ran into Alexander Roland. Together, they pulled up the security footage.

The screen showed a woman in a nurse's uniform sneaking in and tampering with the medication.

"Isabella Langley!" Evelyn slammed her fist on the table.

They raced downstairs just as Isabella was attempting to leave.

Slap! A sharp crack echoed through the hallway.

Isabella clutched her cheek, tears instantly welling up. "Third Brother, she hit me!"

"It's all on camera." Alexander's voice was frigid. "Still denying it?"

"I didn't do anything!" Isabella sobbed dramatically, though her eyes darted nervously. "You're framing me!"

Evelyn grabbed her collar and yanked her forward. "You nearly killed someone!"
###Chapter 279

Isabella's fingertips trembled slightly.

She had deliberately changed into a nurse's uniform identical to the hospital staff. The mask and cap concealed her face completely, leaving only her eyes visible. The disguise should have been flawless in the hospital corridor.

But she hadn't counted on running into Alexander.

"Alex..." Her voice wavered, a cold sweat breaking out down her back. From the corner of her eye, she saw Evelyn's clenched fist and instinctively took half a step back. "It really wasn't me."

"The surveillance footage says otherwise." Evelyn thrust her phone forward, the screen displaying crystal-clear video evidence. She grabbed Isabella by the collar, shoving the phone in her face. "Do you know what this medication does? It could have killed someone!"

Isabella's pupils constricted.

The footage showed her sneaking around, the exact moment she switched the medication bottles. Worse still, the birthmark on her wrist was clearly visible.

"I've overlooked your petty schemes before," Evelyn hissed, each word dripping with ice. "But this? This is attempted murder."

The accusation hit Isabella like a sledgehammer. Her legs nearly gave out. Desperate, she turned to Alexander—only to meet his utterly disappointed gaze.

"Alex..." She clutched at his sleeve, tears welling up. "I know I was wrong. Please don't tell Mom and Dad—"

Evelyn suddenly released her, stepping back as if touching something filthy. With one last glance at Alexander, she turned on her heel and walked away.

The sharp click of her heels against the tile echoed through the hallway.

"Alex!" Panic set in fully now. Tears streamed down Isabella's face. "I swear it won't happen again, please—"

Her nails dug into his sleeve, turning her knuckles white.

A beam of light from the window at the end of the corridor illuminated Alexander's conflicted profile.
###Chapter 280

Isabella's eyes shimmered with hopeful anticipation.

Facing the person who had called him "brother" for over two decades, Alexander couldn't bring himself to be cruel.

His slender fingers gently pried hers from his sleeve. As he turned, a cold breeze swept past.

"Mom!" Isabella cut her off sharply, her nails leaving creases in the tablecloth.

Amid the chatter, no one noticed the drop of blood welling from Isabella's bitten lip.
###Chapter 281

Evelyn's spoon clattered into her bowl with a sharp metallic ring.

###Chapter 282

The night deepened, neon lights painting the city in a kaleidoscope of colors.

Should he tell her?

###Chapter 283

Evelyn Roland frowned slightly, her gaze lingering on Sebastian Valdemar's face for a moment. The man's expression was clearly off, but since he claimed nothing was wrong, she didn't press further.

Under the soft lighting, Sebastian's fingers tapped absently against the table. The formidable business tycoon seemed uncharacteristically restless.

###Chapter 285

###Chapter 286

I stood by the floor-to-ceiling window, gazing at the ink-black night outside.

Sebastian would officially take over Valdemar Group.

9 AM tomorrow, top-floor conference room at Valdemar Tower.

"I'm here."

The storm was coming.

Dorian Wayne's carefree smile froze abruptly.

His brows furrowed slightly, eyes sharpening like blades.

Calvin Lee recounted the events calmly before asking, "Was my action too reckless?"

Calvin Lee nodded approvingly. "Precisely. Prince Ning tested my resolve. Now he's lost both his pawn and his advantage."

"Await Prince Ning's indignant confrontation," Calvin Lee replied impassively.
