###Chapter 291

Sebastian had never been this close to Evelyn before. Her sleeping face was mere inches away, making his breath hitch. Even the fine down on her cheeks was visible, glowing softly under the light.

His gaze lingered on her slightly parted lips, the rosy hue like a silent invitation. Before he realized it, he leaned in, his pulse pounding loud in his ears.

Just as their lips were about to meet, Evelyn's eyes fluttered open.

"You..." Her voice was drowsy, laced with sleep. "What are you doing?"

Sebastian froze, his Adam's apple bobbing. He straightened abruptly, the tips of his ears turning pink.

"Why is your face so red?" Evelyn's attention snapped to his flushed skin. She propped herself up, her warm breath brushing his neck.

He instinctively moved back, but she cupped his face with both hands.

"Don't move." She frowned, studying the rapid spread of crimson across his cheeks, down to his neck, as if flames were licking his skin.

Her expression turned serious. "This isn't normal."

She hurried to the medical cabinet, rummaging for supplies. Sebastian watched her bustling figure, his gaze darkening.

"Lie down." She returned with a stethoscope, gesturing to the couch.

Sebastian arched a brow. "Here?"

"Don't overthink it." Evelyn remained stern. "I need to check your vitals. It might be a toxin reaction."

The cold metal of the stethoscope pressed against his chest as she listened intently. Her fingers accidentally grazed his skin, sending a shiver through him.

"Does this hurt?" She pressed lightly on his abdomen.

Sebastian's throat tightened. "No."

As the examination continued, his flush only deepened. Evelyn bit her lower lip, baffled.

"Ms. Roland." Sebastian finally spoke, his voice rough.

She looked up, questioning.

"I'm just..." He cleared his throat. "Not used to being this close to someone."

Evelyn blinked, then burst into laughter, her eyes crinkling. The sight made Sebastian's heart skip another beat.

"So the mighty Sebastian Valdemar is easily flustered?" She deliberately leaned closer, amused by the way his jaw tensed.

Who would have thought the formidable business tycoon had such an adorable side? The discovery inexplicably lifted her mood.
###Chapter 292

The moment Evelyn's fingertips brushed against Sebastian's chest, she felt his muscles tense instantly.

A mischievous glint flashed in her eyes.

"Mr. Valdemar," she drawled, her crimson lips nearly grazing his earlobe, "don't tell me... you've never been in a relationship before?"

The tips of Sebastian's ears turned visibly red.

His reaction only fueled Evelyn's playful mood. She leaned in closer, tracing slow circles on his chest with her delicate fingers.

Bang—

The door swung open abruptly.

Bianca stood frozen, her files scattering across the floor. Behind her, Theodore gasped so sharply his phone slipped from his grasp and shattered.

The air turned to ice.

"M-Master..." Bianca stammered, "I came to discuss the wine tasting competition..."

Evelyn straightened with effortless grace, as if nothing had happened.

"Wait for me in the conservatory."

Once the two left, only Sebastian and Theodore remained in the room.

The atmosphere plummeted to subzero temperatures.

"Contract." Sebastian's voice could have frozen hell itself.

Theodore trembled as he handed over the documents, not daring to meet his boss's gaze.

After signing, Sebastian adjusted his suit jacket, the crystal cufflinks gleaming like frost under the light.

"Business emergency. I'm leaving."

Outside the winery gates, Theodore finally cracked. "Sir, about you and Ms. Roland—"

"Silence."

One icy glare from Sebastian, and Theodore sealed his lips.

Meanwhile, inside Château Blanc, Bianca blinked rapidly.

"Master, that was—"

"Focus on the matter at hand." Evelyn flipped open the file, her fingers tapping lightly against the pages.

Bianca swallowed her burning curiosity.

The day of the competition arrived swiftly.

By 8 AM, Château Blanc buzzed with activity.

The parking lot overflowed with limited-edition supercars, each worth more than a luxury penthouse.

Staff guided VIP guests with practiced efficiency.

"Your invitation, please."

Every visitor caught the faint aroma of grapes lingering in the air.

Evelyn stood before the floor-to-ceiling windows on the second floor, surveying the bustling crowd below.

She'd chosen a champagne-colored gown today, the diamonds sewn into the skirt catching the light with every movement.

Everything was ready.

Now, the show could begin.
###Chapter 293

"The aesthetic of this winery is truly distinctive."

Guests murmured in admiration as they entered the meticulously arranged guest rooms.

A sleek black luxury sedan glided into Château Blanc. The door opened, revealing a middle-aged man with golden hair and piercing blue eyes.

"It's Mr. Ross!"

Gasps rippled through the crowd. As an internationally renowned master sommelier, Ross's presence instantly commanded attention.

Organizing committee members hesitated, eager to greet him, but faltered at his aloof expression.

Ross surveyed the surroundings, his gaze lingering on the winery's architecture. A faint smile touched his lips.

"Let's proceed."

Staff remained composed despite the VIP's arrival, offering only polite glances before resuming their duties.

At the entrance, a staff member politely stopped him. "Sir, may I see your invitation?"

"Please enter." The staff member verified it with professional detachment before turning to the next guest.

This subtle display of impartiality made Ross's eyes flicker with surprise. He glanced back at the upright, focused staff—none distracted by his fame.

"Master Ross?" His assistant noticed his pause.

"Let's go." Ross strode toward the tasting hall beside the main building.

Inside, guests mingled in small groups, the atmosphere convivial yet refined.

A uniformed middle-aged man stepped to the center, followed by a young waiter pushing a cart.

"Welcome to Château Blanc. Our proprietor has prepared a small token of appreciation."

At his signal, the waiter began distributing two exquisite gift boxes to each guest.

One contained delicate pastries, the other two bottles of premium wine.

Connoisseurs instantly recognized the wine's value—each bottle worth at least five figures.

"My god, this is beyond generous!" The assistant whispered, mentally calculating the gifts' total worth.

But Ross's attention was drawn to the pastries. He noticed each guest's selection seemed unique.

"Master, could it be—" The assistant stared at the familiar hometown pastry before him, speechless.

"Finally catching on." Ross scoffed softly, sampling a piece. A spark of delight flashed in his eyes.

Once gifts were distributed, the middle-aged man smiled. "After your journey, please retire to your rooms and rest."
###Chapter 294

"Mr. Macmillan, this is your room."

The staff member led Ross to the third floor. As the door opened, a faint trace of soothing incense drifted through the air.

Ross narrowed his eyes slightly.

This Miss Roland... was rather intriguing.

After settling in, Ross changed into casual attire and strolled through the winery.

All committee members had arrived, yet the reception staff remained energetic, their smiles genuine and warm.

In the garden pavilion, several employees immediately stood and greeted him with poised yet relaxed manners.

Ross found himself curious. "You seem to enjoy working here?"

"Yes, we're treated with dignity here," a waitress replied, her eyes bright.

"At my last job, people looked down on servers," a younger employee added. "But Miss Roland taught us that no job is beneath anyone."

An older staff member's eyes grew moist. "I wanted to end my life... until she gave me a new purpose."

Ross listened quietly, his expression softening.

"Keep up the good work," he murmured as he stood. "Château Blanc is worthy of your pride."

Over the next two days, Ross's astonishment grew.

He'd seen countless performative philanthropists, but Evelyn Roland's sincerity couldn't be faked.

From her employees' devotion to every meticulous detail, this young winery owner displayed not just competence, but rare integrity.

Perhaps this partnership would exceed his expectations.

Morning light spilled into the hall as Sebastian approached Evelyn's resting form on the sofa.

"Tired?" he asked softly.

She shook her head. "You're the one who's lost weight again."

Before Sebastian could respond, his posture stiffened.

"Uncle?"

A middle-aged man stood at the entrance with a polite smile. "Long time no see, Sebastian."

Vincent Valdemar's gaze slid past his nephew, settling on Evelyn. "At last we meet, Miss Roland."
###Chapter 295

Vincent Valdemar extended his slender fingers. Evelyn Roland grasped them without hesitation. She lifted her gaze to meet the middle-aged man across from them, the corners of her eyes tilting slightly.

"Uncle, you came?" Sebastian Valdemar's tone was deferential.

The man stroked his beard. "I heard the competition was being held domestically this time, so I returned. At my age, I don't plan on traveling anymore."

"This way, please."

Preparations for the International Wine Tasting Championship proceeded with military precision. Contestants stood ready, awaiting the mandatory pre-entry inspection—an anti-cheating tradition.

Evelyn followed protocol step by step. Though everything was under control, an inexplicable tension coiled in her chest. Her right eyelid twitched incessantly, as if foretelling impending disaster.

"What is this?"

A staff member's sharp exclamation sliced through the air. All eyes snapped toward the commotion.

Evelyn hurried forward. When she saw Bianca Savigny at the center of the crowd, her pupils constricted violently.

She refused to believe Bianca would ever cheat.

The official brandished a small pill. "Contestant Bianca Savigny, explain why you're carrying a banned stimulant!"

Bianca's panicked gaze darted around. "It's not mine! I don't know how it got on me—"

The young woman trembled under the scrutiny, her voice shaking.

Evelyn stepped between them. "There must be some mistake."

"Ha! Everyone knows you're close. You'd cover for her even if she cheated!"

"Exactly! This is unfair to other contestants!"

The murmurs swelled like a tidal wave, engulfing them both.

"Château Blanc resorting to such dirty tricks? Disgraceful."

"That winery should be shut down!"

Ross Macmillan had been waiting quietly for the event's start. The disturbance caught his attention. After assessing the situation, his brow furrowed as he observed the spectacle with cold detachment.

A flustered organizer approached. "Mr. Macmillan, a minor incident has occurred. Please wait in the lounge—"

Ross ignored him. His piercing gaze locked onto Evelyn like a hawk sighting prey.
###Chapter 296

"Miss Roland, you owe me an explanation."

Sebastian Valdemar's voice cut through the air like ice, his sharp gaze sweeping across the room. The doping scandal at the International Wine Tasting Championship was nothing short of an insult to the entire industry.

"If your people are proven guilty of cheating," he paused, his tone dropping even colder, "everyone here today will become a laughingstock."

Bianca Savigny paled, her delicate fingers gripping the hem of her dress.

"I didn't do it!" Her voice trembled. "I know nothing about any stimulants—"

A staff member cut her off roughly. "Still denying it with solid evidence right here?"

Bianca stumbled back, tears welling in her eyes. She looked to Evelyn Roland for help, like a frightened fawn.

Sebastian suddenly strode toward Evelyn. Under the stunned gazes of the crowd, he stopped beside her.

"Silence."

Two simple words, yet they instantly hushed the noisy hall.

His cold eyes swept the room before settling on the aggressive staff member.

"Right now, the priority is tracing the source of the stimulant," he said quietly, each word deliberate. "Not making baseless accusations against the winery's representative."

The room fell dead silent. Everyone knew the consequences of crossing the Valdemar Group.

Sebastian shifted slightly, shielding Evelyn behind him. The unconscious gesture warmed her heart.

Ross Macmillan spoke up. "Mr. Valdemar, we need the truth."

"If this is a frame-up, clear the contestant's name. If proven true," he gave Bianca a pointed look, "such people don't belong in this industry."

Bianca could no longer hold back her sobs.

"Everyone!" Evelyn stepped forward. "This is clearly a plot against Château Blanc!"

Someone in the crowd scoffed. "Proof? Anyone can make empty claims."

Just then, Sebastian's phone vibrated. Reading the message, his lips curled into a cold smile.

"Proof?" He raised his phone. "Surveillance footage shows someone tampering with the contestant's bag when she wasn't looking."

The screen displayed the video: a masked woman slipping something into Bianca's bag furtively.

Gasps filled the room.

Evelyn seized the moment. "Now, it's someone else's turn to give us an explanation."
###Chapter 297

A faint smile played on Evelyn Roland's lips, her eyes gleaming with quiet confidence.

"The evidence is right here." Her cool voice instantly silenced the entire venue.

All eyes locked onto the striking woman. Even Bianca Savigny stared at her mentor in stunned silence.

The room erupted in chaos.

Before she could process it, Evelyn produced a medical certificate confirming the allergy.

"Who's to say that document isn't forged?" someone sneered from the crowd.

The blatant provocation made Evelyn's eyes narrow.

Just as she prepared to counter, Bianca stepped forward.

"Then I'll prove it myself." Her voice trembled slightly but held firm.

Evelyn's brow furrowed. Meeting Bianca's determined gaze, she gave a subtle nod.

A staff member quickly brought the injection.

The moment the needle pierced her skin, angry red welts erupted across Bianca's arm. Her breathing turned ragged.

Evelyn swiftly administered antihistamines before turning to face the crowd.

"Any more doubts?"

Dead silence.

Though vindicated, Bianca was still forced to withdraw from the competition.

Then Evelyn spoke again. "I'll take her place."

Gasps rippled through the audience.

The rules allowed substitutions, especially under extenuating circumstances.

"Pathetic performance," came a derisive chuckle from the shadows.

A hulking man stood there, surveying Evelyn with open contempt.

"Dominic, this..." His associate hesitated.

The man—Dominic Laurent—snorted, his disdain deepening.
###Chapter 298

"Château Blanc still dares to compete?" Dominic Laurent scoffed, tapping his fingers on the table. "If I were them, I'd have crawled into a hole by now."

His lackey immediately chimed in, "You're absolutely right, Dom! That woman isn't even fit to polish your shoes."

Dominic smirked in satisfaction. As the rising star of the sommelier world, he'd always looked down on everyone. The earlier fiasco only deepened his disdain for Evelyn Roland.

The competition began promptly. The first round was white wine tasting.

"Contestants must identify the alcohol content, ingredients, and aging period of each sample," the host announced, his gaze flickering between Dominic and Evelyn.

All eyes were on the pair—Dominic, the acknowledged prodigy, and Evelyn, representing the disgraced winery.

Evelyn remained composed. She lifted the glass and drank in one smooth motion. The wine swirled across her palate as she pressed her tongue against the roof of her mouth. Every detail of the vintage crystallized in her mind.

From the audience, Sebastian Valdemar's piercing gaze never left her. Bathed in stage lights, Evelyn seemed to glow, her focused expression strikingly beautiful. The usual coldness in his eyes softened imperceptibly.

"Brilliant!" Ross Macmillan couldn't help murmuring in admiration.

When the first round concluded, Evelyn won by a narrow margin. Dominic's face darkened—a single miscalculation on the final sample had cost him victory.

"Impossible!" He clenched his fists but dared not make a scene.

Yet Evelyn frowned. The aftertaste of one competition sample lingered—a faint trace of industrial alcohol lurking beneath the vintage's richness like a hidden viper.

This was wrong. Competition wines underwent rigorous screening. How could industrial alcohol appear?

She strode toward Sebastian. The man had reverted to his usual unapproachable demeanor, the earlier warmth in his eyes gone as if imagined.

"The wine was tainted," she stated bluntly. "I detected industrial alcohol."

Sebastian's gaze turned glacial, the air around him dropping several degrees. "Certain?"

"Absolutely." Her voice brooked no argument. "We need to trace the source immediately."

Their eyes met, and they spoke simultaneously: "To the winery."
###Chapter 299

Their eyes met in silent understanding.

Sebastian Valdemar tapped the table with his slender fingers, a sharp glint flashing in his gaze.

"Let's go." His lips barely moved.

Posing as business partners, they slipped effortlessly into the winery's restricted area.

Evelyn Roland headed straight for the competition wines, her fingertips grazing the edge of a barrel.

"Something's off." Her eyes narrowed.

The once-clear liquid now held faint, murky particles.

Sebastian bent closer, inhaling slightly.

"Industrial alcohol." His voice turned icy.

Evelyn scanned the room, then froze at the ceiling fixtures.

"Wait." She strode to the corner.

The candlesticks weren't filled with wax—but flammable oil.

"They're planning an explosion." The air around Sebastian dropped to subzero.

His jaw clenched, storms brewing in his darkened eyes.

Evelyn's fingers went cold.

If this plot succeeded, the entire tasting event would be destroyed.

Château Blanc's century-old reputation would burn to ashes.

"Someone's targeting us," she murmured.

Sebastian gave a humorless laugh. "Bold move."

Hurried footsteps approached.

"What are you doing here?" Vincent Valdemar panted as he rushed over. "The awards ceremony is starting!"

Beads of sweat dotted his forehead. His eyes darted nervously.

Sebastian studied his uncle through slitted lids, silent and calculating.
###Chapter 300

Sebastian Valdemar spoke calmly, "Uncle Vincent, don't worry. We're just checking some documents and will return soon."

Vincent Valdemar's forehead glistened with sweat, his chest rising and falling rapidly. "I understand young people have their own ideas. But the competition is still ongoing. If Miss Roland is absent too long as a contestant, it might raise eyebrows."

"Understood. We'll head back now." Sebastian gave a slight nod.

His words were half-truths. Rather than fearing outsiders' gossip, Vincent was more curious about what schemes his nephew and Evelyn Roland might be brewing.

After discovering some wine vats had been replaced with industrial alcohol, the two immediately realized someone was sabotaging the tasting event.

With no time to source enough high-quality wine to fill the gap, this flaw could plunge the entire competition into crisis.

On the way back, Vincent couldn't help but smirk at the thought of their helpless expressions.

He was eager to see what tricks Evelyn could possibly pull off to save the situation this time!

The first day's competition concluded amidst undercurrents of tension.

As the winery's partner, Sebastian accompanied Evelyn to arrange guest accommodations at the hotel for the next day.

As night deepened, he noticed her standing alone on the terrace, silently gazing at the distant coastline.

After a moment's hesitation, he approached.

"Don't worry too much about the wine," Sebastian said in a low voice. "Now that we've found the issue, we'll fix it in time. I'll contact some friends tonight to see if we can secure a batch of quality wine for emergency use."

The sea breeze tousled Evelyn's hair. At his words, a faint smile—rare for her typically cool demeanor—touched her lips.

"You're helping me?" She turned to ask.

Sebastian seldom saw any expression on her face besides indifference. Now, her smile glowed vividly in the night, tightening his throat.

"Yeah," he managed stiffly.

Evelyn shook her head lightly. "I've already made arrangements."

She spoke truthfully. While everyone dispersed earlier, she'd immediately contacted an overseas friend who'd arranged for a shipment of premium wine via private jet without hesitation.

Watching her composed demeanor, Sebastian felt inexplicably irritated. This woman always stood alone, never needing anyone's aid.

The realization weighed heavily on his chest.

The next day's tasting event commenced as scheduled.

###Chapter 301

The second day of the competition buzzed with even more energy than the first.

Evelyn Roland arrived two hours early, triple-checking every detail. Only when satisfied did she allow herself a brief moment of relief.

Before the second round began, contestants drew lots to reseat themselves.

Nearly losing to this woman yesterday had been an unbearable humiliation.

Today, he would reclaim his pride.

Someone was drugging the drink!

###Chapter 302

"Allow me to explain." Evelyn Roland's voice cut through the noisy venue with clarity. "Mr. Laurent's wine was tainted. Had he consumed it, the consequences would have been dire. Given his prejudice against me, conventional persuasion wouldn't work. I had no choice but to resort to this method."

"This is competition-grade wine. What possible issue could there be? At least make your lies believable."

###Chapter 303

Scheming?

###Chapter 306

Evelyn glanced at the data and gave her shoulder a light pat. "Go rest. Your dark circles could touch the floor."

The stress had taken its toll. Even Bianca's usually vibrant eyes had dulled.

"You should rest too, Master." For once, Bianca didn't cling. She kicked off her shoes and flopped onto the sofa.

"Ahhh! We did it!"

Thankfully, the penthouse had soundproofing. Otherwise, her shrieks would've summoned security.

Bianca bolted upright and grabbed her phone.

"Château Blanc" now topped the trending list.

The official account's comments were buried under purchase requests. The hateful remarks had vanished without a trace.

Meanwhile, in a luxury villa, a man smashed his wineglass against the wall.

"Flood the platforms with trolls! Buy more bots! Mask the IPs!"

But it was too late.

The storm around "Château Blanc" had already taken over every platform—Instagram, Twitter, Reddit—all of them.

"Useless! Can't even handle one woman!" His bloodshot eyes burned with rage.

His subordinates cowered. "We never expected her to go live..."

"Get out!"

Once alone, the man's lips twisted into a chilling smile. "Interesting... Miss Roland of the Roland family. It's been a while since I've had such a worthy opponent."

His laughter echoed through the empty hall, sending shivers down the spine.
###Chapter 321

The man stared at the wreckage strewn across the floor, his lips pressed into a thin line. A predatory glint flickered in his eyes, like a beast that had finally caught the scent of its prey after lying in wait for too long.

"Evelyn Roland, you'd better stay alive." He ran his tongue over his molars. "Who else would entertain me?"

"Achoo—"

"Achoo!"

Evelyn sneezed twice the moment she stepped into the villa. Rubbing the tip of her nose, a cold glint flashed in her eyes.

"Seems someone's thinking about me."

She pulled out her phone, her fingers gliding over the screen. The trending list was flooded with news about Château Blanc. After a quick glance, she locked the screen.

The doorbell rang abruptly.

The surveillance feed showed Julian Roland standing at the entrance.

"Second Brother." She opened the door.

Julian's gaze softened as he raised his hand to pinch her cheek, but he paused mid-air. Glancing at his rough palm, he retracted it casually.

"That's my sister for you." He smiled.

"Business?" Evelyn cut straight to the point.

Julian produced several velvet boxes like a magician. The dazzling jewels shimmered under the light.

"From Alexander. He's been swamped lately."

"Thank Third Brother for me."

Evelyn's expression remained indifferent, as if the treasures before her were cheap trinkets.

Her phone buzzed.

A transfer notification from Alexander popped up, followed by eight zeros.

"Alexander is still as stingy as ever." Julian scoffed and tapped his screen twice.

Evelyn's phone chimed again.

This time, nine zeros.

"Second Brother!" She massaged her temples in exasperation.

Julian pulled out a long case like it was a magic trick. Inside lay a customized pistol resting on velvet.

"This..."

"Your legal permit is already processed." Julian pressed down on her hesitant hand. "But promise me—only in life-or-death situations."

Evelyn's eyes lit up as she ran her fingers over the weapon with reverence. "Thank you, Second Brother."

"One more thing."

Julian handed her a flash drive. Evelyn plugged it into her laptop, her fingers flying across the keyboard. A grainy surveillance video began to play.

###Chapter 322
The blue glow of the computer screen cast shadows across Evelyn Roland's face, deepening the intensity in her eyes.

"Take a close look at the surveillance footage from competition day."

She lounged carelessly on the leather sofa, twirling a pen between her slender fingers.

Julian Roland accepted the tablet, his lips curling into a faint smirk.

The footage was shaky, captured from an awkward angle.

Blurred figures moved through the corridors of Château Blanc, the camera jerking unpredictably.

She'd missed it during her first viewing, but now the anomaly stood out.

Not the face—but the distinct cut of that tailored suit.

She remembered it clearly. Vincent Valdemar had worn that exact outfit that day.

"Julian, do you recognize him?"

Evelyn tilted her head, fingertips drumming lightly on the table.

Her brother's gaze turned glacial.

"The third Valdemar heir."

The air thickened instantly.

"Just as I thought."

A derisive snort escaped her, cold fury flashing in her eyes.

Julian's knuckles cracked audibly.

The arrogant message left at the winery resurfaced in his memory.

"Suicidal."

The word hissed through his clenched teeth.

Every military officer knew how terrifying Julian Roland became when provoked.

Clearly, Vincent Valdemar didn't.

"Fascinating."

Evelyn replayed the video for confirmation.

When she turned, she noticed her brother's unsettling stillness.

"Julian."

She unwrapped a peppermint candy and pressed it between his lips.

"Don't dirty your hands. I'll handle this."

Sweetness spread across Julian's tongue. The tension in his shoulders eased slightly.

"Fine."

His eyes remained locked on the screen as he crushed the candy between his teeth.

"Make sure he never leaves this city."
###Chapter 323

"I adore both gifts, Julian."

Evelyn Roland toyed with the exquisite gift box, a faint smile playing on her lips.

Julian Roland's eyes softened as he ruffled her hair. "Since when do you stand on ceremony with me? Rest now. I'll handle the rest."

His gaze lingered on her tired expression. "You look exhausted."

Evelyn shot an exasperated glance at Bianca Savigny beside her.

The dark circles were clearly on Bianca's face.

"Be good."

Faced with her overprotective brother, she felt both touched and helpless.

A black sedan had been waiting outside when they stepped out.

A cold smile curled her lips, eyes glinting dangerously.

Back in the living room, she sank into the sofa, replaying the video footage.

"Sebastian Valdemar... what will you choose?"

Her heart gave an odd flutter at the thought of his pale face.

"Since when did you become so indecisive, Evelyn Roland?"

Shaking her head with self-mockery, she yanked out the USB drive and grabbed her purse.

Château Blanc.

"Good afternoon, Madame!"

A gardener hastily removed his hat in greeting.

"Stay hydrated in this heat."

She nodded courteously, her gaze sweeping over the sun-scorched flowerbeds.

As she walked down the corridor, she missed the gardener's thoughtful stare.

The main hall blazed with light.
###Chapter 324

Bianca Savigny stretched lazily, nearly colliding with a figure as she pushed open her door.

......

Vincent Valdemar had just returned to the country—too new to act alone.

The last lead had vanished.
###Chapter 325

Evelyn Roland abruptly stood from her seat, fingers tapping lightly on the desk.

The only lead had snapped.

Whoever was behind this was both ruthless and meticulous.

Five minutes later.

###Chapter 326

Bianca Savigny twisted her fingers nervously, trying to change the subject. Evelyn Roland's gaze swept over her in silence.

The surveillance footage was unnervingly clear.

When Evelyn first took over Château Blanc, she spared no expense upgrading the entire security system. Now, every minute detail was captured in high definition.

The timestamp read 6:03 AM.

A man in gray athletic wear appeared on screen, his headphone cord swaying with each step.

"That's him."

The waiter had evaporated without a trace.

"Yes."

Evelyn's reply was absolute.

Too perfectly.

Poisoned wine. A missing employee. Vincent's appearance. These weren't coincidences.

Why had the man shown her such unusual kindness? How had he become a judge? Why had even Sebastian been unaware of his travel plans?

Questions exploded in Evelyn's mind as her fingers clenched unconsciously.

"Mentor?"

Bianca worriedly clung to her arm.

"It's nothing."

"Interesting."

Evelyn's smile turned icy. Of all Château Blanc's staff, why had Vincent Valdemar chosen this one?
###Chapter 327

A bolt of lightning split the sky.

Inside the room, the mentor and apprentice sitting across from each other simultaneously looked up toward the window.

The sky darkened abruptly, thick as ink.

Heavy storm clouds hung oppressively low, as if they might collapse at any moment. A fierce wind whipped up fallen leaves, the temperature plummeted, and the swirling black clouds overhead promised a torrential downpour.

"Boom—"

The thunderclap was deafening.

Lightning illuminated the entire sky, its blinding white light forcing eyes shut.

Bianca Savigny shuddered, her fingers unconsciously clutching the hem of her dress.

Evelyn Roland's gaze darkened.

She stared at the pouring rain outside, her thoughts turbulent. How should she broach the subject of that video with Sebastian Valdemar? Once the investigation began, it would inevitably alert him.

She bit her lip, her delicate face scrunched with concern.

"Worried Mr. Valdemar might act on emotion."

Evelyn's expression tightened. She had indeed underestimated Sebastian's capacity for restraint. Rather than leaving him in the dark, it was better to confront the truth head-on.

"Contact me immediately if anything happens."

The Valdemar Group headquarters stood tall and unyielding amid the storm.

"Miss Roland!"

The starry-eyed gaze gave Evelyn pause.

A deep male voice sounded from behind.

Sebastian had appeared in the lobby unnoticed, the corners of his lips lifted. For once, he wasn't in formal attire—a light-colored shirt softened his usual sharp demeanor.

The receptionist instantly fell silent, bowing her head nervously.

Evelyn turned, meeting those smiling peach-blossom eyes. Rainwater dripped from her hair, spreading tiny puddles on the polished floor.

"Looking for me?" Sebastian took a step closer.

His presence was suddenly intimate, carrying the crisp scent of rain. Evelyn tightened her grip on her bag—inside lay a secret that could shatter their fragile peace.
###Chapter 328

Everyone at Valdemar Group knew their CEO was in poor health and rarely made appearances. He seldom attended high-level meetings, let alone personally came downstairs to greet someone.

The receptionist clutched her ID badge, her palms damp with sweat.

Sebastian Valdemar was acting unusually today.

Standing beside Evelyn Roland, his usual icy demeanor had softened noticeably. There was even... a hint of deliberate ingratiation.

Though it felt disrespectful to think it, the scene resembled a man fawning over a woman.

He turned his wheelchair toward the mirrored wall, his pallid reflection staring back.

"Proceed with your plan." His voice was soft but deliberate. "Let me know if you need my cooperation."

Evelyn's tension eased.

Her biggest concern had been Sebastian letting emotions cloud his judgment. But her business partner proved more levelheaded than she'd expected.

"Thank you," she said sincerely.

As the elevator reached the top floor, Sebastian suddenly held the door open.

"Evelyn." It was the first time he'd addressed her so intimately. "No matter the outcome, I'm on your side."

Sunlight streamed through the floor-to-ceiling windows, gilding his gaunt profile in gold.

For the first time, Evelyn found this frail CEO remarkably dependable.
###Chapter 329

"My oversight caused you trouble."

Sebastian Valdemar's voice was low and restrained.

Silence answered.

"After all these years, you still lack composure."

The call ended. The man toyed with his cigar, eyes glinting with amusement.

Every move had been meticulously calculated, every trace erased flawlessly.

Confident, he exhaled a perfect smoke ring. No weaknesses remained to exploit.
###Chapter 330

###Chapter 331

The damp, chilly air reeked of mildew.

###Chapter 332

The entire operation unfolded without a single employee noticing.

In the interrogation room, Daniel spilled every detail of his crimes like a broken dam.

By dawn, an official statement dominated headlines:
[@Château Blanc Poisoned Wine Case Solved. Mastermind Daniel Murphy Arrested. Investigation confirms Château Blanc as the victim. Public urged to refrain from spreading rumors. Justice prevails.]
###Chapter 333

Sunlight streamed through the floor-to-ceiling windows of the villa, casting an eerie glow on the wine glass in the man's hand.

###Chapter 334

Evelyn Roland snapped back to reality, her fingertips trembling slightly. She looked up at the man who had appeared unexpectedly and shook her head gently. "It's nothing. What brings you here?"

Outside the pavilion, Sebastian Valdemar's figure stood tall against the twilight.

Evelyn nodded. As she turned, a strand of her hair brushed against his sleeve. Sebastian remained rooted in place until her slender silhouette vanished down the corridor.

He exhaled deeply, the tension in his shoulders finally easing. These days of deliberate distance had been for the investigation—and the fear of confronting the possibility. If his uncle had truly been involved in the poisoned wine case, how could he face her?

Thankfully, the truth wasn't the worst-case scenario.

Meanwhile, the Valrose family dining room blazed with light.

"Oliver, eat more." Wendy Valrose piled food onto her son's plate, her plump arms making the table wobble.

Oscar Valrose set down his chopsticks with a frown. "I heard you've been getting close to Isabella Langley?"

Oliver Valrose's chopsticks stilled. The braised pork in his bowl suddenly lost its flavor.

"Dad, let's talk after dinner," he muttered, shoveling rice into his mouth. Yet another face surfaced in his mind—Evelyn on the awards podium, the pale curve of her neck glowing under the spotlight.

"How far have things progressed?" Wendy pressed eagerly.

Oliver's Adam's apple bobbed as he forced down tasteless bites. His mother's voice sounded muffled, as if through frosted glass. His thoughts had already drifted to the grapevines of Château Blanc—and the woman who never spared him a second glance.
###Chapter 335

Isabella Langley was undeniably beautiful, with a petite and curvaceous figure that would normally make her Oliver Valrose's type.

But that was before he met Evelyn Roland.

Standing next to Evelyn, Isabella paled in comparison—like a firefly overshadowed by moonlight.

Evelyn possessed an innate, ethereal elegance that captivated attention even without makeup.

Oliver prided himself on being a connoisseur of women, surrounded by countless beauties.

Yet Evelyn struck him with a bone-deep awe he'd never experienced before.

A woman like her—this was the kind of unparalleled beauty he, Oliver Valrose, deserved to marry.

The memory of Evelyn's delicate profile made his lips curl into an infatuated smirk.

"Oliver, I've made inquiries. The Roland heiress is truly exceptional," Wendy Valrose patted her son's hand. "Propose tomorrow. A woman like her won't stay unattached for long."

A shadow flickered in Oliver's eyes.

"Do as your mother says," Oscar Valrose set down his teacup with finality. "Or get out of this house."

Marrying into the Roland family would elevate the Valrose name to new heights.

"Understood," Oliver gritted out, his gaze toward his father venomous.

Damn old man!

Using his credit cards as leverage?

How was he supposed to host tonight's pool party without funds? His reputation would be ruined.

"Old Ma will drive you tomorrow," Oscar said, his retreating footsteps like a death knell.

The door slammed shut behind him.

Oliver stared at his dwindling bank balance, knuckles cracking under the force of his clenched fists.

"Senile bastard!" he spat, fury boiling in his eyes.

His father's desperation to court the Rolands was embarrassingly transparent.

He knew exactly what was at stake—the Roland family's influence was something people would kill to access.

Even as a mere adopted daughter, Isabella was still a legitimate Roland.

Crack!

His phone shattered against the wall, the screen fracturing like a spiderweb.

Oliver laughed as he surveyed the wreckage.
###Chapter 336 

Oliver Valrose's eyes snapped open in the darkness, a wild idea exploding in his mind.

He bolted upright in bed, fingers digging unconsciously into his palms.

The image of Evelyn Roland's icy, breathtaking beauty haunted him.

"If only I could step through the Roland family's gates..."

He licked his cracked lips, eyes gleaming with feral intensity.

Isabella's breath hitched.

"Fine." The word barely escaped her clenched jaw. "But if you breathe a word of—"

After hanging up, he moved to the window, staring at the distant silhouette of the Roland mansion.

"Evelyn Roland..." His whisper slithered through the night. "This time, you won't escape me."

Moonlight stretched his shadow long and thin across the floor—a viper poised to strike.
###Chapter 337

Evelyn accepted the tray, her fingers brushing the warm porcelain.

"Mom" flashed across the screen.

"Evelyn? Why are you eating so late?"

"Mom, I—"

Evelyn swiftly pulled Bianca into frame.

###Chapter 338

Sophia Roland's eyes glistened with unshed tears as her fingers traced her daughter's face on the display.

Blenheim Palace glowed with light.

Sophia threw herself into her husband's arms like an excited schoolgirl. "Our daughter's coming home tomorrow!"

Dawn found the estate buzzing with activity.

Edward, unusually dressed in casual homewear, accompanied his wife on final inspections.

Sophia directed maids polishing vases. "Isabella, you're up early. Did we disturb you?"
###Chapter 339

"Mother, why is it so lively downstairs?" Isabella Langley rubbed her sleepy eyes as she descended the staircase, watching the servants bustle about.

###Chapter 340

###Chapter 341

Though they knew she was dating, an unannounced visit...

###Chapter 342

"We're here."

###Chapter 343

"Sister." Isabella's eyes instantly welled up with tears, her voice trembling.

###Chapter 346

###Chapter 348

###Chapter 349

Oliver continued his grand speech, oblivious to the exchanged glances between the Roland parents. Alexander peeled shrimp with deliberate slowness, his gaze flickering between Sebastian and Oliver.

"It's getting late."

The moment dessert plates were cleared, Alexander smiled at Oliver. Crystal chandelier light fractured across his glasses, obscuring the ice in his eyes.

Her words died as she caught him staring at Evelyn's décolletage. Sebastian's head snapped up, dark pupils churning with violence.

"Something the matter, Mr. Valrose?"

Evelyn's feather-light voice sent Oliver flushing crimson. Isabella dug nails into her palms, watching Sebastian drape his tailored blazer over Evelyn's shoulders.

That bespoke piece she'd seen in last week's magazine—priced at six figures—now cocooned another woman.

Evelyn turned suddenly, her glassy eyes reflecting Isabella's contorted expression. Oliver had already fled toward the foyer, knocking over a celadon vase.

He murmured to his parents, gaze sliding to where Sebastian fastened a cashmere scarf around Evelyn's neck. The man's aristocratic profile belonged in a museum, yet his fingers moved with impossible tenderness.

"Evelyn!"

###Chapter 370

###Chapter 372

###Chapter 373

"Wait for me," he murmured. "I'll take you away from here."

A smile warmed Sebastian's eyes as he reached to caress her cheek—then stopped mid-motion.

"Everyone here is a businessperson," he turned, his voice measured. "You should all know Valdemar Group's standing in this city."

The grand hall fell deathly silent.

"Since we're all gathered," Sebastian ascended the steps, a faint smirk playing on his lips, "I should mention—I'm extremely protective of what's mine."

He slowly twisted the ring on his finger. "Those who cross me... should consider the consequences in advance."

"Valdemar Group stands firmly with Evelyn Roland."

The temperature in the hall seemed to plummet.

His razor-sharp aura sent chills down every spine. Several seasoned executives broke into cold sweats.

They'd clearly provoked the wrong man.

"What matters most to you," Sebastian said coolly, "is prosperity."

"Y-yes, exactly..." a few CEOs stammered in agreement.

"Then tell me," his gaze turned glacial, "who exactly holds the reins to your prosperity?"

The younger entrepreneurs immediately scrambled to distance themselves. "Mr. Valdemar, we had no part in this!"

Everyone knew Sebastian's reputation. The man who'd salvaged Valdemar Group from crisis and built it into an empire was no ordinary opponent.

Crossing him now would be suicide.

Sebastian's piercing stare made several men turn to bow at Evelyn. "Our apologies, Miss Roland. We were out of line."

Evelyn lifted her gaze to meet Sebastian's.

"We're leaving," he gave a slight nod.

The icy edge in his expression melted instantly as he turned back to her.

"Let's go."

He took Evelyn's hand and walked out, ignoring the murderous glares from her brothers and the terrified stares of the crowd.

"It's over..." The ringleader of the harassment collapsed to his knees, drenched in sweat.

"Nonsense!" An older CEO clutched his incense stick like a lifeline. "If we pray sincerely, the gods will protect us!"

His white-knuckled grip betrayed his false bravado.
###Chapter 377

Sebastian's hand still held Evelyn's as they descended Mount Pilatus.

His palm was broad and warm, sending tingles through her fingertips.

He released her instantly, throat bobbing. "My apologies."

"Thank you for earlier."

"Between us, such words aren't necessary."

The statement pricked her heart like a needle.

She bit her lip, edging nearer.

His lips quirked at the sight of her flushed earlobe.

###Chapter 378

"Yes! I'll get it right away!"

Alice practically fled the room.

Alice's shoulders hunched instinctively.

Evelyn's eyes turned icy.

Mount Pilatus.

The novice monk.

The acting abbot.

Isabella Langley.

The connections snapped into place in Evelyn's mind. Her knuckles whitened as her grip tightened, a cold glint flashing in her eyes.
###Chapter 379

###Chapter 380

Isabella's pupils constricted.

The jade bracelet suddenly burned against her skin. She remembered the drenched figure on the mountain path at dawn—frail as mist about to dissolve.

The scent of vegetarian dishes drifted from the dining hall.

Footsteps approached the meditation hall.

Sophia Roland's voice carried through: "Isabella? Is the master keeping you for lunch?"

Isabella's grip tightened around the teacup.

The prescription. The bracelet. The villagers. Fragments swirled in her mind. Suddenly she understood—this ordinary morning was unraveling an extraordinary secret.
###Chapter 381

The tranquil monastery courtyard buzzed with activity outside the sandalwood-scented meditation hall.

###Chapter 391

Sebastian Valdemar's gaze flickered, his eyes reflecting only her.

No one had expected this seemingly aloof young woman to share such a close bond with Old Chen.

Evelyn gave a brief explanation.

Six months ago, Old Chen had suffered a sudden heart attack on the street. She happened to pass by and saved him with her extraordinary acupuncture skills, pulling him back from death's door.

Later, Old Chen tracked her down to Château Blanc, and their relationship deepened. With no children of his own, he treated her like a beloved granddaughter.

Recalling this, Old Chen's eyes shimmered with affection.

The conference room was so quiet you could hear a pin drop.

All eyes turned to Oliver Valrose, their gazes practically screaming, What do you have to say now?

Oliver squirmed under the scrutiny before suddenly slamming the table. "You think you can fool everyone with some random old man? Evelyn, do you take us for idiots?"

He pulled out his phone with a sneer. "Let me call the real Old Chen. Then we'll see how you explain this!"

The crowd's expressions turned odd.

Evelyn merely arched a brow, not even bothering to lift her eyelids.
###Chapter 405

A thunderous roar erupted from the phone.

"How dare you!"

On the projection screen in the meditation hall, Elder Chen abruptly stood, slamming his palm on the table. Behind him, a dozen experts in the conference room rose in unison, their piercing gazes fixed on the screen.

Silver-haired yet ramrod straight, Elder Chen's usually warm eyes now gleamed like sharpened blades.

"It seems I've been too modest these years."

His voice boomed with unquestionable authority.

Someone immediately snatched Oliver's phone and aimed it at the camera.

###Chapter 406

She hadn't forgotten the knife he'd used to stab Alice.

A well-dressed lawyer stepped forward from the crowd.

"Miss Roland."

"He's all yours."

Sebastian gave a signal, and security dragged Oliver away. The lawyer followed closely behind.

Isabella Langley cowered in a corner, wishing she could strangle this idiot.

Evelyn crossed her arms, watching the farce unfold with icy detachment.

"Everyone, let's resume the charity auction." Scarlett Galatea smoothly stepped in to diffuse the tension.
###Chapter 407

The air in the venue suddenly turned heavy.

Business tycoons exchanged glances, their eyes lingering on Scarlett Galatea.

As Oliver Valrose was escorted out by security, his shouts dissolved into the murmuring crowd.

###Chapter 411

Rain lashed against the windows like bullets, the heavy drops cracking against the glass. I curled into the corner of the sofa, fingers twisting the edge of the blanket absently.

I stared at his slender fingers, still glistening with rain. "You know I won't."

"Why are you still here?" His voice was ragged.

"You'll hurt yourself like this."

She reached for his hand. The scorching heat of his skin startled her.

He tried to pull away, but her grip tightened.

"Stop torturing yourself."

His head snapped up. Bloodshot eyes locked onto hers.

His fingers absently traced the back of her hand as he rasped, "Do you have any idea what you're doing, Ms. Roland?"

His Adam's apple bobbed. The next words came through clenched teeth.

"I'm a man. A very... normal man."
###Chapter 417

"I'm completely sober."

Evelyn Roland's whisper ignited the air like a spark.

The private room's soundproofing swallowed all noise, leaving only their interwoven breaths. Sebastian Valdemar's chest heaved violently, his Adam's apple bobbing as he fought for control.

His knuckles turned white.

He abruptly released her wrist and stepped back.

Evelyn advanced instead, her stilettos sinking soundlessly into the plush carpet. Tilting her chin up, she parted her crimson lips. "What are you afraid of, Mr. Valdemar?"

"Don't play with fire." His voice was gravel-rough.

"What if I refuse?"

Rising onto her toes, she enveloped him in the scent of roses. Sebastian's pupils contracted—the last thread of his restraint snapping.

His arm banded around her waist.

Heat seared through fabric to brand her skin. His other hand gripped her jaw, thumb grinding against her lower lip.

"You'll regret this."

The warning dissolved against her mouth as he claimed her in a savage kiss. It was all teeth and desperation, a caged beast finally unleashed.

Evelyn laughed into his mouth.

Her arms twined around his neck, feeling every muscle in his body lock. The response shattered Sebastian completely. He cradled her skull, deepening the kiss with ruthless intent.

Breaths tangled.

The clash of lips and tongues turned punishing. Sebastian kissed like he wanted to devour her whole. Pinned between the cold wall and his scorching body, Evelyn arched against him.

A gasp escaped her as oxygen dwindled. Instinct made her bite down. Sebastian groaned—not in pain, but dark exhilaration. He wrenched both wrists above her head, knee forcing her thighs apart.

"Too late to stop now."

His voice dripped with predatory hunger. The collar of his shirt gaped open, revealing the sharp lines of his collarbones. This feral version of Sebastian made Evelyn's pulse stutter.

Beneath that polished exterior lurked a primal predator.

His mouth trailed fire down her neck, branding her collarbone with crimson marks. Evelyn tipped her head back, feeling the coiled tension in his frame—a volcano on the verge of eruption.

"That hurts—"

Her breathy protest earned tighter restraint. Sebastian's heated exhale scorched her ear. "We're just getting started."
###Chapter 418

"Sebastian!"

Evelyn suddenly grasped the man's wandering hand, her fingertips trembling slightly. She tilted her head up to meet his lust-darkened gaze. "Look at me. Who am I?"

"Evelyn..." His voice was rough, his Adam's apple bobbing.

Before he could finish, his lips crashed down on hers, searing and possessive. The strap of her dress slipped off her shoulder, revealing skin like polished pearls in the dim light.

"I love you..." Sebastian murmured against her neck, leaving a trail of red marks in his wake.

Evelyn's eyes grew damp, her nails digging into his back. Wave after wave of pleasure crashed over her, leaving her clinging to him like he was her only lifeline.

At two in the morning, the storm finally subsided.

Exhausted, Evelyn couldn't even lift a finger. Half-asleep, she felt someone gently caress her cheek.

"Thank you." Sebastian gazed at her with satiated clarity, his eyes now sober.

When dawn's light crept through the curtains, Evelyn woke to a dull ache in her waist. She tried to turn over but was immediately pulled back by a muscular arm.

Sebastian's sleeping face was inches away, his long lashes casting delicate shadows. Unable to resist, she reached out and lightly brushed his eyelashes.

"Mischief." His eyes flew open, capturing her wandering fingers.

He nuzzled against her like a large, affectionate dog, burying his face in the crook of her neck. "Evelyn..."

"Haven't you called my name enough for one night?"

Suddenly, he propped himself up and looked into her eyes with startling intensity. "Marry me."

Evelyn arched a brow. "What if I say no?"

"Then I'll keep asking until you say yes."

She deliberately drew out her next words. "And... what if I fall for someone else?"

The air turned to ice.

Sebastian's jaw tightened. After a long pause, he finally spoke, his voice raw. "Then I'll let you go." He pulled her closer, pressing his face into her hair. "As long as you're happy."

A sudden breeze parted the curtains, and a beam of sunlight fell across their intertwined fingers—illuminating the diamond ring that glittered between them.
###Chapter 419

Evelyn Roland had intended to tease him, but when she caught the fleeting hurt in his eyes, it felt like a needle pricking her heart.

An unexpected ache welled up inside her.

Her fingers tightened around the bedsheet instinctively.

"I agree."

"Hmm?"

"Never mind."

Evelyn arched a brow, deliberately drawing out her words. "What a shame."

"You just said yes!"

Sebastian Valdemar's eyes lit up instantly, his entire being melting into tenderness.

"Say it again, Evelyn."

His voice was so soft it could drip honey, as if coaxing his most precious treasure.

"I said, yes."

When she turned her head, she met his intense gaze.

His deep pupils reflected her current state with perfect clarity—dark hair splayed across white pillows, lips slightly swollen, bare shoulders glowing like pearls in the morning light.

Sebastian's Adam's apple bobbed.

He suddenly leaned down, pressing a trail of featherlight kisses along her swan-like neck.

"Time to get up?"

"Mhm."

As she sat up, the sheets slipped away, and Evelyn gasped at the sudden chill, scrambling back under the covers.

She wasn't usually prudish, but after last night's relentless vigor, she had to consider the state of her waist.

A low chuckle brushed her ear.

"Mr. Valdemar, don't make me take it back."

Her attempt at sternness was utterly endearing. Sebastian knew it was an act, yet his chest still tightened.

His smile vanished instantly.

"I'll have clothes sent over."

He grabbed his discarded shirt from the floor and disappeared into the bathroom.

Through the frosted glass, Evelyn glimpsed his blurred silhouette before checking her phone—nearly noon.

Her gaze fell on the shredded fabric littering the floor, and she sighed, pressing a hand to her forehead.

That had been her favorite dress.

Premium silk, reduced to rags by his bare hands.

After fresh clothes arrived, they freshened up quickly.

"I'll take you home."

The moment they stepped out of the suite, Sebastian seized her hand.

When their fingers intertwined, he leaned down, his warm breath tickling her ear.

"No need."

Evelyn clung to her last shred of rationality, stopping in the parking lot.

"Let's keep this between us for now."

"A secret relationship?" Sebastian arched a brow.
###Chapter 420

"Wait a little longer." Evelyn Roland leaned against the car door, her fingertips lightly tapping the window. "The timing isn't right yet."

Sebastian Valdemar frowned slightly, a flicker of disappointment in his eyes. "Am I really that embarrassing to be seen with?"

Sunlight filtered through the leaves, casting dappled shadows across his face—highlighting the faint scratch on his cheek. Evelyn couldn't resist reaching out to trace it with her fingers. "If news gets out that the Valdemar heir was poisoned, do you think those people would let me—your obvious weakness—off the hook?"

She paused, lowering her voice. "Not to mention... your father's side..."

Evelyn arched a brow. This man had just been sulking, and now he looked like a cat who'd gotten the cream.

"Let's go." She pulled her hand free and turned to open the car door.

"Wait." Sebastian suddenly tugged at the hem of her coat. "Text me when you arrive."

Evelyn glanced back and saw the blatant expectation in his eyes. It reminded her of how this wolf had pinned her to the couch last night, kissing her senseless. Her ears burned, and she slammed the door shut with a sharp click.

In the rearview mirror, his tall figure remained rooted in place until the car turned the corner and he vanished from sight.

At the Valdemar Group headquarters, the receptionist was touching up her makeup when the elevator dinged. She glanced over—and nearly drew her lipstick down to her chin.

"G-Good morning, Mr. Valdemar!"

The entire lobby fell silent. Everyone gaped at the man in a pink hoodie—their usually icy, ruthless CEO, who was not only two hours late but also radiating an unmistakable aura of... satisfaction?

"Morning." Sebastian actually nodded in response before striding toward his private elevator, his steps unusually light.

The employees exchanged stunned looks.

"Am I hallucinating? Did the boss just wear... pink?"
"Is that a... mark on his neck?"
"Shh! Do you have a death wish?"

On the 28th floor, Theodore Ashcroft was reviewing meeting materials when the office door opened. "Just leave the documents on the desk," he said without looking up.

"Clear my afternoon schedule."

The familiar deep voice made Theodore jerk his head up. His folder hit the floor with a thud as he took in his boss's noticeably snug hoodie and the faint scratches peeking above the collar. His brain short-circuited.

"Sir, would you... like some coffee?" he managed weakly.

Sebastian glanced at his phone's lock screen—a photo of the two of them together—and smirked. "Double sugar."

Half an hour later, a dazed Theodore floated out of the office, only to be ambushed by curious colleagues.

"Theo, is the boss...?"
"Don't ask." Theodore clutched his chest. "I need a moment."

Meanwhile, Evelyn's phone buzzed.

"I'm here," came the unmistakably cheerful voice on the other end. "How's your side?"

Evelyn surveyed the warehouse full of oak barrels and sighed. "Sebastian, it's work hours."

"But I miss you." His voice dropped, warm and intimate, as if he were standing right behind her. "Last night, when you dug your nails into my back—"

"Shut up!" She hung up abruptly, but the tips of her ears betrayed her, flushing pink.

The winery staff peeked at their usually no-nonsense boss, now glaring at her phone—yet failing to suppress the tiny smile tugging at her lips.
###Chapter 421

Theodore Ashcroft stood outside the CEO's office, his finger hovering in midair, hesitating to knock.

A rare gentle voice drifted through the crack in the door. "Remember to eat on time. Don't overwork yourself."

The sound sent a shiver down Theodore's spine. For a moment, he thought he'd come to the wrong floor.

The person on the other end of the line must have said something, because Sebastian Valdemar chuckled softly. "I miss you too."

Theodore's hand froze in place, caught between retreating and proceeding.

"Come in."

Sebastian cut him off, his long fingers tapping impatiently on the desk.

Sebastian paused mid-flip, his gaze deepening.

"Yes. It's a collaboration personally spearheaded by Director Galatea."

Sebastian closed the file, fingertips brushing the cover. He remembered the way Evelyn Roland's eyes had reddened when Theodore Valdemar first called her "Mom."

The decision came so swiftly that even Theodore was taken aback. But he quickly realized—this had to be about Miss Roland.

"Anything else?"

Sebastian arched a brow when his assistant remained rooted in place.

"Hm."

That single syllable made the air in the office freeze. Sebastian's warning glare had Theodore clamping his mouth shut instantly.

"I'll go send that email right away!"

Theodore practically fled. As the door clicked shut behind him, he heard the telltale chime of a phone being unlocked.

Out in the hallway, he wiped sweat from his brow. Looks like he'd have to start calling her "Madam" from now on.

Meanwhile, Sebastian was already dialing Olivia Valdemar's number.

"Sis, there's a project I need you on."

Gazing at the sunlight streaming through the window, he pictured Evelyn helping Theodore with his therapy exercises.

"It's for children with autism spectrum disorder."

Olivia's delighted voice came through the line. "An official project? Perfect! I'll add another fifty million in funding."

Sebastian chuckled. "Knew you'd support it."

After hanging up, he opened his photo gallery. The most recent picture showed Evelyn bending to tie Theodore's shoelaces, sunlight gilding them both in gold.

The man's stern features softened imperceptibly.
###Chapter 422

Victor Galatea carefully placed Valdemar Group's response letter in the innermost compartment of his briefcase, his fingers lingering on the document before withdrawing. Standing by his office window, he watched the endless stream of traffic below, his brow slightly furrowed.

A photo of Sebastian Valdemar and Evelyn Roland standing side by side glared back from the display.
###Chapter 423

A woman.

Meanwhile, Scarlett Galatea scrolled through the trending list with satisfaction. The trolls she'd paid handsomely had already stirred chaos, flooding the comments with venom.

"Turn up the heat." She smirked as she messaged the gossip accounts. "I want Evelyn Roland ruined!"

Within two hours, #EvelynRolandAbusesChildren exploded to the top of the trends. The official accounts of Château Blanc and Roland Group were bombarded with furious demands for an apology.

"Serves her right." Scarlett watched the numbers climb, finally allowing herself a triumphant smile. "This is what happens when you steal my projects."

Chaos erupted in Roland Group's PR department. The director burst into Edward Roland's office, beads of sweat on his forehead.

"What?!"

Edward slammed his hands on the desk, rattling the teacup. He quickly created a family group chat—excluding Evelyn—and added everyone.

The moment the messages went through, the chat exploded.

Alexander Roland: Who dares mess with my sister?!
Julian Roland: We're not standing by this time!
Isabella Langley: Should I contact my media friends?

The brothers' messages poured in, each laced with barely contained rage. Edward watched the screen, his expression turning dangerous.

###Chapter 444

The post went viral instantly. Netizens erupted with speculation about her next move.

Ding—
Ding-ding-ding—

Four consecutive transfer notifications chimed. Evelyn arched a brow at the staggering sums on her screen.

Sebastian's gaze also locked onto the amounts. Then—a fifth transfer alert popped up.

All three froze in unison.
###Chapter 445

Evelyn stared at her phone screen for a long time.

The nine-figure sum Sebastian had just transferred glared back at her. The endless string of zeros made her eyes sting.

She finally tapped "Accept."

She also collected the transfers from the Roland family.

"Don't."

Compared to Sebastian, who could casually transfer nine figures, her savings were practically pocket change.

The next morning.

Sunshine Special School.

"Look! It's Evelyn Roland!"

The couple struggled against the security guards, screaming, "Evelyn, you vile woman! Using our daughter for fame! You deserve to die!"

Evelyn immediately recognized them—Ruby's biological parents.

The ones who had abandoned their child.

The crowd jeered:

"Disgusting!"

"Exploiting a disabled child for clout—have you no shame?"

Security formed a human barricade, holding back the furious mob.

Evelyn calmly scanned the crowd.

Her composure only fueled their anger.

Thud!

A water bottle flew toward her.

She sidestepped, and it missed her by inches.

"Ms. Roland, I'm so sorry—" The school director rushed forward, sweating profusely. "We'll issue a statement—"

"Let them in," Evelyn interrupted, her gaze locked on the couple. "But keep them away from Ruby."

The director nodded hastily.

Inside the classroom, the children were having their lesson.

The moment Evelyn entered, the restless atmosphere stilled.

"Ruby."

As Evelyn approached the corner, the usually silent little girl reached out—asking to be held.
###Chapter 446

"Let's take the child outside for some air."

The little girl trembled violently, burrowing deeper into Evelyn Roland's arms.

Evelyn's voice was calm, but her gaze was sharp as ice.

[Such theatrics!]
[Faking it!]

The innocent words silenced the live chat.

The couple paled.

Viewer numbers skyrocketed.

###Chapter 447

[Mr. Valdemar?!]

###Chapter 448

###Chapter 450

Margaret Lefèvre paced anxiously across the living room until Scarlett Galatea appeared at the doorway. Only then did her racing heart settle slightly.

Scarlett's vision darkened momentarily. She nearly lost her balance.

"Is it critical?"

The doctor's silence spoke volumes.

After seeing the doctor out, Scarlett rushed upstairs. The elderly woman on the bed looked gaunt, aged years in mere days.

"You must stay strong, Miss." Margaret's eyes were red-rimmed as she tried to comfort her.

Scarlett nodded mechanically, her fingers moving on their own to dial a number.

"Scarlett?"

###Chapter 451

"Why are you looking at me like that?" Evelyn Roland's lips curved slightly, amusement flickering in her eyes. "Do I seem like the petty type?"

Scarlett Galatea's matter truly didn't weigh on her mind. Since Sebastian Valdemar had spoken up, and it involved a life-or-death situation, she wasn't about to make a fuss over something so trivial. Unless, of course, the other party crossed a line.

###Chapter 452

###Chapter 453

###Chapter 454

###Chapter 455

###Chapter 456

###Chapter 457

The surveillance room supervisor rushed over with a laptop, followed by the hospital director wiping sweat from his brow.

Only when the ECG flatlined did he panic and halt the procedure.

Then Evelyn arrived—and a miracle occurred.

Within thirty minutes, that deadly flatline revived into a steady rhythm.

Evelyn's skilled hands moved with precision, her surgical team executing her commands flawlessly.

Even at double speed, the breathtaking rescue left everyone awestruck.
###Chapter 458

The operating room lights flickered off, the air thick enough to choke on.

Dr. Neil Harrison slumped to the floor, fingers clawing at the tiles until his knuckles turned white. His lips trembled. "I followed every protocol... The old woman's condition was too complex—"

Silence swallowed his words.

Evelyn Roland leaned against the wall, idly tapping her folded arm. A humorless laugh escaped her. "Playing God when you knew the risks—is that your idea of medical ethics?"

Dr. Harrison's Adam's apple bobbed, sweat trickling down his temples.

Dark spots danced in his vision. Sebastian Valdemar stood three paces away, while Scarlett Galatea's grip on her phone turned her fingers bone-white. Any one of them could destroy him with a snap of their fingers.

Worse was the hospital director's glacial stare. Performing an unauthorized cross-hospital procedure was bad enough—now there was a corpse involved.

"Video evidence clear enough for you?" Evelyn straightened, her lab coat flaring. "Miss Galatea, he's yours to deal with."

Scarlett's chest heaved.

Sebastian's voice cut through the tension. "Hesitation breeds ruin." His gaze flicked to Scarlett's quivering lashes. "Need me to handle it?"

"No—" Scarlett stumbled back half a step. "I need to see Grandmother."

Dr. Harrison lunged for her hem, only to be wrestled down by security. He twisted toward Evelyn, pupils dilating wildly. "You can't—"

"Director." Sebastian's interruption came like an ice pick.

The balding director bowed obsequiously. "Mr. Valdemar, rest assured we'll conduct a thorough investigation."

The steady beep of monitors echoed from the corridor's end. Evelyn massaged her temples as Sebastian's arm encircled her shoulders. "Home."

Passing the crumpled doctor, Evelyn paused. The man on the floor shook like a leaf in a storm, his lab coat wrinkled beyond recognition.
###Chapter 459

"Dr. Roland, please wait."

The hospital director hurried after her, eyes gleaming with admiration. Having reviewed the surgical footage repeatedly, he was awestruck by the young female surgeon's extraordinary skills.

As the head of this elite medical institution, he'd always prided himself on his expertise. But Evelyn Roland's flawless technique made him recognize true mastery for the first time.

"Dr. Roland, we sincerely invite you to join our team." His voice carried genuine respect. "We'll offer you the most competitive compensation package."

Other physicians gathered around, especially those who'd witnessed the surgery—their gazes brimming with reverence. They yearned to learn from this brilliant surgeon, yet none dared overstep.

Sebastian Valdemar's possessive glare had made the boundaries abundantly clear.

"No, thank you." Evelyn's refusal was crisp. "I don't work well with constraints."

Disappointment flickered across the director's face, though he'd anticipated this outcome.

——

Inside the private suite, Scarlett Galatea clutched her grandmother's frail hand, tears soaking the sheets.

"Miss, Dr. Roland assured us Madeline will recover," Mrs. Lefèvre murmured soothingly.

Scarlett's expression darkened—until she felt the faintest twitch against her palm.

"Grandmother?" Her head snapped up just as the elderly woman's eyelids fluttered open.

"Scarlett..." Madeline whispered weakly before succumbing to exhaustion again.

"Get the doctor!" Scarlett shouted.

Mrs. Lefèvre rushed out, finding Evelyn mid-conversation. "Dr. Roland! She's awake!"

This exceeded even Evelyn's projections. One elegant brow arched. "Let's assess her."

A retinue of physicians fell into step behind her—an unspoken acknowledgment of her authority.

At the ICU entrance, Evelyn glanced back at Sebastian, silently instructing him to wait. The last thing this porcelain-skinned aristocrat needed was more exposure to pathogens.

The corner of his mouth lifted in acquiescence.
###Chapter 460

The sterile operating room hummed with activity as doctors suited up in protective gear.

Metal instruments clinked sharply against trays in the hallway.

"Vitals stabilizing!" A nurse called out excitedly from the monitoring station.

Madeline Galatea's eyelids fluttered weakly before opening.

Her clouded gaze settled on a striking young woman standing nearby.

Margaret Lefèvre stepped forward quickly. "Madam, this is Dr. Roland. She saved you."

The elderly woman studied Evelyn Roland's face with surprising intensity.

Evelyn returned the scrutiny calmly. Despite her frail condition, the matriarch's commanding presence remained undiminished.

"Let me examine you," Evelyn said coolly, her movements gentle despite her clinical tone.

Madeline suddenly grasped her hand. "Child, I owe you my life."

"Just doing my job." Evelyn deftly withdrew her hand. "You need rest. Try not to exert yourself."

In the corner, Scarlett Galatea dug her nails into her palms.

"Scarlett!" Madeline's voice rang out unexpectedly strong. "Come meet Dr. Roland."

The two young women locked eyes.

"An honor," Evelyn said with a faint smile.

Scarlett forced a tight-lipped grin.

Madeline chatted animatedly with Evelyn, oblivious to her granddaughter's strained expression.

"Where's Sebastian?" the matriarch asked suddenly.

Heavy footsteps approached from the corridor.

Sebastian Valdemar strode in, his gaze immediately finding Evelyn.

"You're looking much better, Madam," he remarked in that deep baritone.

Madeline beamed. "All thanks to you two lovebirds—"

"Madam!" Evelyn's ears turned pink.

Sebastian's lips twitched, though his tone remained professional. "Credit goes to Dr. Roland's medical expertise."

The room's atmosphere shifted palpably.
###Chapter 461

Madeline Galatea studied Evelyn Roland intently, her admiration growing more evident with each passing moment.

This girl was truly extraordinary.

Those clear, unflinching eyes showed not a trace of timidity. In all her years, Madeline had met countless people, but rarely had she encountered someone so composed at such a young age.

That calm, unshakable poise alone commanded respect.

"Madame Galatea, since you're recovering well, I'll take my leave now." Evelyn deftly gathered her silver needles with practiced efficiency.

Madeline exchanged a glance with Margaret Lefèvre, both women's eyes brimming with gratitude.

"Dear child, once this old bones feels better, you must come visit." Madeline's voice was warm. "Margaret will prepare her specialties for you."

Evelyn gave a slight nod, her gaze briefly flickering to Scarlett Galatea before turning away.

She had barely stepped out of the ICU when hurried footsteps followed.

"Miss Roland!" Scarlett caught up, pulling a black card from her purse. "Ten million. Please accept it."

"Unnecessary." Evelyn's tone remained detached.

Saving lives had never been about payment. Had Sebastian Valdemar not intervened, she wouldn't have set foot in this hospital.

"You must take it!" Scarlett insisted, thrusting the card forward. "Grandmother insisted. You saved her life—you saved our entire family."

Evelyn gently pushed the card away. "It was nothing."

Undeterred, Scarlett pressed it into her palm. "The PIN is six zeros." Without waiting for a response, she spun on her heel and marched off, shoulders set with determination.

Back in the room, Madeline reclined against the pillows as her granddaughter returned. "Why the rush, child? I'm perfectly fine now."

Scarlett buried her face against the elderly woman's shoulder, voice trembling. "You terrified me..."

"Silly girl." Madeline stroked her hair. "Thank Mr. Valdemar and Evelyn. We owe them everything today."

At Sebastian's name, Scarlett's expression shifted. "Grandmother... what do you think of Mr. Valdemar?"

"That young man..." Madeline's eyes sparkled. "Handsome, distinguished, though he seems rather frail. But..."

Her tone turned playful. "Standing beside Evelyn? They complemented each other perfectly. Like a pair carved from jade."

Scarlett's smile froze. "What did you say?"

"I said they look destined for each other." Madeline chuckled. "Can't you see it?"

Scarlett's fingers tightened imperceptibly around the bedsheet.
###Chapter 462

The hospital corridor was bathed in harsh fluorescent light.

Scarlett clenched her fists so tightly her nails dug into her palms. Behind her, excited chatter spilled from the hospital room—Grandma and Mrs. Lefèvre's voices, each word like a knife twisting in her chest.

"They make such a perfect match!"
"Did you see the way Sebastian looked at Evelyn?"

Her stiletto slammed into the wall, sending a shower of plaster dust to the floor. Scarlett stared at the dent she'd left, her chest heaving.

Why?
Why did everyone think they belonged together?

Meanwhile, the black Maybach glided through the night.

Evelyn leaned against the seat with her eyes closed, long lashes casting shadows. Sebastian kept stealing glances at her, his grip tightening on the steering wheel.

"We're here."

The car stopped in front of the villa. Sebastian's voice was soft when he spoke. Evelyn opened her eyes, still drowsy.

"Need me to carry you inside?"
His deep tone held a hint of hope.

She shook her head—but as she pushed the car door open, her pinky hooked around his. That tiny gesture made his eyes light up instantly.

Fingers intertwined, they walked toward the entrance. The night breeze carried the faint scent of flowers.

"This is far enough." Evelyn stopped at the door.

Sebastian suddenly pulled her into his arms. Warm breath brushed her ear: "Remember. No other man steps foot in your home except me."

The tips of her ears turned pink, but she feigned composure as she pushed him away. "Are you restricting my freedom, Mr. Valdemar?"

"What if I am?" He arched a brow, danger glinting in his gaze.

Evelyn chuckled and swiped her keycard. As the door closed, she caught him still standing there, watching intently through the gap.

She slammed it shut deliberately—but the moment she turned away, her lips curved up.

Outside, Sebastian stared at the door, his Adam's apple bobbing. After a long pause, he shook his head and left.

Back in the hospital corridor, Scarlett's phone screen lit up. An unknown number had sent a photo—Sebastian holding Evelyn intimately.

Her nails scraped across the screen with a screech.
###Chapter 463

A tall figure emerged from the corner of the parking lot.

Sunlight slanted across the man's sharp profile—Alexander Roland, Evelyn's third brother.

He had arrived ten minutes ago. His brow furrowed when his gaze landed on the familiar black Maybach.

Wasn't that Sebastian Valdemar's car?

Why was it parked outside his sister's company?

Just as he was about to step out to investigate, Sebastian drove off in haste.

"Strange..."

Alexander drummed his fingers absently against the steering wheel.

"Was he here to see Evelyn?"

From his angle, he'd completely missed the tense exchange at the entrance.

The car door slammed shut as Alexander adjusted his suit cuffs.

She paused mid-step. "What trouble could I possibly be in?"

"He just left." Her tone was casual.

Alexander's pupils constricted. "So he was here for you?"

"He gave me a ride back. That's all."

He gripped her shoulders. "Don't tell me you and that guy—"

"Alex!" Evelyn cut him off with an exasperated sigh. "It's strictly business."

"Cough—"

Evelyn choked on her water, the tips of her ears turning suspiciously pink.

"No!" Her denial came sharp and swift.

Yet unbidden memories surfaced—tangled limbs in a hotel room, scorching breaths, burning palms...

"Why are you blushing harder?" His eyes narrowed.

Evelyn ducked her head under the guise of coughing, avoiding his scrutiny.

"Just choked, that's all."

Only after triple-checking her expression did Alexander finally relax.

"Good." He ruffled her hair, then abruptly changed tack. "Not that I'm against you dating..."

Evelyn rolled her eyes discreetly.

"When you're older, you can date as many guys as you want..."

His lecturing voice faded into the background as Evelyn gazed at the darkening twilight outside, her thoughts drifting to that dangerously alluring man.
###Chapter 464

Morning sunlight filtered through the gap in the curtains as I rubbed my tired eyes.

Staying up late talking with Edward last night left my head still foggy.

###Chapter 465

The words died in his throat under her glacial stare.

Alexander swallowed hard. In this moment, he knew with absolute certainty—he was dancing on the razor's edge of oblivion.
###Chapter 466

Alexander Roland met his sister Evelyn's amused gaze, his knees inexplicably weakening.

###Chapter 467

###Chapter 468

###Chapter 469

"Daniel, do you think Ms. Roland will be satisfied?"

Inside the laboratory, Daniel and David Murphy waited anxiously. The success of this drug development owed much to Evelyn Roland. From initial data corrections to every critical milestone, her precise guidance had been indispensable.

Though they were the primary researchers, everyone knew Evelyn was the driving force behind this project.

When they first took on the autism medication research, the brothers had felt overwhelming pressure. Now, with a breakthrough finally achieved, they couldn’t wait to report their progress to Evelyn.

###Chapter 470

###Chapter 471

"Fine, I'll be the hands-off boss then."

Evelyn Roland's lips curved slightly, a glint of mischief flashing in her eyes. She knew full well how much Sebastian Valdemar cared for her.

Sebastian's smile deepened at her words.

Theodore moved swiftly. By noon, all official Valdemar Group accounts simultaneously pinned an announcement.

Within one minute of posting, comments surpassed a thousand.

Many parents of autistic children wept with relief.

In under ten minutes, reposts broke ten thousand. Comments skyrocketed.

Unprecedented engagement!

Theodore delivered the latest data immediately after lunch.
